Transform Sri Lanka

The last time El NiÃ±o affected Sri Lanka, between 2016 and 2017, more than 2 million people were affectedâ€”first by flooding and landslides, and then by a severe drought. Currently in its development phase, is forecasted to peak towards the end of 2023 in the Asia Pacific region. If the situation continues, we must be ready to embrace a similar, if not worse, scenario that will have direct impact on communities, especially in the availability of water. 

Today is a particularly opportune time to bring this issue to the limelight as Sri Lanka hosts the fifth Forum of Ministers and Environment Authorities of Asia Pacific, with the aim of contributing to the outcome of the sixth session of the UN Environment Programme Assembly happening in 2024. 

The Green Climate Fund financed, Climate Resilient Integrated Water Management Project (CRIWMP) implemented by the Government of Sri Lanka together with United Nations Development Programme - UNDP in Sri Lanka, offers a blueprint to reviving Sri Lankaâ€™s cascade system for water resilience, incorporating modern technologies and climate resilient infrastructure, climate information services and agro-met advisories to create a more sustainable dry-zone eco-system and enhance climate resilience. 

READ MORE: https://bit.ly/46CrmSx

On May 18th, at Making Cents International's Global Youth Economic Opportunities Summit in Silver Spring, Maryland, IESCâ€™s USAID-funded youth employment and entrepreneurship program, YouLead, led a presentation in partnership with ACDI/VOCA and Chemonics on the approaches, tools, successes, and challenges of building alternative pathways to get youth into the IT sector. The presentation, The Leaky Pipeline â€“ Alternative pathways for youth in the digital economy, featured the YouLead Future Careers Bridge program as well as Chemonics and ACDI/VOCAâ€™s IT Women â€“ Karakalpakstan activity in Uzbekistan. In addition to best practices, the session acknowledged some of the programs' unanswered structural and systemic challenges, such as effectively encouraging rural female participation in the ICT workforce and incentivizing private sector ownership for hiring rural youth. Through the presentation, IESC and partners tapped the collective expertise of program attendees to brainstorm solutions to these and other critical questions. #GYEOSummit #YEO2030

Law and Society Trust in partnership with Young Researcher Network has conducted joint learning and research planning workshop in Jaffna recently. The purpose of the workshop was to identify possible collaborative research projects on the rural economy and agrarian issues in Sri Lanka. Debt restructuring and its impact on the rural economy, credit, indebtedness, dispossession, and social security, and women's role in agriculture value chains and in fisheries, land, and labor in the plantation economy were among some of the possible areas of research that were discussed. 

Group also visited a number of cooperative-based industries initiated and supported by the North Cooperative Development Bank as part of the economic recovery of post-conflict North.

Smashing Times International Centre for the Arts and Equality, Front Line Defenders, and partners, present the fifth annual, international Dublin Arts and Human Rights Festival from the 13 to 22 October 2023. 

Check out the full festival program here and reserve your seats early for your favourite events:
https://zurl.co/YbiU 

The festival features exciting and innovative events that promote equality, human rights and diversity through the arts, taking place in Dublin, Kerry, Donegal and Cork, with artists and speakers in attendance from Ireland, Finland, Sweden, Italy, Spain, Portugal, the Netherlands, Greece, Belgium, Cyprus, Romania, Bulgaria and Ukraine. The aim of the festival is to showcase and highlight the extraordinary work of human rights defenders in Ireland and around the world, past and present, and the role of the arts and artists in promoting human rights today.

text:
Young people are at-risk, often facing barriers to accessing sexual & reproductive health information & care.

UNFPA Sri Lanka partnered with FPA Sri Lanka and the Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to support adolescent girls in Sri Lanka on their health and wellbeing, empowering them to make informed choices to protect their health. 

Comprehensive sexuality education enables young people to protect and advocate for their health, well-being and dignity by providing them with a necessary toolkit of knowledge, attitudes and skills.

Low & Society Trust ( LST ) is looking for a professional web designing company / web designer to design and develop a new website. As an established organization, we already have a hosting domain in place and now we are looking for a skilled and responsible company / individual designer to create a high-security, user-friendly, and modern website that aligns with our brand image.

We value security as a top priority, and we require the entire website to be built with the utmost security measures in mind. 

we expect the website to have a user-friendly interface that enhances the overall user experience. Intuitive navigation, clear information architecture, and seamless functionality are crucial aspects that we would like to incorporate into the design.

We invite interested web designing company / designers to submit their quotations for this project before 18th June 2023. Along with your pricing details, please provide information on your experience, portfolio, and any additional services you offer that are relevant to our needs.

Email : communications@lstlanka.org

Mr.Hemantha Withanage, Director/ Senior advisor of the Center for Environmental Justice, said that there is a risk of submergence in many parts of the country including Jaffna, Mannar, Puttalam, Colombo and Galle between 2060 and 2100 as a result of high carbon dioxide emissions. He also explained the adverse effects of climate change on Sri Lanka, the seriousness of elephant-human conflict, and how deforestation and agricultural activities have affected today's ecology and advice.

Two participants from the IESC-implemented USDA Food for Progress-funded Trade Safe project (Proyecto Trade Safe) in the Dominican Republic (DR) attended a study tour in Nicaragua for the inaugural Latin American Regional Institute for Agricultural Protection and Health conference and outbreak simulation on Fusarium Wilt. FocR4T is the fungus responsible for the Fusarium wilt of bananas and plantains (Musaceae). An outbreak of this new Fusarium race is considered a serious threat to the region, as it would drastically impact food security and banana and plantain production. IESCâ€™s TraSa team joined the DR delegation at the conference, which participants from 12 countries attended. The study tour included information sessions, field simulations, and mobile laboratory visits. OIRSA, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), Centro de InvestigaciÃ³n PrÃ­ncipe Felipe - CIPF, IICA Nicaragua, and other international organizations coordinated the conference.

30 August marks the International Day of the Disappeared/ the UN International Day of the Victims of Enforced Disappearances. 

Governments around the world use enforced disappearances to silence human rights defenders, placing them in detention or other horrific conditions with no information of their whereabouts. 

We denounce the impunity that characterises these cases, calling for accountability for those involved in this grave human rights violation and for support for those human rights defenders working to find the disappeared and bring the perpetrators to justice. 

#InternationalDayofTheDisappeared #EnforcedDisappearances

Sri Lanka Women Lawyers' Association (SLWLA), in partnership with the Support to Justice Sector Project (#JURE), funded by the European Union in Sri Lanka and the Maldives, jointly implemented by the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP #lka  and UNICEF Sri Lanka, and facilitated by the Ministry of Justice - Sri Lanka, successfully concluded a series of workshops that focussed on developing a new strategic plan for SLWLA, for the next five years. 

The workshops covered the North, Central, and Southern parts of the country, and were attended by the executive members, key office bearers, past presidents and the regional representatives of SLWLA. The series of workshops aimed to build and strengthen the capacity of women lawyers in Sri Lanka, ensuring that they are well-prepared to reach out and make a difference; especially in the lives of vulnerable women and girls in need of legal aid and #AccessToJustice.

On 20 August Atekeh Rajabi learned of a summons to court scheduled to take place the following day. The woman human rights defender and her lawyer were denied full access to the content of the indictment issued against her. She was subsequently sentenced to 6 months in prison. She has faced judicial harassment and targeting before, being arrested and charged for her protest against the series of deliberate poisonings of school girls across Iran and terminated from her job as a primary school teacher because of her engagement in the Iranian September 2022 protests. 

We urge authorities to immediately and unconditionally drop all charges against Atekeh Rajabi, as we believe she has been targeted solely as a result of her legitimate human rights work.

Read more: https://zurl.co/2drq

With the Family Planning Association (FPA Sri Lanka), UNFPA Sri Lanka is conducting health education sessions for pregnant women in Nuwara Eliya on maternal danger signals. 

With Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade support, programme ensures everyone has equal access to sexual and reproductive health services & information & healthcare.

Making motherhood safer is a human rights imperative, and it is at the core of UNFPAâ€™s mandate. UNFPA works around the world with governments, health experts and civil society to train health workers, improve the availability of essential medicines and reproductive health services, strengthen health systems, and promote international maternal health standards.

"From the Margins of War: The Post War Experience of the Palankudi Community", a policy brief by CEPA's Social Cohesion thematic was launched on 08.08.2022. The policy brief outlines structural and institutional issues faced by the Palankudi community, with emphasis on the need for institutional recognition for indigenous rights and the palankudi identity. The brief supplements the on-going "memories from the margin" photographic exhibition. Access it at: https://www.cepa.lk/publications/from-the-margins-of-war-the-post-war-experience-of-the-palankudi-community/

We are hiring a full-time Research Writer!
Curious to uncover intriguing stories that are just waiting to be heard? Weâ€™re on the lookout for a go-getter who does their research and produces impactful stories! 
If this sounds like your calling, join our versatile team of creatives and see how far you can excel!
Send us your CV and portfolio to shout@pulse.lk!

Job Description
- Ideating and conceptualising content
- Producing insightful and impactful audiovisual content i.e. documentaries
- Producing comprehensive and engaging infographic content
- Producing in-depth research articles
- Engaging in fieldwork
- Coordinating with multiple in-house teams and external parties
- Fact checking
- Proofreading 

Requirements
- Academic qualifications in writing/ literature/ journalism/audiovisual media
- 2 years of experience in a similar capacity
- Outstanding portfolio of work
- Excellent command of English 
- Fluency in Sinhala and/or Tamil will be an added advantage
- Attention to detail 
- Ability to work in a fast-paced environment and be a team player

We are an equal opportunity employer.
All eligible applicants will receive equal consideration for employment. 
Females are encouraged to apply.

The 2023 Commercial Mediation Symposium dives into the world of mediation - the smart choice for resolving commercial disputes! Led by the Internation ADR Centre, powered by The Asia Foundation with support from United Nations Development Programme - UNDP & UNICEF Sri Lanka's European Union in Sri Lanka and the Maldives funded 'Support to Justice Reform (JURE)' project. 

Joining the #CommercialMediationSymposium2023 yesterday was H.E Ranil Wickremesinghe President of #SriLanka & Hon. Minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe, Minister of Justice Ministry of Justice - Sri Lanka, along with other notable attendees in the legal landscape, exploring the critical role of mediation towards #SriLanka's growth and recovery, while striving towards achieving the #SDGs. 

Speaking at the forum, Ms. Azusa Kubota, Resident Representative, UNDP Sri Lanka noted the transformative power of commercial mediation, noting the opportunities and challenges within the landscape and the pivotal role commercial mediation plays in promoting trade & attracting foreign investments.

Vindya Silva, Partnerships Director for USAID's youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, held a lunch and learn session today for IESC's home office staff in Washington, DC, on alternative career pathways for youth in the digital economy. During the session, Vindya discussed the Future Careers Bridge program, implemented in Sri Lanka by YouLead in collaboration with SLASSCOM, which assists youth without college degrees to secure jobs in the ICT sector. She discussed the importance of building soft skills, English language skills, and more technical ICT skills as critical avenues for getting youth employment-ready. Vindya also highlighted the difficulty of creating a mindset shift within the industry to employ youth without university degrees as long as they have the requisite baseline of skills for success.

CEPA signs MOU with Janashakthi Foundation and YUMA | CEPA has signed an agreement with the Janashakthi Foundation and Yuma Foundation to produce a flagship publication on inequality.  This publication which will be called the Inequality Report (TIER) Sri Lanka, will take a multifaceted approach to understanding and addressing inequality which affects a majority of people in Sri Lanka. The project intends to deepen the understanding of the subject, bringing together research, policy and dialogue. This will evolve over the next three years intending to become a key reference literature on inequality for the country. 

From left to right Ramesh Schaffter, Managing Director / Group CEO of Janashakthi Group, Karin Fernando, Acting Executive Director of CEPA and Christoph Feyen, Director of YUMA Foundation.

As we enter the vibrant and empowering month of Pride, we want to take a moment to express our unwavering support for the rights of all individuals. At Law & Society Trust, we firmly believe in equity and equality for everyone, recognizing that LGBTIQ+ rights are, indeed, human rights.

Pride Month serves as a poignant reminder of the progress we have made in the journey towards inclusivity, acceptance, and understanding. It is a time to celebrate the diverse identities and experiences within the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, and gender-nonconforming communities, as well as an opportunity to reflect on the challenges that still lie ahead.

We extend our heartfelt wishes to our LGBTIQ+ colleagues, friends, and community members. May this Pride Month be a joyous and empowering time filled with love, unity, and pride in who you are. We stand beside you as allies and advocates, committed to fostering an environment that respects and values the rights and dignity of every individual.

Let us use this month as a catalyst for meaningful conversations, education, and awareness, ensuring that the fight for equality extends far beyond the colorful festivities of Pride. Together, let us create a world where every person can live authentically, free from discrimination and prejudice.

Happy Pride Month to all...!

The SOVA Centre for Information and Analysis, a Moscow-based human rights organisation is the latest Russian human rights organisation to be shut down after a court ruling on 17 August. They have carried out important work documenting and advocating against nationalism, xenophobia and racism as well as anti-extremism legislation, religion in a secular society, and political radicalism which will now cease.

We condemn all forms of judicial harassment against human rights organisations and human rights defenders and urge the Russian government to cease their restriction of  spaces for the defense of human rights.

IESCâ€™s USAID LinkSME project in Vietnam supports small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in rebalancing financial resources and increasing their access to finance as they recover from the economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja is a Danish-Bahraini prominent human rights defender and former Front Line Defenders Protection Coordinator for the Middle East and North Africa. He has been imprisoned since 2011, when he was detained, tortured and subjected to an unfair trial on fabricated charges that led to him being sentenced to life in prison because of his human rights activities.

In protest of his continued imprisonment and denial of access to adequate medical treatment, Al-Khawaja started a water-only hunger strike on 9 August 2023. He is now at imminent danger of losing his life. 

Read more about his situation: 
https://zurl.co/sOBZ

Sri Lankaâ€™s Department of Animal Production and Health (DAPH) and IESCâ€™s USDA Food for Progress-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project are collaborating to expand the national coverage of artificial insemination (AI) services through private AI technicians. To improve private sector AI techniciansâ€™ skills, IESC supported two University of Florida (UF) trainers to deliver eight in-person refresher training programs to 282 participants, including 68 private technicians. As most of these technicians had not received any AI training in five years, they greatly benefited from the technical knowledge imparted by the trainers, which will improve AI success rates and the dairy herd in Sri Lanka. The MOD-TRADE app, a tool for booking AI services, monitoring, and follow-up, was introduced during these sessions.

''Two years after the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan on August 15, 2021, we strongly condemn ongoing and escalating gross human rights violations by the Taliban especially against women and girls and the lack of an effective response from the international community, 10 international human rights organizations stated today.

Over the past two years, the Taliban have imposed increasingly abusive policies especially against women and girls and religious and ethnic minorities that clearly violate Afghanistanâ€™s obligations under international human rights law. Policies that ban and restrict women and girls from education, work and other livelihood opportunities, free movement and access to public spaces and services have been widely condemned. In their joint report to the United Nations (UN) Human Rights Council, published in June 2023, the UN Special Rapporteur on the human rights situation in Afghanistan and the UN Working Group on Discrimination Against Women and Girls stated that the Taliban treatment of women and girls â€œmay amount to gender persecution â€“ a crime against humanity â€“ and be characterised as gender apartheidâ€. 

Read full statement here:

https://zurl.co/Zf5V

Law and Society Trust (LST) collaborating with FORUM ASIA conducted a two-day capacity-building workshop on Strengthening Workers' Rights in Free Trade Zones in Sri Lanka during COVID-19 and Economic Crisis. The workshop was mainly targeted at worker representatives, trade union leaders, and activists from civil society organizations in FTZs (Katunayaka, Wathupitiwala, and Biyagama) in Sri Lanka. The objectives of the workshop were to Enhance the knowledge of worker leaders (CSO and TU leaders) on the current legal frameworks on workersâ€™ rights, Increased understanding of worker leaders on the proposed labor law reforms and their impact on workersâ€™ rights, Identify current forms of workerâ€™s rights violations within FTZs and identify possible actions to address them.

The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program officially launched a partnership with Swiss Agricultural School Caucasus (SASC) to establish an Agricultural Training Center in the Kvemo Kartli region of Georgia. This partnership aims to create opportunities for rural farmers and dairy processors to improve their employment and productivity by giving them access to high-quality, practical skills development programs based on the principles of Swiss dual education. The training center will provide courses on animal husbandry, dairy processing, farm animal feeding, animal health, crop production and agricultural mechanization, and pasture management and forage conservation.

Abdul-Hadi Al-Khawaja is a Danish-Bahraini citizen, a recognized human rights defender and a political prisoner who has been unjustly sentenced to life imprisonment, serving this sentence in Bahrain since 2011. He has been subjected to brutal arrest, physical, psychological and sexual torture and suffered severe medical neglect in prison.

On Wednesday, August 9, Al-Khawaja began a water only hunger strike in protest of his continued imprisonment and after facing serious and consistent denial of access to adequate medical treatment. His family has reported that Friday, August 11, he was rushed to the intensive care unit of a Bahraini hospital due to urgent heart problems. Al-Khawaja's family states that the attending doctor declared that Al-Khawaja's life was in danger. 

Al-Khawaja was given an intravenous injection, which stabilized his heart rhythm after two hours. He was then returned to his cell. The next few days may be fatal. We strongly urge his release to Denmark from Bahrain, as well as meaningful dialogue between Denmark and Bahrain in order to save Al-Khawaja's fatherâ€™s life and get him released to Denmark.

What can you do?
1) Share this message with your network
2) Follow #FreeAlKhawaja on social media
3) Consider contacting your local politician, government official or the Danish Ministry of
Foreign Affairs to press the case.

September 15 Global Day of Action to End Fossil Fuels: Asia
=======================================

Earlier this year, international and regional networks working for a rapid, equitable and just transition out of fossil fuels decided to escalate globally coordinated campaigning efforts in view of; very weak outcomes of COP27 on the fossil fuel phase-outs, backtracking by the G7 and other wealthy countries from their earlier pledge to  phase out public financing of fossil fuels, continued low ambition and loopholes in the decarbonization policy of public and private financing institutions, the continuing  increase in fossil fuel production globally and the aggressive push for the expansion of the gas industry justifying gas as transition fuel and using the global energy crisis as an excuse, and increase in efforts of governments and corporations to promote false solutions in the form of abatement technologies that will serve to the extend of life of fossil fuel projects.

Today we organized a protest at Galle Fort to stand with Asian Peoples' Movement on Debt and Development and demand maximization of the key moments of the United Nations General Assembly and United Nations Secretary General Climate Ambition Summit to demonstrate the escalating global fight to end fossil fuels in Asia, to demonstrate to governments corporations and institutions, media and general public that the fight against fossil fuels has broadened and heightened in the Asia region, to assert, popularize and amplify our calls and demands to complement the push for a more aggressive anti-fossil gas narrative. 

End Fossil Fuels Now! Fast, Fair and Forever!

#EndFossilFuels #FastFairForever #dontgasasia

IESC through the USAID youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, recently reached a milestone in its entrepreneurship development program, as more than 4,000 women have formalized their businesses following completion of the program.

Priyanthi Konthasena attended one of the five-day entrepreneurship development programs and has since registered her tailoring business, hiring five women from her community as employees. She commented that the program allowed her to understand how to develop a business plan and manage her company more effectively. 

In partnership with the Department of Samurdhi Development, Sri Lankaâ€™s poverty alleviation agency, the entrepreneurship development program provides the fundamentals of starting and running a business to rural communities where most people are engaged in micro-scale agriculture or daily wage work.
Blessed Easter.

Youâ€™re looking at a Christmas tree made with thousands of upcycled plastic bottles! 

This is an annual tradition brought to life by a group of Sri Lankan youths who fight for marine life conservation around Sri Lanka; The Pearl Protectors. 

Using PET bottles the group collected over the year at their beach clean-ups, they managed to build a  tree thatâ€™s over 12 feet tall â€“ including its various ornaments. 

More importantly, what are the Pearl Protectors trying to tell us?
No matter the season, we're in a climate emergency, and festive seasons are when our plastic footprints go through the roof. The PET bottle Christmas tree reminds us of the impact of single-use plastic and inspires hope for a more sustainable 2024.

Initiative Partners:
ZeroTrash
HOPE Childrenâ€™s Resource Centre 
Interact Club of Ananda College
Visakha Vidyalaya

text: On April 8, IESCâ€™s USAID LinkSME project in Vietnam and the Department of Commerce of Thai Nguyen Province organized a workshop for 160 representatives of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) on financial management and business-to-business sales strategy. The workshop also provided an overview of Vietnamâ€™s economic forecast for the remainder of 2023 and solutions for SMEs to manage economic difficulties. Participants expressed interest in learning about sound financial management and connecting with lead firms. The workshop is part of USAID LinkSMEâ€™s support to SMEs in rebalancing financial resources and increasing their access to finance as they recover from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Last month as part of its International Womenâ€™s Day celebration, IESCâ€™s USDA Food for Progress-funded Trade Safe project (Proyecto Trade Safe) in the Dominican Republic and the Ministry of Agricultureâ€™s Department of Plant Health recognized 23 women professionals working in the phytosanitary sector. During the award ceremony, the honorees were recognized for their outstanding contributions to the sector related to plant quarantine inspections, pesticides, field inspection, and academic and laboratory work, among others.

â€œThe women we are recognizing represent the forefront of defense against various phytosanitary threats to the Dominican Republic. The country has suffered quite recently from the entry of pests and exotic diseases such as the Mediterranean fly and African swine fever. With the increase of tourism and the efforts to convert the Dominican Republic into a regional logistics hub, threats have increased significantly. The US Ambassador to Sri Lanka recently visited the countryâ€™s largest dairy farm, Ambewela Farms. The visit was facilitated by the USDA Food for Progress-funded Market Oriented Dairy (MOD) project implemented by IESC. During the visit, Ambewelaâ€™s leadership team provided a walkthrough of their facilities and an overview of the dairy farmâ€™s work to date with the MOD Project. Thanks to IESC and its partners from the University of Florida, Ambewelaâ€™s staff have received training on artificial insemination and technical guidance on food rationing, hoof care, and farm management practices. Senior staff even participated in a business exchange where they shared best practices and ideas with large dairy farms in Florida and Georgia. With better practices in place, their cows have better comfort, nutrition, and care, leading to higher milk productivity.

The Small and Medium Enterprise Development Fund (SMEDF) of Vietnamâ€™s Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) provides loans with concessionary terms to SMEs. It has struggled to reach its target audience, however, mainly due to a lack of skills in assessing SMEsâ€™ loan eligibility and potential lending risks. On March 16-17, IESCâ€™s USAID LinkSME project trained 18 SMEDF credit officers on credit appraisal and risk control for Vietnamese SMEs. Enhancing the credit appraisal skills of SMEDF credit officers will help improve SME access to finance, bridging the gap between SMEsâ€™ capital needs and capital on offer from mainstream banks and financial institutions.

Front Line Defenders was devastated to learn about the passing of the woman human rights defender and writer Viktoria Amelina as a result of the injures she incurred in a Russian missile strike in the city of Kramatorsk, Ukraine, where she and her colleagues carried out their peaceful and non-violent human rights work. The organisation got to know Viktoria Amelina when she visited Front Line Defendersâ€™ and Smashing Times' Dublin Arts and Human Rights Festival in October 2022, where she discussed her project â€œWar and Justice Diary: Looking at Women Looking at Warâ€ and had a drawing workshop for Ukrainian children refugees. Front Line Defenders expresses sincere condolences to Viktoria Amelinaâ€™s family and loved ones.

Last week, IESC staff from the Farmer-to-Farmer (F2F) Tanzania program joined USAID Tanzania to meet with the Minister of Agriculture in Dodoma, Tanzania, to discuss shared priorities. Together with the Ministry of Agricultureâ€™s access to finance technical staff, IESC and USAID Tanzania shared details about F2Fâ€™s focus on alleviating barriers to accessing finance, particularly for rural farmers, women, youth, and other marginalized populations. They discussed how F2F and the USAID Missionâ€™s activities could help advance the Ministry of Agricultureâ€™s goals by enhancing rural access to finance throughout the country.

Olivier is a Congolese environmental rights defender and lawyer from North Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo. He has dedicated his lifeâ€™s work to advocating for environmental rights, land rights and land justice; pushing for transparent, accountable, and sustainable governance of land tenure regimes for the countryâ€™s lands. In 2008, he co-founded the NGO â€˜â€™Alerte Congolaise pour lâ€™Environnement et les Droits de lâ€™Hommeâ€™â€™ , through which he has actively supported and represented local communities, groups and individuals working on the environment for over 15 years.

Olivier has been persecuted and faced grave danger due to his human rights work, targeted by recurring death threats and an attempted assasination, which caused him to flee his home country and go into exile for his own protection. He has been severely beaten and tortured by security forces; once to the point of needing hospitalisation for 12 days. His organisation has also faced attempts of sabotage such as robbery and break-ins. Despite these harrowing circumstances, he is hopeful and inspired to continue securing justice for the victims of land and environmental injustices in the DRC, especially at-risk and vulnerable groups like women and children.
Olivier is known as the â€˜â€™Green Lawyerâ€™â€™ in North Kivu because of his defence of Virunga Park and its workers and people. The communities he has represented face economic expropriation and exploitation of their land and resources. In the context of the DRC, this has affected women and children most â€“ many women have lost their husbands in the conflict and are left vulnerable. They are then driven off their land, which has plunged them into grave insecurity. Olivier has ensured that they, and other vulnerable victims, are not forgotten.

On March 6, The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program officially launched a partnership with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) to advance Georgiaâ€™s EU Association agenda and support Government of Georgia reforms in the healthcare sector. The reforms aim to harmonize the nursing profession with the regulations and the countryâ€™s newly adopted Nursing Development Strategy.

Through this partnership, USAID and EBRD are joining forces to establish a Public-Private Dialogue platform to develop workable strategies for nursing professionals with a specific focus on advancing their skills, competencies, and career opportunities. This will streamline the adoption of Georgiaâ€™s upcoming regulatory framework on nursing.

The MOU signing event gathered, from left to right, USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program Chief of Party David Blood, USAID Mission Director John A. Pennell, Minister of Internally Displaced Persons from the Occupied Territories, Labor, Health, and Social Affairs Zurab Azarashvili, EBRD Regional Head for the Caucasus Catarina Bjorlin Hansen, and Deputy Minister Tamar Gabunia.

Last month, members of IESCâ€™s USDA Food for Progress-funded Agricultural Trade and Climate Smart Innovations (ATraCSI) team visited the Chamber of Commerce and Industries of Choloma (CCICH) and the Chamber of Commerce and Industries in Puerto Cortes (CCIPC) in Honduras. ATraCSI Chief of Party Ray Waldron, Guatemala Deputy Chief of Party Isabel Gonzalez, and El Salvador Deputy Chief of Party Napoleon Castillo met with Alejandra MejÃ­a from CCICH and Yolibeth del Cid from CCIPC. During the meeting, the ATraCSI team discussed the five-year project and potential areas of collaboration. Together they examined the production, processing, and marketing of horticultural products in Central America. These collaborative efforts will strengthen IESCâ€™s approach to increasing the trade of horticultural goods and cultivating productive value chains in El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras.

In Sri Lanka, the USDA Food for Progress-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) Project, implemented by IESC, has developed a unique climate-smart dairy model to enable small- and medium-scale dairy farmers to both mitigate climate impacts and adapt to the changing climate. In our initial tests with 27 dairy farmers, the tool has helped farmers to increase productivity and reduce their emissions rate while identifying key areas for on-farm improvements and informing future training efforts. This initiative has the potential to help achieve emissions reduction targets while improving farmer incomes and increasing national milk supplies. You can read more about the climate-smart dairy model in this article, which was recently published on Agrilinks: https://agrilinks.org/post/practical-tool-drive-climate-smart-dairy-production-sri-lanka

text: Following the delivery of in-depth surveys and strategy reports to 50 small and medium enterprises (SMEs), IESCâ€™s USAID LinkSME project and the Agency for Enterprise Development (AED) in Vietnam finalized a list of 25 SMEs that will receive further support in developing digital transformation (DX) roadmaps. Over the last month, the project and AED met with and presented initial roadmaps to four of the SMEs on the shortlist located in central and southern parts of Vietnam. The roadmaps provided each SME with a master plan for their DX implementation over the next three years, along with detailed steps, timelines, and tentative DX solutions.

Nelson Mandela has been described as the ultimate public servant.

â€œWhat counts in life is not the mere fact that we have lived. It is what difference we have made to the lives of others that will determine the significance of the life we lead.â€ 
Nelson Mandela

Today is more than a celebration of Nelson Mandelaâ€™s life and legacy. 

CPA Sri Lanka is proud to join the global movement to honour his lifeâ€™s work and act to change the world for the better.

MAKE EVERY DAY A MANDELA DAY

The message behind Mandela Day is simple â€“ each individual has the ability and the responsibility to change the world for the better.

If each one of us heeded the call to simply do good every day, we would be living Nelson Mandelaâ€™s legacy and helping to build a country of our dreams.

The baton of leadership has been handed over to us. It is in our hands now to make a positive difference.

IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Trade Safe project (Proyecto Trade Safe) in the Dominican Republic conducted a workshop together with MERCADOM (mercadom_rd) to present the results of their safety audit carried out at 35 locations selling meat and dairy products, as well as cafeterias and places where prepared food is sold. In honor of International Womenâ€™s Day this month, the USDA Food for Progress-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project in Sri Lanka, implemented by IESC, celebrates the women entrepreneurs who have expanded their businesses and discovered new revenue streams after attending MOD training sessions and applying MOD best practices. Through MODâ€™s efforts to advance women's economic empowerment in Sri Lankaâ€™s dairy value chain, IESC has delivered technical training or entrepreneurial guidance to nearly 1,600 women dairy farmers and over 40 women input retailers. For instance, Ms. Pavithra, an input retailer, expanded her product range and multiplied her monthly sales volume by fifteen. USAID LinkSME, implemented by IESC, and the Agency for Enterprise Development (AED) finalized the 2022 Annual Report on Enterprise Digital Transformation (DX), which explores the readiness of Vietnamese enterprises to apply DX solutions. The report highlights key trends in DX readiness, summarizes milestones achieved in the Ministry of Planning and Investmentâ€™s (MPI) DX program, and features inspiring success stories from enterprises that have applied DX solutions. The report was formally announced in a February 16 workshop organized by USAID LinkSME and AED. It highlighted the availability and potential usefulness of information on DX for Vietnamese small and medium enterprises (SMEs) through the MPI.

Government and NGO-led service entry points are available for GBV victims. These can be accessed either through referrals or in-person. 

In contrast to GBV victims, current practices make accessing services difficult for human trafficking victims.

Digital Security Lab Ukraine (DSLU) was established in 2017 to address digital security concerns of human rights defenders and organisations in Ukraine. Civil society voices have always been strong in Ukraine, reaching a peak in 2013 with the EuroMaidan clashes, aimed at overthrowing a pro-Russian government. Russiaâ€™s war in Ukraine, that started with occupation of Crimea in 2014 and destabilisation and shadow support to the so-called separatist movement in Donetsk and Luhansk regions in eastern Ukraine, has posed a grave danger to human rights defenders in the occupied territories.

When Russia launched its full-scale invasion in Ukraine on 24 February 2022, human rights defenders and groups experienced blackouts and disruptions in communications due to Russiaâ€™s shelling of Ukraineâ€™s critical infrastructure. There have been significant fluctuations in internet connectivity in many regions of Ukraine, impeding the ability to document and report on war crimes and human rights violations. DSLUâ€™s work has been integral to rebuilding digital security infrastructure and documentation of war crimes, ensuring that organisations could continue to operate by providing and setting up satellite internet kits for teams working on documenting and reporting war crimes.
Despite the circumstances of the war, while many fled to safety, DSLU stayed on the ground, recognising the crucial digital needs of the context. This was not easy and came with significant safety and security challenges. They continue to work hard to combat online censorship and provide means of communication during the invasion to ensure that crucial information can be shared and exchanged despite the barriers. Despite growing physical security risks amid the ongoing conflict, they continue to provide digital security support to HRDs and HROs in Ukraine.

Segundo OrdÃ³Ã±ez is an Afro-descendant human rights defender from Esmeraldas, Ecuador. His family migrated from Tumaco, Colombia when he was a child, due to the violence and poverty they experienced there. For most of his life in Ecuador, he lived and worked on abacÃ¡ (Manila hemp) plantations with abacaleros (Manila-hemp worker), for the Japanese company â€˜â€™Furukawa Plantaciones C. Aâ€™â€™ â€“ a company which produces and exports abacÃ¡ fibre. AbacÃ¡ is formed from the stalks of banana trees, used and exported to the US and Europe for paper money, rope, teabags, cars and more. Ecuador is the second largest exporter of abacÃ¡ fibre, yet those who farm the raw materials have done so under slavery-like conditions.

Abacaleros, including Segundo, united after years of discrimination, and took the company and the State of Ecuador to court, accusing them of plunging at least three generations of impoverished rural workers into conditions of modern slavery. With the support of the civil society solidarity committee â€œFurukawa Nunca MÃ¡sâ€, constitutional and criminal proceedings were instituted against the company but so far they have not achieved justice or any type of reparation for the abacaleros. When the case became public in 2019, the company retaliated and demolished some of the camps where abacaleros and their families lived, and evicted hundreds of other families from the camps. Segundo, along with a group of abacaleros, resisted the evictions by remaining in two of the camps owned by the company â€“ an occupation which continues four years on.
Inspired by his bravery and ability to maintain community cohesion, Segundo became the representative of his community in legal proceedings, playing a key role in confronting the company in court and in public, which has also come at a risk to his life.
As a result of his resistance, he has been targeted in a number of ways ranging from consistent harassment, â€˜â€™SLAPPâ€™â€™ and other lawsuits filed by the company to intimidate and discredit him, and more recently, death threats.

Jeany Rose Hayahay is an indigenous woman human rights defender based in Mindanao, Philippines. She advocates for indigenous peoplesâ€™ rights, focusing on childrenâ€™s right to education. Rose played a significant role in uniting indigenous and community-based schools in Mindanao and coordinated with national groups on a campaign to stop militarisation, environmental plunder and land grabbing of ancestral lands. She has faced violence from different authorities many times during peaceful protests, yet she has persisted in her cause with courage, leadership, and dedication. She became the spokesperson of the Save Our Schools Network (SOS Network) in 2019, a network of child-focused NGOs, church-based groups and other stakeholders who bring attention to, and take action regarding the ongoing violation of childrenâ€™s right to education, particularly in the context of militarisation and attacks on schools.

Roseâ€™s journey began as a volunteer teacher for the Lumad communities in Mindanao, during which time she raised awareness on the human rights violations the Lumads were facing. Beyond basic education, Rose also taught practical skills such as agriculture that would help students enrich their environment, culture, and defend their ancestral lands. Rose helped build a communal farm in several schools for students to have hands-on experience with agriculture.
Rose was a part of the â€˜â€™Lumad Bakwit schoolâ€ from 2018 until 2021, where hundred of indigenous students from southern Philippines gather in main cities to protest against human rights violations of indigenous and minority groups. As the spokesperson of SOS Network, she is at the forefront of many public gatherings, protests and meetings, and is consistently red-tagged and monitored as a leader, facing reprisals and threats, both directly and indirectly. She is at high risk of being killed, arrested or imprisoned yet continues to lead at the forefront with determination and courage.

Hala Ahed is a Jordanian woman human rights defender and lawyer. Born in December 1971 in Kuwait, Hala moved to Amman, Jordan when she was 10 years old, and has lived there since. Hala has conducted significant work in the human rights landscape in Jordan, and is well recognised in civil society as a trusted leader and ally. The focus of her work has been womenâ€™s rights, but within the political context of Jordan, she has also worked across freedom of opinion and expression, labour rights, and trade union freedoms.

Despite her vital work and advocacy, Hala has endured various forms of intimidation and harassment, including being summoned multiple times by the Jordanian General Intelligence Directorate (GID). She has recieved threats from authorities who have gone as far as threatening her son in order to get to her. Hala grew her public legitimacy by increasing her visibility and public profile, and building a support network which has given her public credibility.
Most recently, Hala was a victim of NSOâ€™s Pegasus digital hacking spyware initiated by the government. It was found that she was being surveilled when her mobile device was infected with Pegasus in March 2021. In other instances, Hala was targeted with online defamation campaigns where government-backed social media accounts would storm her account with harassment. Over the years as a lawyer, Hala represented and defended human rights defenders, activists, rights movements, civil society organisations and trade unions, making herself known as a strong ally for civil society in Jordan. She supported multiple unions with voluntary legal representation, including the Jordan Teachersâ€™ Syndicate which represents more than 14,000 teachers; and the Agricultural Association. Her human rights work goes beyond the realms of her desk and books. Despite all the obstacles, dangers and restrictions she faces for her human rights work, Hala continues to be dedicated in her pursuit of improving the human rights situation in Jordan for all.

Front Line Defenders is excited to announce a fellowship opportunity in our Communications & Events team - for recent graduates interested in developing a career in communications/events within the international human rights field. 

The Communications and Events Fellow will be based in Front Line Defendersâ€™ office in Blackrock for 30 hours per week, and will:

-Provide support to the Visibility and Communications Officer, including but not limited to: administrative and substantive tasks around the creation, design, dissemination and monitoring of social media content and multimedia materials (e.g. videos and podcasts).
 -Assist with capturing and recording multimedia content at FLD events.
 -Provide support to the International Events and Promotions Coordinator, including with the creation and upkeep of guest and supplier lists, tracking visa applications and flights, and drafting of materials for events.
- Upload approved content (Urgent Appeals, Statements, human rights defender profiles, etc.) to the Front Line Defenders website.
- Assist in archiving images related to Front Line Defendersâ€™ field work to protect human rights defenders.
- Assist in drafting and designing, as requested, media materials or content to support Front Line Defenders events.
-Carry out administrative duties as required.

Take a look at the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP's #SDGinsights which is a collaboration with 95 developing countries ahead of the upcoming United Nations Sustainable Development Summit.

The reports highlight the importance for developing countries to invest in enabling #environments for digital and green transitions.

This requires:
â€¢ Institutional effectiveness

In 2022, human rights defenders (HRDs) in the Americas continued to transform their societies and communities. Their long-standing role in defending land and territories, access to justice and building peace was fundamental to sustain creative responses to persisting challenges in the region. 

Despite the adverse context, women human rights defenders (WHRDs) and LGBTIQ+ groups continued to flourish and creatively build new leaderships. Although the region saw positive political changes as a result of important elections, the political will to protect HRDs continued to be largely absent. The criminalisation of defenders, including WHRDs, journalists and anti-corruption defenders was unrelenting during the year.

In addition to the threat of criminalisation, those defending indigenous peoplesâ€™, Afro-descendant communitiesâ€™, land and environmental rights were exposed to persistent and alarming levels of violence by both state and non-state actors, including widespread killings. In the midst of a prevailing rhetoric of â€œgender ideologyâ€ that has become normalised in the region in recent years, the risks to LGBTIQ+ defenders and WHRDs remained particularly acute. 

Read more regional analysis on the #Americas in our #GlobalAnalysis22 from page 34: https://zurl.co/sPxc

Human-elephant conflict is very widespread in Sri Lanka. It is currently reported from over half the country and almost the entire dry zone. On the direction of His Excellency the President, the Presidential Committee to Prepare a National Action Plan for Human Elephant Conflict Mitigation was appointed by the Secretary to the President on the 22nd of July 2020. This Action Plan proposes activities providing results in the short, medium and long term.
Committee members
Dr. Prithiviraj Fernando, Chairman, Centre for Conservation and Research Secretary
Mr. Vernon Perera, Additional Secretary, Ministry of Environment & Wildlife Members
Dr. Sumith Pilapitiya, Former Director General, Dept. of Wildlife Conservation
Dr. U. K. G. K. Padmalal, Senior Lecturer, Open University of Sri Lanka
Dr. S. Wijeyamohan, Senior Lecturer, Vavuniya Campus, University of Jaffna

IESCâ€™s Farmer-to-Farmer Access to Finance program celebrates International Womenâ€™s Day by promoting financial inclusion and ensuring that women in Tanzania have access to financial services. Working with Equity Bank Tanzania LTD, F2F volunteer experts have targeted the gender gap in accessing formal financial services â€“ a significant barrier to achieving gender equity. F2F and Equity Bank trained 251 women from 12 village saving and loan associations (VSLAs) in Morogoro and Mvomero districts to build their budgeting, saving, and financial planning skills so that the women farmers can achieve their business goals. Equity Bank, in turn, developed a specific financial product called the Mwanamke Fanikisha loan product specifically geared towards women lacking material assets that would allow them to access finance in the traditional marketplace. Because of this intervention, more women farmers in Tanzania have access to bank accounts and financial services, enabling them to grow their agribusinesses. #IWD2023 #EmbraceEquity

The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program's new grant partnership with Business and Technology University Georgia (BTU â€¢ áƒ‘áƒ˜áƒ–áƒœáƒ”áƒ¡áƒ˜áƒ¡áƒ áƒ“áƒ áƒ¢áƒ”áƒ¥áƒœáƒáƒšáƒáƒ’áƒ˜áƒ”áƒ‘áƒ˜áƒ¡ áƒ£áƒœáƒ˜áƒ•áƒ”áƒ áƒ¡áƒ˜áƒ¢áƒ”áƒ¢áƒ˜) Georgia will train 1,500 women across rural regions of Georgia in software development, user experience design, graphic design, and digital marketing. Fraudulent or misleading claims using the United Nations name and emblem are circulating on social media, websites, e-mails, phone calls and messaging services.

Recipients of such messages are advised to exercise extreme caution, and to not respond to requests for the transfer of funds or for the provision of private information. Anyone with doubts about the authenticity of a message purportedly from, for, or on behalf of the United Nations Sri Lanka or its officials, is encouraged to send an e-mail to rcs-unsrilanka@un.org  or to our global fraud alert network at www.un.org/en/aboutun/fraudalert/

Withdraw the proposed Anti-Terrorism Bill
The incumbent government is working to bring a new Act to replace the existing Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). Taken as a whole, it is clear that this draft bill goes against the basic rights of the people, Sri Lankaâ€™s international human rights obligations, and democracy. Therefore, civil society activists have come together to sign a public petition urging the government to withdraw this bill immediately. Express your opposition to the proposed bill by signing the petition at the link below.

Our #GlobalAnalysis22 showed that human rights defenders (HRDs) in Asia faced unprecedented challenges in 2022 as they pushed back against regressive states, including legal persecution combined with misuse and abuse of anti-terrorism frameworks and growing restrictions on the rights to privacy and freedoms of expression, assembly and movement. 

Over the years, state authorities across the region have regularly targeted and vilified HRDs with impunity, branding them as terrorists and exposing them to harm through legal and extra legal means. During the year, women human rights defenders (WHRDs), especially those with intersecting identities that are traditionally persecuted, were particularly affected. 

While indigenous peoplesâ€™ rights defenders and those protecting land and environmental rights against corporate and state interests faced heightened risks. Meanwhile, governments extended their extra-territorial reach to target defenders in exile and pursued increasingly sophisticated forms of digital surveillance of defenders and repression of freedom of expression online.

Despite this hostile context, HRDs persisted in challenging governmentsâ€™ anti-rights
agendas and policies that harm and undermine citizens, while consistently speaking out
alongside the most marginalised communities. Defenders steadfastly countered negative
misinformation campaigns, exposing the increasingly unconvincing narratives depicting
HRDs and their communities as serious security threats. 

Read more regional analysis on Asia for 2022 from page 46:
https://zurl.co/PCkP

Our #GlobalAnalysis22 showed that HRDs in #Africa faced criminilisation and attacks for pushing for civic freedoms in the face of human rights violations, corruption and authoritarian governments.  

In several countries, counter-terrorism imperatives were used to justify the restriction of civil society operations and the brutal repression of protests, with security forces using excessive and in some cases lethal force.

Land, indigenous peoplesâ€™ and environmental rights defenders consolidated their networks, enhancing collective strategies of resistance, while denouncing companies responsible for human rights and environmental abuses. 

Authoritiesâ€™ intolerance for those defending economic, social and cultural rights persisted as did impunity for attacks against them. Women, feminists and LGBTIQ+ defenders faced threats, violence and discrimination and dangerous while regressive legislation to criminalise LGBTIQ+ communities was pursued by several governments during the year.

HRDs working in contexts of conflict and crisis faced extreme risks and danger when conducting their human rights work. 

Read more regional analysis on #Africa from page 22 in our #GlobalAnalysis22:

https://zurl.co/Sqht

Prof A D V de S Indraratne honoured by the Organisation of Professional Associations of Sri Lanka (OPA)

We are very proud to announce that Prof Indraratne, member of our Advisory Council, has been awarded a National Apex Award for his outstanding contribution to the country in the field of economics at the 26th annual conference and National Apex Awards held by the Organisation of Professional Associations of Sri Lanka on September 24 and 25 in Colombo.

Prof Indraratne (pictured right) received his award from Mr. Maithri Sirisena, Minister of Health (pictured left).

The inaugural apex award ceremony highlights the talents and achievements of members of the affiliated professional associations in Sri Lanka and this year's annual conference focussed on the theme Human Capital Towards 2020.

text: IESCâ€™s USAID LinkSME project in Vietnam is supporting the Administrative Procedure Control Agency (APCA), the Office of the Government (OOG), and the Management Information System (MIS) center to conduct field trips to three regions in Vietnam. They will survey the readiness of local information systems and the ability of localities to connect and provide data on proposed socio-economic indicators. Comments and feedback from these field trips will help the experts at the MIS center and APCA formulate the socio-economic indicator framework, in turn helping Government of Vietnam leaders make better decisions based on accurate and timely information concerning socio-economic issues, especially those related to the business environment.

Uththara was 14 when she was kidnapped by someone she knew from her hometown in Rathnapura. For almost two years, she was held captive somewhere in Colombo. While being abused by her captor, she was exposed to Colomboâ€™s trafficking, drugs, casinos and nightlife culture. 

After she was let go, she went back home to her mother in Ratnapura, but quickly got tired of the village life. So, she came back to Colombo, using the last bit of her money. To earn money, she danced at different clubs in Colombo. That is when she met her boyfriend. 

For her, unprotected sex and abortions became a norm. But when she got pregnant because of her boyfriend, Uththara decided to keep the baby. But because of their differences, her relationship ended. Then she brought her mother to Colombo, who stuck by her through all her trials and tribulations. 

Now Uththara is a mother herself, navigating the world as she continues her trade as a sex worker, to give a better life for her daughter.

text: On February 15, 2023, The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program in Georgia and partner PMCG (Policy and Management Consulting Group - PMCG) hosted the 4th Business Leadersâ€™ Council meeting. Leading Georgian business decision-makers and stakeholders met to discuss Georgiaâ€™s Development Strategyâ€“2030, which emphasizes priority and high-growth economic sectors such as ICT, logistics, transport, and tourism. They also discussed the labor market, unemployment in Georgia, and the role of business in economic development. The group raised several important issues requiring special attention, such as employee working hours in specific sectors, the need to promote medical tourism, ICT sector development, and the need to train IT specialists to address worldwide tech industry trends.

Today, on the 12th anniversary of his detention,  we reiterate the call to free imprisoned HRD #Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja and drop all charges against him, including his life sentence. 

Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja is an internationally respected human rights defender who won the Martin Ennals Award for Human Rights Defenders in 2022, elected by a jury of ten of the worldâ€™s leading human rights NGOs. He has a long history of working to promote human rights in the MENA region and championing the protection of human rights defenders at risk, including working as the MENA Protection Coordinator for Front Line Defenders, serving as President of the Bahrain Centre for Human Rights (BCHR) and Founding Director of the Gulf Centre for Human Rights (GCHR).

He was arrested on 9 April 2011; and was detained, tortured and subjected to an unfair trial on fabricated charges, that led to him being sentenced to life in prison because of his human rights work. That sentence was deemed arbitrary by the UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention as far back as 2012.

Throughout his detention, Mr Al-Khawaja has endured various forms of reprisals, including physical and mental torture. 

We will not rest in calling for his freedom. 

#Bahrain must #FreeAlkhawaja now.

Share the call.

Kamal Shrimp Farm in Wilathawa, Chilaw is a leading shrimp exporter with a farm that sprawls over 2 acres. The process of raising larvae into shrimp takes roughly 4 to 5 months but is an effort that has a high energy requirement. The shrimp ponds need to be aerated for at least 22 hours a day, which costs the farm over a million rupees each month. UNDP's intervention has provided Kamal Shrimp Farm with the capital to invest in solar aerators. This not only allows the farm to save on costs and increase its profits but also sets the groundwork for transitioning the entire industry towards renewable energy. 

To learn more about this #SouthSouthCooperation intervention  click on the link below and read the full article. 
https://undpsrilanka.exposure.co/paddling-towards-a-sustainable-future

On Tuesday, February 14, 2023, members of IESCâ€™s USDA Food for Progress-funded Agricultural Trade and Climate Smart Innovations (ATraCSI) team visited Puerto Cortes, the largest port and industrial center in Honduras. ATraCSI Chief of Party Ray Waldron, Guatemala Deputy Chief of Party Isabel Gonzalez, and El Salvador Deputy Chief of Party Napoleon Castillo met with Dr. Orlin Ramirez of the National Food Safety and Quality Service (SENASA). Together they analyzed export and import issues, visited cold chain facilities, and discussed sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS) inspection measures and customs coordination. These efforts will support IESC in improving food safety, customs coordination, and overall trade facilitation in El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras.

WIF organized a series of COVID 19 relief support programmes for our women entrepreneurs. First being the psychological support sessions to provide help to those in need better face and manage the pandemic and resulting conditions. Then we organized a series of Leadership training sessions to better equip women entrepreneurs face the changing environment. These sessions presented a leadership model which the entrepreneurs can easily relate to and practice in their day to day life. 

Our third programme planned under the COVID 19 relief is a technical support and follow up programme where we will equip the women entrepreneurs with important knowledge and skill areas vital to survive in a crisis situation. Areas such as financial literacy, digital finance, taxation, law will be discussed in the programme. Also the programme will have a rigorous follow up support to ensure that you successfully connect with the entrepreneurial eco system. This programme will commence by early July and interested and committed women entrepreneurs are requested to connect with us to enroll with the programme. 

Thanks to our generous support organisations, donors and volunteers, all these sessions are conducted free of charge to help women entrepreneurs succeed and grow. 
These programme are currently limited to Sri Lankan Women Entrepreneurs. 

#womenentrepreneurs #covid19support #wif #support #survive #relief #Srilankacan

In 2022, the 3 most targeted sectors for HRDs were land, environmental and indigenous rights, freedom of assembly and freedom of expression.

ğŸ”´ Pervasive levels of impunity combined with limited access to justice enabled ongoing criminalisation, combined with other forms of violent attack, to be used to silence and derail the crucial work of indigenous peoplesâ€™, land, territory and environmental rights defenders. These defenders faced persistent and violent attacks as authorities, companies, landowners and farmers sought to further advance their commercial interests through the violent expropriation of land and ancestral territories. 

In the face of expanding extractive, agro-industrial and tourism projects, defenders and their communities were subjected to armed attacks, forced evictions and displacement, destruction of property, stigmatisation, surveillance, criminalisation, enforced disappearances and killings. 

ğŸ”´ Journalists and HRDs working on freedom of expression by documenting, collecting evidence of and exposing corruption and human rights violations during protests and in other contexts of serious repression were criminalised and targeted with office raids, intimidation, digital attacks and
surveillance. 

ğŸ”´ Around the world new waves of social protest erupted as citizens demonstrated against rising inflation, costs of living and fuel, and poor labour conditions, while also denouncing more fundamental grievances around corrupt and abusive governance. Crackdowns using disproportionate and brutal force were widespread, making the act of peaceful protest increasingly unsafe for demonstrators and defenders. Criminalisation of HRDs who led, mobilised or documented violations occurring in the context of protests was also commonplace during the year.

Read more here: https://zurl.co/B1Tc

CEPAâ€™s recent study (https://bit.ly/3NrwFeP) investigates the majoritarian, populist rhetoric which materialised across the country in 2019. The close monitoring of the rhetoric in physical and virtual spaces show that current events have shifted the narrative, especially in relation to the notion of the â€œcommon enemyâ€ which has changed from one community against the country to the public vs the state apparatus. This was evident in the mass circumvention of and disregard for the social media ban. In order to understand where weâ€™re headed right now, it is imperative to understand the genesis. We continue to closely monitor the situation for a deeper understanding of what created this shift in the rhetoric and narrative, and the way forward in terms of implications for social cohesion. 

#SriLankaCrisis #EconomicCrisisLK #lka #SriLanka

text: With the support of IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Trade Safe project (Proyecto Trade Safe) in the Dominican Republic, a delegation of Dominican cold chain industry leaders attended a study tour in Veracruz, Mexico to observe best handling practices of perishable products. Led by IESCâ€™s implementing sub-partner, the Global Cold Chain Alliance â€“ World Food Logistics Organization (GCCA-WFLO), the observation tour included a visit to one of Mexicoâ€™s most important ports and strategic logistics connection centers. With IESC's support, study tour participants returned to the DR with knowledge of best practices and network sharing to improve their business models and resources. On January 27th, Ultramarathon runner Hyun Chang Chung became the first person to successfully run the entire 300 kilometers of The Pekoe Trail, a long-distance walking trail in Sri Lanka developed by the European Union-funded Tourism Resilience Program in collaboration with USAID and implemented by IESC, on behalf of Sri Lanka Tourism. Designed as a 22-day walk from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya, Chang averaged five kilometers an hour over the course of 59 hours to complete the trail in two and a half days. A veteran of many similar runs, such as the Hong Kong Four Trails race, Chang described The Pekoe Trail as being on par with some of the best trails in the world. Chalaka Gajabhu, Chairman of the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotions Bureau, expressed his delight that Chang had chosen to run The Pekoe Trail. He believes that his amazing feat will help attract further interest from new traveler segments, such as adventure seekers. The Pekoe Trail will be open for visitors in Summer 2023. Read more here: http://ow.ly/oPPO50MTfKK 
Serendipity Trails #ThePekoeTrail #VisitSriLanka #TravelSriLanka #SerendipityTrails

Our #GlobalAnalysis22 showed that governmentsâ€™ tactics of repression transcended digital spaces as they continued to extend their dominion over the online sphere including through a range of cybercrime legislation, collusion with social media companies, digital surveillance and internet shutdowns.

The reform or passing of new cybercrime legislation - often on the justification of counter-terrorism imperatives - further restricted one of the few remaining channels for dissent and access to information. This type of legislation enabled provisions ranging from prohibiting VPN use, permitting internet shutdowns, removal of  content critical of authorities, surveillance, censorship, interception of communications, retention of user data and penalties for tech and telecommunications companies that fail to cooperate, among other abusive provisions.

Read more here: https://zurl.co/c3fb

â–¶ï¸Killings of human rights defenders as a result of their work around the world continued to increase in 2022, totally 401, with Colombia bearing almost half of these killings. 

HRD Memorial partner Somos Defensores recording a staggering 186 killings of
defenders to date. Limited state presence in remote territories continued to leave HRDs
exposed to violence, especially members of local civic structures and social organisations.

In the absence of the state, these HRDs have taken on a very visible role in the promotion
of the 2016 Peace Accords in their territories, including the implementation of some of the
provisions of the Accords and the protection of at-risk populations, but with limited state
support and protection. In 2022 alone, 72 defenders working with Community Action
Boards (Juntas de AcciÃ³n Comunal22) were killed. 

Read more about this alarming reality here:

USAID Farmer-to-Farmer program volunteers Deonath and Harris teamed up in Tanzania to support MUCOBA, a community bank that provides loans and other financial services to rural farmers outside of Iringa. Together, Deonath and Harris supported the community bank by re-evaluating their loan monitoring and recovery strategies to decrease its non-performing loans (NPL) ratio, which is the percentage of loans given that are never repaid. With IESCâ€™s support, the volunteers trained community bank management and staff on risk management and other strategies they can employ to increase the likelihood of loans being repaid. Overall, this training supports the bank in expanding its ability to serve rural farmers in Tanzania, especially youth and women. Tanzanian volunteer Deonath (left) is pictured with an onion farmer who has benefitted from MUCOBAâ€™s financial services.

Despite being one of the fastest growing industries in Sri Lanka, the ICT field is experiencing a shortage of workers. In collaboration with SLASSCOM, USAIDâ€™s youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, implemented the Future Careers BRIDGE program, a learning platform to assist youth without college degrees to secure jobs in the ICT sector, to tackle the problem. Over 23,000 youth, including 10,000 women, have enrolled in this program. To date, more than 100 of those youth have received jobs from BRIDGE partners, while others have found work in related fields or launched their own ICT ventures. 

A recent update to BRIDGE, known as 2.0, has added nine new learning streams, including networking, visual design, cybersecurity, and customer service, to help provide enrolled youth with additional skills vital to success in the ICT industry.  With the additional offerings, IESC is helping to further Sri Lankaâ€™s digital transformation across all sectors while increasing youth employability and meeting industry needs for skilled workers.

ğŸ”Š Front Line Defenders Global Analysis 2022 on human rights defenders at risk out now:

The report details the variety of killings (data from HRD Memorial), risks, threats and attacks faced by HRDs around the world in 2022, and provides examples of HRDs continuing to defend and advance the rights of their communities and societies despite threats to their lives.  

2022 saw a significant increase in killings, threats, and criminilisation of HRDs, but despite an assault on human rights and the rule of law in many countries, human rights defenders showed remarkable courage and persistence in advocating for more democratic, just and inclusive societies in 2022.  

''Across nearly all countries, human rights organisations, networks and social movements pushed back against deepening authoritarianism and closing civic space, mobilising for change while expanding collective voices and responding to the needs of the most marginalised and targeted communities. Even in the most violent contexts, feminist, women and LGBTIQ+ defenders repeatedly stood up for their communities and against discrimination, while strengthening their networks and forming broader alliances. Nevertheless, this steadfast and courageous defence of human rights often came at significant cost to HRDs ''.

Read the full report now for in-depth analysis and data both globally and regionally:

https://zurl.co/9gu5  

#GA22 #GlobalAnalysis22

Jewelex Agri Kumaragama Pvt Ltd. is a mango orchard in Thanamalwila.  The company boasts 75 acres of mango trees and access to 300 acres of mango plantations in the country. They harvest 3000 to 4000 mangoes on average everyday. 

Once harvested, fruits need proper processing and cold storage. The lack of which results in 40% of the produce going to waste. 

The company consumes 2,500 kWh and spends close to Rs. 4 lakhs per month for electricity. A cost that directly impacts the profits they make. 

To learn how #SouthSouthCooperation has supported Jewelex Agri to become a #Sustainable and environmental friendly venture and in turn helped them increase their revenue, click on the link below and read the full article. 
https://undpsrilanka.exposure.co/fresh-green-and-sustainable

Due to the ongoing drought in Kenya, Wega Dairy Cooperative was on the brink of dissolving. With drastically reduced milk collection from its members and the inability to meet its debt obligations, the livelihoods of its 10,000 members and their families were at stake. IESCâ€™s Farmer-to-Farmer (F2F) volunteers supported the dairy cooperative in all areas - from developing a business plan and rebranding to training farmers on dairy herd reproduction. With support from IESCâ€™s F2F volunteers, Wega successfully turned business around, growing its farmer membership base by 3,000, improving milk quality, and securing a better price for its farmers. Read more about Wegaâ€™s success here: https://iesc.org/f2f-weathering-the-drought/

The USAID LinkSME project in Vietnam, implemented by IESC, performs pre-evaluations of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to identify areas to improve their manufacturing and quality management capabilities. On December 28, the project worked with a lead firm to pre-evaluate SME Cunmac in Binh Duong province. Cunmac produces roll-forming roof panel machines, which could meet the lead firm's demand for steel brackets. The project will complete the pre-evaluation report this month and follow up with the lead firm. (Photo by: Cunmac)

Front Line Defenders and partners presents its Annual Lecture for 2023. taking place from 29-31 March 2023:

Presented by Iranian feminist activist, journalist and writer Parvin Ardalan, join us for ''Jin Jian Azadi / Woman Life Freedom: A social vision for human dignity and human rights''

The governmentâ€™s murder of Jina Amini in September 2022 rocketed Iranian society into a revolutionary moment where women emerged as a symbol of resistance at the intersection of all forms of discrimination. In this paradigm shift, the past and current protest movements are linked together through the celebrated slogan of â€œJin Jian Azadiâ€. 

In her lecture, Parvin will unpack the current revolutionary moment in Iran. How and why did the governmentâ€™s murder of Jina take us to this particular point? Join us as Parvin discusses the radical potential and meaning of ''Jin, Jian, Azadi'' (Woman, Life, Freedom). She will insist on the entangled relation of the three elements of this slogan and as such will argue that this slogan by linking the everyday and material necessities of life to the abstract notion of â€˜rightsâ€™ opens a new horizon of feminist politics for Iran, in specific and the human rights discourse in general.  

More info and registration here:

https://zurl.co/UrZo?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=Zoho+Social

PRESS STATEMENT:

Irish Government should use St. Patrickâ€™s Day diplomacy to urge protection of human rights defenders

Irish Government ministers visiting dozens of countries to mark St. Patrickâ€™s Day should use the opportunity to ensure their counterparts protect human rights defenders (HRDs) and enable them to carry out their peaceful work unhindered, Front Line Defenders said today.

The call comes as Irelandâ€™s Department of Foreign Affairs dispatches 36 representatives on diplomatic visits to 44 countries to mark Irelandâ€™s national holiday â€“ in what it describes as its â€œbiggest everâ€ such initiative to promote â€œGlobal Irelandâ€. 

The Irish Government has repeatedly stated that it prioritises HRDs and their protection in its foreign policy. At Front Line Defendersâ€™ biennial Dublin Platform event held at Dublin Castle in October 2022, Jack Chambers, TD, then-Chief Whip and Minister of State for Sport and the Gaeltacht said: â€œHuman Rights Defenders are humanityâ€™s best hope for justice and accountability.â€ 

Many more HRDs are at constant risk of a wide range of intimidation, including physical and online attacks, smear campaigns and arbitrary detention, as a result of their human rights work. Some are imprisoned unjustly for years on end. 

READ FULL STATEMENT HERE:
https://zurl.co/AEOZ?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=Zoho+Social

"Covid 19 and Women in Sri Lanka". A comprehensive analysis into the current situation and its impact on Women published on today's Daily FT by Ms. Seroshi Nandasiri, Chair & Founder of WIF. 

Quote: 
At the forefront of the countryâ€™s health battle against COVID-19 are women. The nursing fraternity is dominated by women and a staggering 62% of health and social work jobs are also being held by women (Ministry of National Policies and Economic Affairs, 2016). As indicated by the Ministry of National Policies and Economic Affairs, in 2016 more than half of the medical students in Sri Lanka since 2000 have been women and around 70% of students enrolled in paramedics are also women. This is an indication of the level of representation and contribution women make in the battle against the pandemic, and also an indication as to how this important human capital generates return on investment (ROI). 
The most overlooked is the impact on women, an important resource which comprises 51.97% (World Bank, 2018) of the Sri Lankan population. 
Unquote. 
#covid19, #women #impact #battle #srilanka #empowerment
