On International Women's Day, we are highlighting the cases of women human rights defenders who have been harshly targeted for their admirable human rights work. All around the world, women human rights defenders are adversely targeted in different ways for the human rights work they conduct. The cases we highlight today represent some of the most urgent cases of WHRDs who have been silenced by authorities or broader society.  

Ms. Houayheuang Xayabouly, also known as Muay, is a Lao tour guide and shop owner. She is also an environmental and woman human rights defender that contributes to the protection of the rights of the Lao people by highlighting the harms caused by business activities and corruption, as well as calling for solutions to redress this. 

As a result of Muay's human rights work, she was made an example of by the Lao PDR government. She addressed corruption, called out unfair practises by businesses and companies, and denounced the impacts which they had on the Lao people. 

As a result, she is currently imprisoned, facing a sentence of 5 years and a fine of 20 million Kip. Due process and standards were not followed in her pre-trial detention and summary trial. 

You can sign a petition calling for her release here:

https://zurl.co/GwuZ 
https://zurl.co/F158 

 #IWD2023 #IWD #InternationalWomensDay #whrds #iwd23

On International Women's Day, we are highlighting the cases of women human rights defenders who have been harshly targeted for their admirable human rights work. All around the world, women human rights defenders are adversely targeted in different ways for the human rights work they conduct. The cases we highlight today represent some of the most urgent cases of WHRDs who have been silenced by authorities or broader society.  

The context for WHRDs in Iran is dire. Amidst the break out of protests in Iran in late 2022, a number of WHRDs were arrested as a means of silencing protesters and dissent. Additionally, there was also a crackdown on prominent WHRDs who were already active in human rights work before the protests.

We have highlighted below a few cases of Iranian WHRDs who are currently imprisoned on trumped up charges. We call on authorities to:

We call on authorities to:

- Release all WHRDs immediately 
- drop all charges against them 
- end the harassment against WHRDs for their peaceful human rights work
- guarantee the protection of their physical and psychological integrity

Yesterday (09/08/2023), CEJ facilitated a training programme on agroecological practices applicable to home gardening and organic fertilizer production under the GGF project. The training was held at the School of Floriculture and Landscape Gardening, Botanical Gardens Peradeniya. The aim of the training programme was to promote organic agriculture-based self-employment for a selected group of physically challenged people in Kandy District. The lectures were conducted on how to engage in plant production through natural gardening and the methods of maintaining it, flower seedlings and vegetable types, and market opportunities for plant production. The participants were then taken on a field visit to the Botanical Garden to give them an opportunity to learn more about joint gardening.

#StoriesOfResettlement: Pushpakanthi sells fish with her husband. Without proper methods for storing fish and reduced demand for fish, they faced difficulties in earning a profit. UNDP provided a deep freezer and a digital scale and conducted a training programme on how to preserve and pack fish for the market, allowing the family to finally earn a profit. Keerthana, a budding seamstress received training through UNDP on how to improve her sewing and marketing skills. This has allowed her to expand her business. Sinthuja makes cement bricks for a living. The knowledge gained through UNDP's workshops has helped improve profits and allowed her family to construct a barrier wall and make much-needed repairs to the house. Priya, a textile shop owner, has expanded her business by utilising her learnings through UNDP's training programme and has now built a new building with proper showcases, and more clothes. 

The Support for Durable Resettlement (SDR) Project supports the resettlement of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and refugee returnees, providing them with durable resettlement opportunities including access to essential basic services, sustainable livelihoods and income generation opportunities. 

The SDR Project is implemented by the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP in Sri Lanka together with the Government of Sri Lanka, with funding from the British High Commission Colombo, across 4 Districts in #Jaffna, #Kilinochchi, #Mullaitivu and #Trincomalee.

On International Women's Day, we are highlighting the cases of women human rights defenders who have been harshly targeted for their admirable human rights work. All around the world, women human rights defenders are adversely targeted in different ways for the human rights work they conduct. The cases we highlight today represent some of the most urgent cases of WHRDs who have been silenced by authorities or broader society.  

Spotlighting Floriane Irangabiye,  WHRD and journalist from Burundi who has been detained for over six months. In 2019, she co-founded Radio Igicaniro, a Rwanda-based online outlet established by Burundian exiles and expatriates. Her arrest is an attempt at silencing her and the work being done at Radio Igicaniro.

We call for her immediate release and for all charges against her to be dropped.

With assistance from the USAID LinkSME Project in Vietnam, implemented by IESC, the Administrative Procedure Control Agency (APCA) of the Office of the Government (OOG) gathered 90 participants from various Peopleâ€™s Committees and Tax and Social Insurance Departments from the northern provinces, as well as representatives of government ministries, to share their experiences in implementing administrative procedures through One Stop Shops (OSS). The OSS model is a key element of LinkSMEâ€™s support to digitize and streamline administrative procedures, such as business registration, export-import procedures, and tax payments. This support aims to make government-to-business interactions more predictable, accountable, and efficient.

On International Women's Day, we are highlighting the cases of women human rights defenders who have been harshly targeted for their admirable human rights work. All around the world, women human rights defenders are adversely targeted in different ways for the human rights work they conduct. The cases we highlight today represent some of the most urgent cases of WHRDs who have been silenced by authorities or broader society.  

Spotlighting Lesbia Artola from #Guatemala, a member of the CCDA (Campesino Committee of the Highlands) in Guatemala. She fights against sexism in all its forms, works to amplify the voices of women human rights defenders and promotes gender equality. Lesbia also fights for men and womenâ€™s equal exercise of the right to land, as well as for Campesino rights.

Lesbia has courageously and bravely resisted the extermination of native people in Guatemala, while fighting for access to land and labour rights for Mayan indigenous in Guatemala. Through her human rights work she has consistently been subjected to threats, intimidation and defamation shrouded in misogynistic and racist overtones. 

We call for:

- all charges + lawsuits against Lesbia to be dropped
- authorities to guarantee her protection and safety
- authorities to hold accountable those who are targeting and harassing her for her work 

https://zurl.co/hUBT  #IWD2023 #IWD #InternationalWomensDay #whrds #iwd23

A sustainable dairy sector is critical for Sri Lankaâ€™s food security, health, and prosperity, all of which have suffered due to the ongoing economic crisis. The Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock Division requested that the USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project, implemented by IESC, support the development of a national dairy policy and strategy through a public-private dialogue. In November 2022, MOD brought together more than 100 dairy sector professionals from across the government and private sector to determine policy direction and strategic approaches required to meet the countryâ€™s fresh milk needs. Based on these discussions, MOD consultant Dr. Don Mitchell will draft the dairy sector policy document for the Ministry of Agriculture in early 2023.

On International Women's Day, we are highlighting the cases of women human rights defenders who have been harshly targeted for their admirable human rights work. All around the world, women human rights defenders are adversely targeted in different ways for the human rights work they conduct. The cases we highlight today represent some of the most urgent cases of WHRDs who have been silenced by authorities or broader society.  

Spotlighting Gulnara Dzhurabayeva, Klara Sooronkulova, Rita Karasartova, and Asya Sasykbayeva - #Kyrgyzstani women human rights defenders who have peacefully opposed the transfer of ownership of the Kempir-Abad water reserve from Kyrgyzstan to Uzbekistan.  On 24 October 2022, the WHRDs were arbitrarily arrested and detained for their peaceful protest against tranferring the ownership of the Kempir-Abad water reserve from Kyrgyzstan to Uzbekistan. They have remained in pre-trial detention since their arrest, now more than 4 months. 

We call on authorities to:

- Release the WHRDs immediately 
- drop all charges against them 
- end the harassment against them for their human rights work
- guarantee the protection of their physical and psychological integrity

The poor working conditions faced by garment workers in Sri Lanka's Export Processing Zones (EPZs) are concerning. Various human rights violations and safety concerns are faced by workers, particularly female and transgender workers, who are exposed to sexual harassment and abuse in the workplace. Most garment workers are women, yet they are primarily concentrated in low-paying and low-skilled jobs.
The contrast between the rapid growth of the Sri Lankan apparel sector and the need for more progress for workers is stark. Despite the sector's growth, workers have not received increased wages or improved working conditions.
Join FORUM-ASIA and Law & Society Trust in the report launch event tomorrow to talk about challenges and ways forward on labour conditions faced in EPZ in Sri Lanka.

The event will be live-streamed live â–¶ï¸ youtube.com/@lawsocietytrust8867

On International Women's Day, we are highlighting the cases of women human rights defenders who have been harshly targeted for their admirable human rights work. All around the world, women human rights defenders are adversely targeted in different ways for the human rights work they conduct. The cases we highlight today represent some of the most urgent cases of WHRDs who have been silenced by authorities or broader society. 

Spotlighting He Fangmei today, a #Chinese woman human rights defender who advocates for vaccine safety and for access to remedies for victims of defective vaccines after her daughter was paralysed from one.

In October 2020, she was disappeared after conducting a protest in front of a local government office in Huixian, Xinxiang, Henan province. She was pregnant at the time. She remains in extensive detention indefinitely and the whereabouts of her children are still unclear. 

We call for her immediate release and for all charges against her to be dropped immediately. Read her full case here:

https://zurl.co/MsiQ

Joint Statement: 

FLD and other organizations bring light to the dire political situation in Bahrain in light of the 146th Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) Assembly. 

''The slogan of the IPU is â€œFor democracy. For everyone,â€ and the theme for this yearâ€™s conference is â€œPromoting peaceful coexistence and inclusive societies: Fighting intolerance.â€

The government of Bahrain, however, imposes restrictions on expression, association, and assembly that violate Bahrainâ€™s international human rights obligations. Elections are neither free nor fair, and opposition voices are systematically excluded and repressed. ''

At IESC, private sector growth has always been at the heart of our workâ€”work that helps people around the world to improve their lives. We have a storied history of contributing to sustainable economic development and job creation, including in the most challenging environments. 

We are excited to launch our new name, Improving Economies for Stronger Communities (IESC), which embraces our history while reflecting who we are and what we do in the present day. Thank you for being partners in our efforts to create economic opportunity around the world by catalyzing private sector growth and employment. We are privileged to continue this important work with you.

The â€˜Understanding Multidimensional Vulnerabilities: Impact on People of Sri Lankaâ€™ Policy Report launched by United Nations Development Programme - UNDP #lka together with OPHI - Oxford Poverty and Human Development Initiative marks #SriLankaâ€™s first ever Multidimensional Vulnerability Index (MVI), derived using the National Citizen Survey (NCS) 2022-23.

It showcases the overlapping challenges faced by the population through a set of indicators that capture #vulnerabilities beyond traditional income-based measures, looking at three dimensions: #education, health and disasters, and living standards.

To learn more about the Policy Report visit: www.undp.org/srilanka/mvi

Our Maternity Kit is designed to provide the simplest amenities that have the greatest impact on a womanâ€™s health and wellbeing during their pregnancy. 

With support from Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, UNFPA Sri Lanka was able to supply emergency maternity kits to pregnant women.

ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡­ #Bahrain 

HRD Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja has systemically been denied urgent medical treatment while in prison, particularly in the last year, punishing him for protesting to ill-treatment in prison. 

Abdulhadi informed his family of gross ill-treatment by prison guards in relation to serious health complications that he is experiencing. on the evening of 28 February, he experienced intense elevated and rapid heart beats, in addition to laboured breathing, and at the insistence of the prison doctor, he was transferred from Jau Prison to the emergency room at the Bahrain Defence Force (BDF) Hospital. The er doctor stated that he must be immediately referred to a cardiologist. However, he was denied access to a cardiologist and was returned back to Jau Prison. While at the hospital, the security forces attempted to place the human rights defender in handcuffs. Abdulhadi has been facing a systematic denial of medical treatment by the Bahraini prison administration. According to reports between January 2022 and April 2022, necessary medical treatment was actively withheld from him by the Bahraini authorities, and access to medical appointments was denied which has resulted in his worsening health. 

We are deeply concerned about his situation:  

https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/case/human-rights-defender-abdulhadi-al-khawaja-taken-ambulance-emergency-room-urgent-heart-issues?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=Zoho+Social

For nearly six decades, IESC has catalyzed private sector growth in the economically developing world. Working with local counterparts, we solve real problems and share lasting solutions that help people improve their lives. 

We are thrilled to launch our new name, Improving Economies for Stronger Communities (IESC), which captures the work that we do and why we do it. 

Thank you for being partners in our efforts to achieve our vision of a world with economic opportunity for all, where people and communities thrive. We look forward to continuing this important work together.

Bidya is a teacher by profession and the womenâ€™s president of the World Newa Guthi, an indigenous community organization. She has long been leading the movement to stop illegal road expansions, and has been threatened, physically attacked and arbitrarily detained as a result. 

She shares her story of her community, and the challenges she has faced as a human rights defender defending the rights of the Newa Guthi people from illegal construction.

Transform Sri Lanka

On December 11th, 2022, IESCâ€™s SDC and USAID-funded Skilled and Resilient Migrant Workers Project (SRMW) in Sri Lanka held a special online game streaming event of a recreated episode of â€˜Ata Pass,â€™ a behavioral change drama series, for youth with migrant work aspirations. The episode, which aired on a gaming platform, featured eight gamers playing out the storylines of the eight â€˜Ata Passâ€™ characters. With IESCâ€™s support, the gamers delivered a career guidance message, endorsing skilled migration and encouraging fans to connect with YouLeadâ€™s career guidance hotline. Tapping into the 4 million+ gaming base audience in Sri Lanka, the videos exceeded 100,000 views in 24 hours. Requests to sign up for YouLead's career guidance assistance spiked, indicating that the episode reached a wider audience. The two most popular streamers trended at #5 and #8 among all gaming stream videos in the country.

Since September 2022, following the death of Masha (Jina) Amini while in police custody, Front Line Defenders has monitored the cases of over two hundred human rights defenders, journalists and student activists, who were, and continue to be, arrested and arbitrarily detained, charged with security-related actions and sentenced for their human rights work.

Hundreds of prisoners, including human rights defenders, have been released since the Iranian judicial system announced that the Iranian Supreme Leader had pardoned 10,000 prisoners in Iran. 

While Front Line Defenders welcomes the release of a number of human rights defenders, we call on the Iranian authorities to release the hundreds of human rights defenders who remain in detention. 

This includes:

Narges Mohammadi, Mustafa Nili, Golrokh Iraee, Bahareh Hedayat, Esmail Abdi, Reza Shahabi, Hassan Saidi, Vida Rabbani, Amirsalar Davoudi, Arash Keykhosravi, Rasoul Bodaghi, Jafar Ebrahimi, Nasrin Javadi, Soheil Arabi, Sepideh Gholian, Soha Mortezaie, Mehdi Mahmoudian, Akram Nasirian, Fariba Kamalabadi, Mahvash Shahriari (Sabet), Afif Naimi, Behnam Mousivand, Sam Rajabi, and Kasra Nouri. 

Front Line Defenders additionally calls on the Iranian authorities to drop charges against Arash Sadeghi, who was sentenced by Branch 26 of the Tehran Revolutionary Court to five years in prison on 26 January 2023 for the advocacy he carried out from inside prison, calling for the rights of protesters to be respected, in particular the right to life. â€™ 

Read full statement here:

https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/statement-iran-should-unconditionally-release-all-detained-human-rights-defenders

The world indigenous day 2023 was celebrated today in Morabadda, Dambana with the participation of around 100 indigenous people representing Dhambana, Rathugala, Henanigala, Pollebadda, Wakare and Dalukaana as well as around 70 government officers and journalists. As usual, CEJ was presented a copy of "Morabadda sandeshaya", the document compiling the problems faced by indigenous people of Sri Lanka. CEJ presented a letter to the Minister of Buddhist, religion and cultural affairs, Hon. Minister Vidura wickramanayaka, reminding the issues presented last year and importance of government involvement in resolving them. In fact, this was the main message of the Chieftain Uruwarige Wannilaththo.

Human trafficking is considered a serious crime in Sri Lanka. But do you know what types of services victims can access in Sri Lanka? How well does the existing service framework respond to their particular needs? What measures can we adopt to make sure they receive the support they require?

Front Line Defenders joins ten human rights groups in urging the EU to continue the suspension of the EU-China Human Rights Dialogue, until meetings can bring genuine human rights improvements - which was not the case in previous 37 rounds.

If the EU continue to hold the Human Rights Dialogue with China in spite of the concerns of civil society, it should use the occasion to raise individual cases of human rights defenders who have endured a number of human rights violations, and demand their immediate and unconditional release .

Here are but a few examples of how HRDs are treated in China. Against a backdrop of credible allegations by @UNHumanRights of crimes against Humanity committed by the Chinese government & continued persecution of human rights defenders, â€˜â€™business as usualâ€™â€™ should not go ahead with China.

What is freedom...? As a country, as a nation, and as individuals are we really free..? This is the question that we all ask especially nowadays... 
We believe that "Freedom means breaking frames". We went to different areas across the country in search of individuals who broke the existing social barriers & boundaries for their freedom and as well as dedicated themselves to the real freedom of other people and society.
Sundaralingam Kalaichchelvi, We had an opportunity to talk to her and this is how she has shared her thoughts and experiences with us.
The full program will be released soon on YouTube.

Niranjani Shanmugaraja

text: UNFPA Sri Lanka hosted a consultation with the Police Women and Children's Desks to strengthen their capacity to respond to gender-based violence. Ministry of Public Security and Sri Lanka Police joined the consultation.

ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¸  #Spain

Five human rights defenders are bringing legal action over the infiltration of social + labour movements by a police officer from the Spanish National Police Corps in Barcelona. The under cover officer in question used intimate, sexual relationships, to create and consolidate a bond of trust with those movements.   His actions were endorsed and backed up by the rest of the police. Thanks to an investigation conducted by the newspaper, La Directa, the officerâ€™s activity was documented from May 2020 to October 2022. It is essential to expose, name, and challenge this type of police strategy, integrated into a state policy, as well as the specific gender-based violence it entails, in order to demand truth, justice, reparation and, above all, prevent these events from happening again. 

Front Line Defenders joins over 80 organisations in calling out the Spanish state and police for the violation of fundamental rights, and exploiting intimate and sexual relationships to monitor political dissident.

Read full statement here:

https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/statement-police-infiltration-social-movements-recent-years-spain

Hoof trimming is an important aspect of intensive dairy cow management. The functional life of dairy cows can be extended through proper hoof trimming and claw care. When cows have properly trimmed hooves, they are generally healthier and happier, leading to higher milk production. In addition, it will result in a reduction of lameness and will prevent laminitis and foot rot. The USDA-funded Market Oriented Dairy (MOD) Project in Sri Lanka, implemented by IESC, identified hoof trimming as an essential area in which skills were lacking in the country. To help address this gap, IESC fielded an international hoof trimming volunteer expert, Pieter Kloosterman, to visit large dairy farms, assess their current hoof trimming practices, and deliver hands-on training to improve knowledge and skills. Mr. Kloosterman trained 30 farm workers on three large farms. IESC plans to build on these workshops by establishing a hoof trimming certificate course for the Department of Animal Production and Health.

I think freedom is a journey rather than a place where we can reach or something that we can achieve. Frames are something we put on ourselves. Living in these frames or breaking them and coming out of them is a decision. That's our responsibility.
- Yasodhara Pathanjali -

text:
After fleeing South Sudan to Kenya due to death threats, South Sudanese HRD Morris Mabior was attacked + abducted in Kenya and is reportedly being held in prison in Juba, South Sudan. We are concerned for his well being and call for his immediate release:

https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/case/fourth-and-fifth-hearings-case-woman-human-rights-defender-justyna-wydrzynska 

In 2021, FLD published a report on South Sudanese HRDs who flee to Kenya - still facing persistent cross-border harassment by the South Sudanese government, who operate in the neighbouring territory to pursue those who have fled. 

Read more here:
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/sites/default/files/no_refuge_-_final.pdf

â€œWhat do women do in the fishing industry?â€
"They are supporting us with making dry fish, cleaning, fixing, and bait preparing.â€
 Some of the fishermen who we met in North, Sri Lanka
Womenâ€™s role in fishery industries has been identified as a supportive role for men from the histories.  IS IT SO? 
The fishery women that we met at Kottadi village in Point Pedro, Jaffna are mostly engaging in bait preparing ( à®¤à¯‚à®£à¯à®Ÿà®¿à®²à¯ à®•à®Ÿà¯à®Ÿà¯à®¤à®²à¯) for fishing nets. In this process, their service is taken from the boat owners and sometimes their husbands if they own a fishing boat.
They are paid Rs 2,000 per fishing net box if they clean the fishing net by removing the waste baits and fixing the treads and needles. Apart from that if they do the baiting, they are paid Rs 3,000 for one fishing net box. The fishery women come into the bait preparation site and usually, it takes 4 to five 5 hours to finish one box.

JOINT STATEMENT - FRONT LINE DEFENDERS, FORUM-ASIA, and ASEAN Parliamentarians for Human Rights 

Two years after the Myanmar military launched a coup on 1 February 2021, civil society organizations strongly condemn the ongoing human rights violations, and call for accountability and the restoration of a legitimate government. The attempted coup breached Myanmarâ€™s constitution and international law, and was met with massive and largely spontaneous protests that illustrated the lack of meaningful support for the junta among the people of Myanmar. To date, sustained opposition among the population has denied the junta full control over the country, despite an escalation in brutality. There are many well-documented cases of the military committing atrocities, including strong evidence of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

In this context, human rights defenders are more vulnerable because of their work and their visibility, and their safety in both Myanmar and neighboring countries continues to deteriorate. 

Read full statement here: https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/two-years-after-myanmars-military-coup-human-rights-violations-continue-escalate

The Market Oriented Dairy (MOD) project, initiated in 2017 by USDAâ€™s Food for Progress program and implemented by IESC, launched a voucher initiative in mid-2022 that enables progressive farmers to invest in climate-smart equipment such as solar-powered pumps to irrigate fields for nutrient-rich fodder. Farmers who are already applying progressive techniques and practices can receive vouchers from MOD to purchase equipment from participating vendors at a significant discount. Some 1,200 dairy entrepreneurs are expected to enroll in the voucher program.

Today, on International Human Rights Defenders Day, we are happy to present the #FLDAward22 for Europe and Central Asia to the inspiring women human rights defender Volha Harbunova from #Belarus. She remained anonymous at the time of announcement earlier this year due to security reasons. 

Volha has consistently worked to protect women and girls at the risk of her own personal freedom and in spite of the hostile culture against HRDs in Belarus, leading marches and initiatives to protect womens rights in Belarus.  Volha has consistently worked to protect women and girls at the risk of her own personal freedom and in spite of the hostile culture against HRDs in Belarus. In November 2021, Volha was arrested in Minsk in relation to her alleged involvement in organising marches that were supporting womenâ€™s rights in the summer of 2020.  She was released earlier this year, enduring horrific conditions while in  detention.

She is currently sentenced to 3 years of detention without commitment to a penitentiary institution for her  work defending  women's rights.

Blockchain and barcode technology is helping Vietnamese small and medium enterprises (SMEs) satisfy the traceability of goods increasingly in demand by larger international buyers. On November 21-22, the USAID Linkages for Small and Medium Enterprises (USAID LinkSME) Project, the Agency for Enterprise Development (AED), and the Department of Planning and Investment in Ninh Thuan province trained Vietnamese Government officials and SMEs on how to combine blockchains, barcodes, and branding to build credibility in the traceability of their products. The course attracted 71 participants from local SMEs and the provincial Department of Science and Technology. SMEs showing a commitment and potential in these three areas are eligible for further technical advice on implementation. Traceability in the supply chain is becoming essential to ensuring compliance with international trade requirements and is rapidly becoming just as important as scale, quality, and quantity, making SMEs winning the â€œrace to traceâ€ more competitive.

There are just four days left to donate to IESC this giving season! Your support expands our legacy of helping people and communities thrive. In the Dominican Republic, for example, we are helping a family farm started in 1942 to grow its business by exporting to the U.S. market. With our ongoing support and training, they can now meet rigorous U.S. market requirements and have just signed their first contract to export to the U.S. With IESCâ€™s support, the family farm business is well-positioned for growthâ€”growth that will help the family and those that work for them to improve their lives. Luis, the business owner today, said, â€œNow we have the opportunity to grow our business by exporting to the U.S., and this is all thanks to our dream and to the help you provided us.'' 

Click here to donate now! Your support will help propel IESC's efforts into the new year.

The Government of #SriLankaâ€™s ğŸ‡±ğŸ‡° forum on Sustainable Development Trajectories & Pathways led by Sustainable Development Council of Sri Lanka took place yesterday presided by Ranil Wickremesinghe President of Sri Lanka, to invoke a surge in commitment from all stakeholders to action and realize the #SDGs. 

At the forum, Chamindry Saparamadu Director General of 
Sustainable Development Council of Sri Lanka  shared #SriLankaâ€™s #SDG progress and the National #SDG dashboard - to take stock and look ahead on #SDGAction for a sustainable development pathway. Presenting United Nations Development Programme - UNDP's global offer to the #SDGSummit- the SDG Insight Report for #SriLanka, Azusa Kubota, Resident Representative for #SriLanka noted that this analysis will help direct the focus of reforms, policy and programmatic interventions and resources to achieve sustainable development while addressing needs of the most vulnerable.

Also present at the forum were key representatives from the Government, United Nations Sri Lanka Resident Coordinator Marc-Andre Franche, dignitaries from the development sector, representatives from the private sector and CSOs in Sri Lanka, with video messages shared by United Nations ESCAP & UNDP in Asia and the Pacific

Repeal PTA.. No to reforms.. No to replace..
A public gathering was held recently in Colombo, demanding the government to repeal the PTA act without adding any amendments to it. The convener of the Inter-University Student Council, Wasantha Mudalige, lawyer Armisa Teagle, lawyer Nuvan Bopage, and lawyer Swastika Arulingam addressed the gathering.

With support from IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Tradeâ€“Facilitating Agricultural Systems and Technology (T-FAST) project in Paraguay, the Paraguayan Industrial Union (UIP) has been working on a union strengthening plan to optimize processes and improve institutional capacities. IESC and UIP work together to help public institutions adopt ICT systems and more efficient technologies that help facilitate international trade. To ensure the sustainability of systems implemented by T-FAST, IESC is providing organizational development assistance to UIP, including conducting a comprehensive institutional analysis, collaboratively developing a new organizational strategic plan, and designing a monitoring and control system for planned activities. IESC utilizes an inclusive, participatory, and interactive methodology to include participants from all divisions across UIP, positioning the organization to support groups linked to foreign trade more effectively. #UIP #PlanificacionEstrategica #TFAST #USDA Proyecto T-FAST

WE ARE HIRING! 

We have an interesting job opportunity for law graduates who are interested in environmental law and are passionate about environmental justice. 

CEJ is an environmental organization dedicated to protecting equal environmental rights of people and animals and promoting ecological sustainability by supporting ecologically sound community activities. CEJ has filed over 200 cases relating to environmental issues, including the Wilpattu deforestation matter and the X-press pearl disaster. We are looking for individuals who want to bring justice to people and animals affected by environmental issues and who are planning to pursue a career in environmental law.

Sounds like you?
Then please send us your CV to the email address mentioned in the job advertisement below.

Learn more about us: https://ejustice.lk/

UNFPA Sri Lanka with the Ministry of Health led a discussion with 8 key ministries to develop a way forward on menstrual health & hygiene advocacy, with a focus on the rights based health and dignity of women and girls & reduction of the environmental impact. The discussion also covered the importance of integrating Comprehensive Sexuality Education in schools.
Covid 19 and impact on Women.

A UNDP Country Diagnostic Mission on #SDGs Taxation Framework (STF) & Taxation and Gender Equality took place from 21-25th August 2023 in Colombo, #SriLanka in partnership with the Inland Revenue Dept (IRD) & Fiscal Policy Dept (FPD) of the Ministry of Finance- Sri Lanka, and in collaboration with Sustainable Development Council of Sri Lanka and the Ministry of Women & Child Affairs.

The purpose of the mission was first to promote a shared understanding of tax and SDGs issues amongst tax administrators, policy makers and other stakeholders at the national level, and second to support carrying out a self-evaluation using an SDG taxation framework to evaluate the coherence of tax systems with respect to specific targets for SDG 17 related to DRM and SDG 5 related to Gender Equality.

READ MORE: https://www.undp.org/srilanka/press-releases/sdgs-taxation-framework-stf-sri-lanka 
UNDP in Asia and the Pacific United Nations Sri Lanka #Tax4SDGs

The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program, together with USAID/Georgia Mission Director John Pennell, officially launched a new grant partnership with Business and Technology University (BTU) Georgia. With support from the Program, BTU will train 1,500 women across six regions of Georgia in software development and testing, user experience design, graphic design, and digital marketing to increase and diversify the countryâ€™s qualified ICT workforce. The partnership will also aim to break gender stereotypes in the industry and raise awareness about women's career prospects in the ICT sector nationwide.

ğŸ“¢ğŸ“¢ CALL FOR NOMINATIONS:

Nominations for the 2023 Front Line Defenders Award is now open - honoring HRDs courageously contributing to the protection of human rights, often at great personal risk to themselves.

See more details and nominate an HRD here: 

Forms are available in various different languages. 

The Front Line Defenders Award is intended for HRDs for whom visibility can contribute to their security and who have not already had a lot of international recognition for their human rights work.

DEADLINE FOR SUBMISSIONS IS: 13th January 2023

Selection Criteria:

 -the nature of human rights defender's work
 -the impact of human rights defender's work in advancing the rights of others
 -the level of risk or negative consequences associated with human rights defender's work
 -the continued commitment to advancing human rights, despite high level risks
 -the potential impact of receiving the Award on the human rights defender and their work

Nomination Guidelines:

 -Incomplete nominations will not be considered.
 -Nominations can be submitted by organisations or individuals.
 -Individual nominees may not play a prominent role in a political party.
 - Individual nominees must be currently active in human rights work (the Front Line Defenders Award is not intended to recognise a historical or posthumous contribution).
- Individual nominees should not have previously been the recipient of high-profile international recognition.
- Nominees should be active human rights defenders and if in exile, only nominations of HRDs still at risk will be eligible.
- Self-nomination is not permitted.
- The number of nominations a HRD or organisation receives is not considered when evaluating the nominees. 

More info and forms here:
 
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/front-line-defenders-award

IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Trade Safe (TraSa) project in the Dominican Republic recently held a graduation ceremony for its second farmer field school (FFS) training program. The FFS program helps packinghouses and producers comply with the U.S. Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA). With local partner CEDAF, IESC celebrated the next round of participants completing the FFS, which helps ensure the fresh produce exported from DR follows health and food safety regulations required for entrance into US markets. With IESCâ€™s support, these courses build producersâ€™ and packinghousesâ€™ knowledge of the FSMA Produce Safety Rule, which supports trade facilitation in the DR. #ProyectoTraSa #ProyectoTradeSafe #TraSa #TradeSafe Proyecto Trade Safe

JOINT STATEMENT: 

On International Women Human Rights Defenders Day, Front Line Defenders and others express concern about ongoing detention of WHRD Li Yuhan who has been detained since October 2017, and remains so indefinitely. Li Yuhan is a veteran human rights lawyer who started practising in the 1990s. One of her cases included that of Wang Yu, one of the most prominent lawyers arrested in the â€œ709 crackdownâ€ - a mass arrest of human rights lawyers and other activists in 2015. The arrest of Li was regarded as retaliation for her involvement in Wang Yuâ€™s and other cases. and other sensitive cases. Li Yuhan has been detained in Shenyang City, the capital of the Northeastern province of Liaoning since October 2017. Although her case was tried last year, there is still no verdict and her release date remains unknown. We call for all charges against Li Yuhan to be dropped and release her immediately and unconditionally. 

Read more:
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/joint-statement-calling-release-li-yuhan

IESC brings private sector development to the economically developing world - sharing proven skills and experience and growing small and medium enterprises through sustainable business solutions. With your contributions, we can help people around the globe thrive - people like dairy farmer Mr. Sugath in Sri Lanka, who began working with IESC in 2019. Although based in the country's second-highest milk-producing region, Mr. Sugathâ€™s operation only produced 25-30 liters of milk per day. Since working with IESC to cultivate his own fodder, provide clean drinking water to his cows, and improve the cowsâ€™ environment by adding a new shed, Mr. Sugathâ€™s dairy business now produces 100 liters of milk per day. Following his success, Mr. Sugath shared his experiences with 300 dairy farmers, who will now be able to improve their own milk production. To date, IESCâ€™s dairy program in Sri Lanka has served 6,108 dairy farmers like Mr. Sugath. Click here to make a donation!

On December 9, the USAID Linkages for Small and Medium Enterprises (USAID LinkSME) Project, Vietnamâ€™s Agency for Enterprise Development (AED), and the Association of Women Entrepreneurs of Dong Thap province organized a workshop on â€œImproving the competitiveness of women-owned enterprises through sound financial management.â€ Validus Vietnam, Chailease Vietnam, and HDBank informed 50 women-owned SMEs about alternative sources of finance such as purchase order financing, equipment leasing financing, low-interest loans, and online lending marketplaces. UNFPA Sri Lanka and University of Colombo with the Sarvodaya Shramadhana Movement launched the â€˜Youth Wellness Centerâ€™, a collaborative initiative to provide a safe and creative space for young people to connect and access youth friendly services to enhance their health and wellbeing.

The 25th of November marks the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. Every year, this day signals the beginning of 16 days of activism against Gender-Based Violence. 

Those working on womenâ€™s rights, especially in patriarchal societies, often face push back and resistance for the work they are carrying out. This year, we spotlight the African Girls Empowerment Network, better known as the AGE network, based in Nigeria â€“ a collective working to end violence against women - whether structural, physical, emotional or other. 

In this episode of Rights on The Line, African Girls Empowerment Network AGE networks Matina, Esther and Margeret share the challenges they face in their work, the nuances of advocating for womens rights within a patriarchal society, and their own experiences and stories as women regarding the work they carry out at AGE network in Nigeria.  

LISTEN NOW on all major platforms by searching for ''Rights on The Line''. 

SoundCloud link here:

https://soundcloud.com/front-line-defenders/violence-against-women-in-nigeria-in-conversation-with-the-african-girls-empowerment-network-age

Since 1964, IESC has delivered lasting solutions that have resulted in more than 1.5 million jobs in 137 countries. We recently helped establish specialized workforce training centers for Bosnia and Herzegovinaâ€™s metal and textile sectors. The goal was to help job seekers, especially women, acquire new skills and increase their employability. With IESCâ€™s support, 53% of the job seekers secured jobs immediately after the training. Apart from meeting the needs of the textile and metal sectors for skilled labor, IESC helped contribute to the economic empowerment of women and greater representation in the labor market. Joint Statement - India: Human rights organisations call for the release of Khurram Parvez after one year of arbitrary detention:

''Khurram Parvez, the Coordinator of the Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society (JKCCS) and Chairperson of the Asian Federation Against Involuntary Disappearances (AFAD), has been a champion of human rights advocacy, documentation, and investigations including in the Jammu and Kashmir region, for over 20 years. 

On November 22, 2021, Indiaâ€™s counterterrorism body, the National Investigation Agency (NIA), raided Parvezâ€™s home and office for approximately 14 hours, seizing his and his family membersâ€™ laptop, mobile phone, and books. He was then called in for questioning at the NIA office where he was arrested on the basis of a First Information Report lodged by the NIA on November 6, 2021. The arrest memo stated that Parvez was being charged under the Indian Penal Code and the Unlawful Activities Prevention Act (UAPA), Indiaâ€™s abusive counterterrorism law, which makes release on bail difficult. 

Parvez has now been in detention for one year. His arbitrary detention is part of a longstanding list of human rights violations committed by Indian authorities against human rights defenders, civil society organisations, journalists, and activists in Jammu and Kashmir. Rather than working towards accountability for these violations, authorities have targeted and arrested those who have exposed and sought justice for such violations.  ''

On December 9, 2022, US Ambassador to Georgia, Kelly Degnan, visited Construct2 Vocational College in West Georgia. Construct2 is a partnership between USAID, BK Construction, and the Government of Georgia to train young people to qualify for existing job vacancies and fuel Georgiaâ€™s economic growth. Over the past year, The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program supported BK Construction and Construct2 College to conduct outreach and promote high-value employment opportunities in the sector. These efforts garnered interest from the public and resulted in a 20% increase in enrollment.

The Legal Aid Commission (LAC) in Sri Lanka recently signed an agreement with United Nations Development Programme - UNDP's flagship Support to Justice Sector Project (#JURE). 

JURE is funded by the European Union in Sri Lanka and the Maldives and jointly implemented by the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP #lka and UNICEF Sri Lanka, and is facilitated by the Ministry of Justice - Sri Lanka. This partnership seeks to realise LACâ€™s mandate by supporting:

- Launch of revised National Legal Aid Policy and Action Plan

- Partnerships with the Child Protection Authority, Department of Probation and Child Care Services, National Authority for the Protection of Victims of Crime and Witnesses and Human Rights Commission

- Represent bail cases from prisons and rehabilitation centres islandwide; develop a fee schedule for criminal matters beyond bail and related support.

- Conduct over 250 legal awareness programmes in remote areas islandwide.

- Facilitate meetings for indigenous people and LGBTQI + communities.
.
.
.

As a valued partner in the economically developing world, nothing brings us more joy than sharing proven skills and experience that help people thrive. In Tanzania, a pairing of our US and Tanzanian expert volunteers recently delivered hands-on leadership and management training for an agribusiness-focused foundation that supports youth and women farmers. With our support, one farmer group established a savings and credit service and can now loan up to USD 2,000 per member. Such financing is extremely impactful for youth and women farmers who are frequently excluded from the formal financial sector. 

You can help us empower more people to improve their lives by making a gift to IESC today. Your donation supports IESC in achieving our vision of a world with economic opportunity for all. Thank you for your support! http://ow.ly/nGJc50LXHaQ

NEW STATEMENT: #Bahrain

Front Line Defenders  is deeply concerned by a series of new criminal charges being tabled against leading HRD Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja, which appear to be a direct reprisal against Abdulhadi for speaking out in prison.

Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja is an internationally respected human rights defender who won the Martin Ennals Award for Human Rights Defenders in 2022, elected by a Jury of ten of the worldâ€™s leading human rights NGOs. In 2011 he was detained, tortured and subjected to an unfair trial on fabricated charges that led to him being sentenced to life in prison because of his human rights activities. That sentence was deemed arbitrary by the UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention as far back as 2012. He is also a dual Danish-Bahraini citizen. 

In recent weeks, Front Line Defenders has been informed of a series of new criminal charges being tabled against the human rights defender. These new charges appear to be a direct reprisal against Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja for his continued determination to speak out in the face of injustice and mistreatment at Jau prison.

The first of the new charges concerns an incident in November 2021 when Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja was denied his right to telephone calls with his daughters. He is charged with breaking a plastic chair and â€œverbally insultingâ€ a prison official. At the time, Al-Khawaja undertook a hunger strike in response to the denial of his right to telephone calls, and the telephone calls were later reinstated. 

Read the full statement here:

https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/statement-recent-judicial-harassment-of-human-rights-defender-abdulhadi-al-khawaja-in-bahrain 

#FreeAlkhawaja now!

On 17th July 2023, Kandiyapita Sobadam Surakime Samithiya organized an awareness programme on Climate change mitigation and adaptations at Thanamalwila Agrarian service centre under GGF project. CEJ was invited to contribute as resource person to conduct sessions on National Climate change adaptation and mitigation plan and climate change impact on Agriculture, and also Agrochemical wastes and the polythene wastes in the agriculture in Sri Lanka.

On the same day evening, Kandiyapita Sobadam Surakime Samithiya organized another awareness programme on Climate change mitigation and adaptations at Wellawaya,Thelulla Agrarian service centre under GGF project. And CEJ was invited to contribute to the event as resource person and conduct sessions on the above topics. Both the awareness programmes were organized for government officers in Thanamalwila and Thelula.

Luxmi is the sole #BreadWinner in her family - providing for her husband - a kidney patient, and their four daughters. Read more on how Climate Smart Agricultural practices have been a key aspect of Luxmi's farming practices. The Green Climate Fund supported Climate Resilient Integrated Water Management Project (CRIWMP) done together with the Government of Sri Lanka and United Nations Development Programme - UNDP #lka has allowed Luxmi to earn a livelihood despite the multiple crises that Sri Lanka has faced.

On November 25, 2022, IESCâ€™s EU and USAID-funded Tourism Resilience Project (TRP) in Sri Lanka trained more than 400 tourism students and employees of micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSME) on workforce readiness skills. This training is part of a series designed to update the skills of Sri Lankaâ€™s tourism workforce. The training provided an introduction to wellness tourism with a focus on communications, hygiene, and problem-solving. Through these activities, IESC is helping MSMEs retain staff, increasing the capacity of the potential tourism workforce, and encouraging new talent to join the industry in an effort to create a more resilient and sustainable tourism sector.

Fodder cultivators in Sri Lanka have faced major difficulties over the last year, including an unprecedented economic crisis and a national ban on the import of inorganic fertilizers. To help them adapt to this combination of hardships, IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project guided and mentored many cultivators to adopt organic fertilizer options to lower their fertilizer costs and maintain their businesses. An added benefit to this pivot towards more organic fertilizers is a greener practice that is better for soil health in the long run. Using a higher concentration of organic fertilizers, 13 cultivators working with MOD grew 161 hectares of fodder and increased their incomes. In the case of one cultivator, Mr. Dushmantha, his fertilizer costs fell by over 80 percent when he switched to purely organic options and the market price for his crops increased by 25 percent. Through MOD, IESC and its partners have commissioned a research study to optimize the incorporation of organic fertilizers in fodder cultivation to spread the practice, improve soil health, and increase earnings for cultivators.

As #IWD2023 month comes to an end, President of AKASA speaks on her experiences and work with UNFPA and Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to support and empower women and girls with disabilities who have experiences sexual and gender based violence. 

Findings from a landmark survey in 2019 on violence against women, by the Department of Census and Statistics, showed that 1 in 5 (20.4%) of every-partnered women in Sri Lanka have experienced physical or sexual violence by an intimate partner in their lifetime. 
Women who experienced Sexual and Gender Based Violence (SBGV) did not seek help anywhere and those experiencing SGBV had not revealed their experience to anyone based on shame. More than half of the women who face violence do not leave for fear of separation from their children.

''Several organizations express their deep concern at the risk of refoulement of an Algerian asylum seeker - Zakaria Hannache - present in Tunisia since August 2022. Tunisian authorities must under no circumstances repeat the dangerous precedent set by the kidnapping and refoulement of Algerian refugee Slimane Bouhafs on 25 August, 2021, about which no investigation has been opened to date in Tunisia.

Mr. Zakaria Hannache is an Algerian human rights defender, who has been prosecuted in Algeria since February 2022 under spurious charges, including charges of â€œapology of terrorismâ€ and â€œundermining national unityâ€, for which he faces up to 35 years in prison, solely for exercising his freedom of expression through his work publishing information and documenting the arrests of prisoners of conscience.

After spending several weeks in prison in Algeria and then being granted provisional release in March 2022, Mr. Hannache continued to be subject to significant intimidation and pressure in Algeria, following which he came to Tunisia, in August 2022. On 9 November, Mr. Hannache was informed that he was summoned to the court of Sidi M'hamed, in Algiers, for a hearing as part of his trial. The hearing was postponed indefinitely and could now be scheduled at any point.

Multiple international human rights organizations, as well as several United Nations Special Procedures, have highlighted the excessively vague nature of the Algerian Penal Code, threatening the right to a fair trial and the proper functioning of justice. Anti-terrorist legislation has notably been used arbitrarily and almost systematically since 2021 to target peaceful activists and journalists. 

read more: 

https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/joint-statement-tunisia-risk-refoulement-asylum-seeker-in-cooperation-with-algerian-authorities

What is our Maternity Kit? 
Together with Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, UNFPA Sri Lanka distributed over 3,600 maternity kits to pregnant women in 2022. 
Many pregnant women in Sri Lanka are unable to afford the basic items required when giving birth. The kits are designed to support the mother and child during birth.

"You'll come back for more", Sri Lanka Tourism's much awaited global brand and marketing communications strategy was revealed on 04 December at Cinnamon Grand Hotel.

The event was graced by the presence of the Tourism Minister, Hon. Harin Fernando, as well as other reputable guests from diplomatic missions and the tourism industry. 

The essence of the new positioning of the destination brand is succinctly captured in the new tagline and the campaign being developed brings to life how Sri Lanka offers travellers so much diversity unmatched by any other destination of its size in Asia, and once they visit the island for the first time, it casts a spell on them, pulling them back for more again!

On this International Volunteer Day, IESCâ€™s Farmer-to-Farmer (F2F) program is proud to celebrate the accomplishments of volunteer experts Gary Bloomberg and George Muruka for their tremendous work supporting Siraji SACCO, a member-owned farmer producer organization in Kenya. IESC paired Gary, from the U.S., and George, from Kenya, on a F2F volunteer assignment to combine their expertise on agriculture loan product development. Gary and George developed three new loan products tailor-made for smallholder farmers in Kenya, with a special focus on youth and women. Their efforts have helped smallholder farmers gain access to finance to grow their businesses and see long-term prosperity. George and Garyâ€™s contributions are enabling Siraji SACCO to transform into a leading agri-lender in the region, which will directly support underserved smallholder farmers.  #IVD2022 #InternationalVolunteerDay

Ananda College Old Boys' Association hosted the Olcott Oration of 2023 in memory of the yeaman services rendered by their founders. This event took place on 25 November at Kularathna Hall.

The annual Olcott Oration, a flagship event of the Ananda College Old Boys' Association (ACOBA), featured a distinguished speaker, Prof. Buddhima Indraratna, discussing "Advances in Sustainable Transportation Infrastructure" this year.

The oration, dedicated to the founders of Ananda College, honors Col. Henry Steel Olcott's contributions to Buddhism and education.

High Commissioner of the Australian High Commission for Sri Lanka H.E. Paul Stephens & UNFPA Sri Lanka opened the newly refurbished safe house and vocational training center for AKASA for women and girls with disabilities who are survivors of gender based violence. The initiative was supported by Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. 

UNFPA partnered with the Women's Development Centre (WDC) to strengthen the capacities of AKASA and the new Vocational Training Center. 
WDC provided special training to women and girls in the safe house, including small business skills development that will enhance capacity for economic generation and livelihoods.

An information session on #sustainable finance was held recently by the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP in Sri Lanka, in collaboration with the Ministry of Plantation Industries, conducted for over 80 participants including from the Ministry of Plantation Industries, Sri Lanka Tea Board, Coconut Cultivation Board, Sri Lanka Cashew Corporation and Tea Research Institute of Sri Lanka, Kithul Development Board. 

The workshop unpacked the future of Sri Lankaâ€™s plantation industry and the importance of sustainable #finance in this sector, the global sustainable finance landscape and opportunities, innovative financing options, and case studies on green and sustainable bonds in the global #plantation sector. 

UNDP looks forward to expanding on this session and exploring the next steps as part of the Global Environment Facility and Ministry of Environment project on â€˜Partnerships and Innovative Financing to Mainstream Biodiversity and Sustainable Land Management in the Wet Climatic Zone of Sri Lankaâ€™

Front Line Defenders board member Roja Fazaeli reads out a moving testimony from Iranian WHRD Atena Daemi at the closing of the #DublinPlatform. 

Atena has been judicially harassed in Iran for many years - first arrested in 2014 and kept in solitary confinement. She has been physically and emotionally abused while in prison. Read more about Atena here: https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/profile/atena-daemi 

Despite everything that Atena has gone through, she remains steadfast in fighting for change in Iran. Now, an important moment in Iran's history, she called on us to stand by Iranians as they face resistance in the face of fighting for essential change.

"South and North fisher leaders with considerable cooperative experience got together in search of collaborative strategies to overcome challenges to livelihoods due to the prevailing economic crisis".
 
Law and Society Trust together with Academics from the University of Jaffna and fisher leaders from Northern and Southern initiated a discussion to identify prospective solutions to address the common issues faced by North and South fisheries. 
The event took place from the 27th to the 28th of January 2023 across Poneryn, Karainagar, and Jaffna with over fifteen North and South fisher leaders.

Front Line Defenders welcomes over 100 human rights defenders from all over the world to Dublin this week, for the 2022 Dublin Platform for human rights defenders at risk. Established in 2002, the Dublin Platform for Human Rights Defenders is a biennial event providing a truly unique opportunity for human rights defenders from almost every country in the world to gather in Dublin. Over 3 days in Dublin Castle, HRDs share strategies for advocacy and protection, build solidarity with colleagues around the world, and network with high-level decision makers from governmental and intergovernmental bodies. 

A unique space for HRDs to share, connect, and strategise. Keep an eye on our pages!

The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program, together with USAID/Georgiaâ€™s Economic Growth Office Director Marika Olson, officially launched a new partnership with Georgian digital marketing company Sweeft to establish a short-term skills development program. With support from the Program, Sweeft will address the needs of software development and digital service markets by developing an accelerated internship program comprised of 20 new and improved short-term professional skills training programs focused on technical and soft skills in great demand by the ICT sector.

COVID 19 is challenging for women across. Some have lost livelihoods, some victims of domestic violence, some suffer from social distancing & loneliness, some with anxiety of their future. We are here to help. To listen to you, to support you and to guide you better manage the crisis situation. This service is offered free to our women in need. Tomato farming opened the door to greater profits for one youth group in Tanzania. With volunteer support through IESCâ€™s Farmer-to-Farmer program, the Sasa Kazi youth group learned about tomato cultivation and soil health management, and decided to make the switch from maize and bean farming to tomato farming. This year alone, the youth have earned over $7,800 in profits from their tomato crops. Read more about their transformation here: http://ow.ly/MhUy50LR4w9

text: Through the USDA-funded Tradeâ€“Facilitating Agricultural Systems and Technology (Proyecto T-FAST) project in Paraguay, IESC has been working with Paraguayâ€™s National Vegetable and Seed Health Service (SENAVE) to reengineer its processes to increase efficiency. As part of this technical assistance, IESC and SENAVE are conducting a series of 11 workshops to identify opportunities for improvement related to registration of national and international laboratories; registration of plant protection products; fertilizer registration; collection, shipment, and testing of plant and chemical samples; and issuance of plant transit documents. With IESC's support, the review and restructuring of SENAVEâ€™s Strategic Institutional Plan will set the stage for SENAVE to contribute to improved trade facilitation. #SENAVE #USDA #TFAST

text:
Interested in abortion rights?

Join us at the Dublin Arts and Human Rights Festival on the 18th October at 7pm online - My Body My Choice: Abortion Rights Activism Across the Globe.

 The Repeal movement was one of the most important political and social movements in Irish history. It involved tens of thousands of activists from every corner of the island making the case for women to be allowed to make decisions for themselves, about their own bodies, their own health and well-being.

As we enter the final stages of the Governmentâ€™s Abortion Review, we want to explore the challenges that remain since Repeal and hear how the struggle to widen access across the island of Ireland is part of a global movement for women and pregnant peopleâ€™s reproductive rights.

Join us to hear from brave human rights defenders who are persecuted for their work on abortion access in Poland. Join us to learn how you can be part of the campaign for abortion rights at home.

This event features guest speakers Ailbhe Smyth,  Emma Campbell and Justyna WydrzyÅ„ska. Ailbhe Smyth is  long-time feminist,  LGBTQ+ campaigner and the former founding head of Womenâ€™s Studies at UCD. Ailbhe co-founded and led the Coalition to Repeal the 8th, and was co-Director of Together for Yes, the national Civil Society Campaign to remove the 8th Amendment from the Irish constitution. Emma is co-convenor of Alliance for Choice and a core campaigner since 2011, helping secure decriminalisation of abortion as a part of the movement. 

Justyna WydrzyÅ„ska is woman human rights defender and founder of the website Women on the Net, Polandâ€™s first online forum supporting women seeking safe abortions, contraception or sex education. She currently works with Abortion Dream Team (ADT), a grass roots initiative of four women human rights defenders who came together in October 2016 with the goal of providing direct and immediate assistance to women who needed abortions. 

Register here:
https://smashingtimes.ie/event/the-struggle-for-abortion-rights-in-ireland-and-internationally/

Yesterday (11/07/2023) CEJ joined hands with "Ayithiya Udhesa Api" an organization in Kandy comprised of physically challenged  people, to promote agroecology under the financial assistance of GGF. The main focus of this project is to support the environmental work of physically challenged people, related to climate change mitigation, efficient land use, and agriculture. During this interaction, they shared their frustration over people seeing them as "incapable people" and giving them money disregarding their dignity. They appreciated CEJ for seeing them as an able group and inducing them to think differently. They also offered their assistance and fullest cooperation in CEJ's environmental struggles. Ms. Nisha Sharif and her team organized the event while Ms. Hasangi Senevirathne assisted participants as the sign language translator. The participants comprised of people with speech, hearing and locomotion disabilities as well as guardians of disabled people.

Joint Statement: We urge the UN Human Rights Council  to hold a special session on Iran urgently - to independently investigate, report and hold accountable the grave violations of human rights under international law amidst protests and crackdowns on WHRDs. 

The recent protests were sparked by outrage at the death in custody of Mahsa (Jina) Amini, a 22 year old woman from the Kurdish minority, on 16 September 2022 days after being arrested by the "morality" police for not complying with the country's discriminatory and abusive compulsory veiling laws, which perpetuate violence against women and girls in Iran and strip them of their right to dignity and bodily autonomy. The focus of the protests has since quickly expanded to broader grievances and encompassed demands for fundamental political and social change towards protection and fulfillment of human rights. 

The United Nations Human Rights Council should act as a matter of urgency by holding a special session and -- given the gravity of crimes under international law and other serious human rights violations committed in Iran and the prevailing systemic impunity -- establish an independent, investigative, reporting and accountability mechanism. 

https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/joint-statment-iran-un-human-rights-council-must-hold-special-session-on-iran

IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Trade Safe (TraSa) project in the Dominican Republic held a post-harvest and cold chain workshop with ProDominicana in Santiago for agricultural producers, packers, merchants, and other actors in the production chain. IESC and ProDominicana delivered training on legal standards and best practices in pre-harvest, harvest, and post-harvest, as well as food safety and cold chain management. Workshops like these build capacity for each stage of perishable goods processing to help ensure the cold chain is maintained from harvest through export. Front Line Defenders is deeply concerned about the two-year detention, conviction and judicial harassment of the human rights defender Tony Germain Nkina. We believe that he is being targeted solely as a result of his past peaceful and legitimate work in defence of human rights.

13 October 2022 marks two years of his detention. On 13 October 2020, he was arrested without a warrant in Kabarore where he was visiting a client for his professional work as a lawyer.

Tony Nkina is a well known human rights lawyer in Kayanza province who provides legal assistance to detained persons and victims of human rights abuses. He is the former representative of the Association for the Protection of Human Rights and Detained Persons (Association pour la protection des droits humains et des personnes dÃ©tenues, APRODH), a leading human rights group in Burundi until 2015. In 2015 the government suspended the organization as part of a crackdown on independent civil society.

In June 2021, a court in Kayanza found Tony Nkina guilty of collaboration with armed groups â€“ a common accusation against perceived opponents and critics in Burundi â€“ and sentenced him to five years in prison. The human rights defenderâ€™s lawyer immediately filed an appeal the Court of Appeal of Ngozi on 16 July 2021. His lawyer reports that Tony Germain Nkina was questioned regarding APRODH. The human rights defender and lawyer was found guilty of complicity with armed groups and sentenced to five yearsâ€™ imprisonment and a fine of one million Burundian francs. 

 Front Line Defenders call on the Burundian authorities to quash the sentence upheld by the appeal court of Ngozi and unconditionally release Tony Germain Nkina. We  encourage the Burundian authorities to guarantee in all circumstances that all human rights defenders in Burundi are able to carry out their legitimate human rights activities without fear of reprisals and free of all restrictions.

This Global Entrepreneurship Week, IESC highlights the USAID-funded youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLeadâ€™s, completion of 276 separate village-level Entrepreneurship Development training programs in collaboration with the Department of Samurdhi Development, Sri Lanka's poverty alleviation agency. The programs reached 13,647 micro and small business owners, providing them with entrepreneurship skills and enabling them to launch or improve their businesses.
 
"With COVID related travel restrictions, I realized that I had to build my customer base online," says Ayo Fashions' owner, 31-year-old Gayani, a determined young micro entrepreneur from Padiyathalawa. Gayani was one of the participants who attended the Entrepreneurship Development (ED) training sessions, which focused on self-employment and microenterprise development. After two years, Gayani wanted to take her business to the next level and improve her understanding of costing, financial management, branding, and marketing, prompting her to enroll in YouLead's ED training program. After completing her training, Gayani registered her business and sourced clothing tags with the brand name. The training provided her with tips and tools to improve her online presence and marketing efforts. As a result, Gayani's micro-business thrived despite COVID and Sri Lanka's socio-economic upheaval.

Global Entrepreneurship Week celebrates and empowers entrepreneurs around the world â€“ especially those individuals who face structural barriers. Through the ED training sessions, IESC supported micro-business owners like Gayani. As a result, they push the boundaries of conventional business thinking, adopt new skills to meet current economic challenges, and are better equipped to sustain their businesses in the long term. YouLead recognizes the importance of developing rural women entrepreneurs and the vital role they can play in uplifting their families and contributing to the national economy. #GEW2022

The Dublin Arts and Human Rights Festival launches this Friday, 14th October:

The Dublin Arts and Human Rights Festival is an annual, international festival organised by Smashing Times International Centre for the Arts and Equality and Front Line Defenders. This yearâ€™s festival runs from the 14 â€“ 23 October, with the theme â€˜In Solidarity: A Celebration of Human Rightsâ€™.

The festival aims to promote human rights and justice for all, and the vision of a world where all people are treated equally, with dignity and respect â€“ linking the arts to civil society, active citizenship and politics. The extraordinary work of human rights defenders in Ireland and around the world, past and present, and the role of the arts in promoting human rights will be showcased and highlighted at the festival, aiming to celebrate and unite community connections, artists, human rights organisations and human rights defenders.

The festival will showcase world-class and diverse acts, artists and speakers, including up and coming performers. It brings arts and human rights together through interdisciplinary events which include workshops, theatre performances, musical performances, visual arts, exhibitions, film screenings, panel discussions, poetry and literature events, historical memory performances, live art, digital installations, and more. 

See the full program here and book your tickets early!

https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/campaign/dublin-arts-human-rights-festival-2022

Job Description:

- Create captivating content that aligns seamlessly with the distinctive branding of Mogo Games and Mogo Studios.
- Monitor and respond to audience inquiries.

- Minimum 1-year experience in social media management and content writing.
- Proficiency in various social media platforms (LinkedIn, Facebook, Instagram, YouTube, TikTok).
- Ability to multitask and collaborate effectively with multiple teams.
- Excellent command of English with strong communication skills.
- Knowledge of Canva, Adobe Premiere, Photoshop, or similar editing software is an advantage.
- Ability to work in a fast-paced environment with meticulous attention to detail.

Send us your resume and a brief introduction to games@mogo.lk. Feel free to showcase your creativity by including samples of your social media, and especially LinkedIn, content!

From October 21 â€“ 28, IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project worked with its partners at the University of Florida (UF) to bring 12 large dairy farm owners and managers and two government officials from Sri Lanka to visit five large dairy farms in Florida and Georgia, including UFâ€™s research farm. The participants were able to observe the farms in action and speak with the owners about strategies for overcoming challenges as well as best practices related to cow comfort, nutrition, and herd management. IESC will support participants in implementing their key takeaways from the trip to increase milk production and strengthen their businesses. The participants also plan to share these best practices with other dairy entrepreneurs in Sri Lanka. #GEW2022

David and Goliath: Front line communities challenging corporate abuse:

Join us at this exclusive event at the Dublin Arts and Human Rights Festival.

Land grabs, violent evictions, widespread deforestation and destruction of biodiversity, poor working conditions and more, are just some of the negative impacts of corporate abuse-  companies operating with impunity for their human rights violations â€“ companies that grow and process products that we use everyday in Ireland.

Communities around the world are on the front lines of challenging these companies, but sadly, human rights defenders that dare to speak out on these harmful practices risk dangerous retaliation, harassment, threats, attacks and criminalisation, and even murder.

At this event, two international guests â€“ women human rights defenders Grecia Eugenia RodrÃ­guez Navarro from Mexico, and Bidya Shrestha Maharjan from Nepal -will share the realities of what it is like challenging corporate abuse on the ground. Both are working hard to expose, and prevent, corporate-related human rights abuse in their communities, and have faced backlash for their defence of human rights. The event will also include an exclusive screening of the new TrÃ³caire Documentary â€˜Make It Your Businessâ€™ â€“ a new short documentary which goes on a journey to explore corporate accountability, meeting experts and human rights activists on the front lines of corporate exploitation and abuse, and how we might improve on this in future. To tackle these injustices, the documentary also explores how we might realise a better future by bringing in new 
rules to protect people and planet, and how ordinary people can stand up and take action.

People are vulnerable to increasing environmental pollution and unprecedented economic changes in countries like Sri Lanka. Development projects such as coal power plants have exaggerated the vulnerability of the communities to the threats of environmental pollution coupled with economic crises. This study is to present the concurrent socio-environmental issues related to the largest power plant in Sri Lankaâ€”the Norochcholai coal power plant (NCPP).

On November 9, IESCâ€™s USAID-funded LinkSME project in Vietnam and the Agency for Enterprise Development (AED) organized a training session for business support organizations (BSOs) on evaluating the capacity of small and medium enterprises (SMEs). Thirty participants from ten BSOs learned how to utilize SME assessment-and-auditing tools and handbooks developed by the project and AED, thereby enabling BSOs to confidently identify and introduce an increasing number of qualified SMEs to lead firms as potential suppliers. This kind of training helps BSOs support SMEs without project assistance, leading to a more sustainable supporting environment.

#StoriesOfResettlement: After returning to Batticaloa in 2006, Kokila Devi resettled armed with an MBA in Human Resources from India. However, her plans for a good job opportunity were quashed when she was told she was overqualified by all potential employers. She then turned to her childhood dream of making her own spices. With help from UNDPs SDR programme she was able to get machines to help start up her business 'Naga Pasumai Masala'. She now runs a successful business and received the 'Best Women Entrepreneur' Award and the 'Best Industrialist Award for her efforts. In the next 5 years, she aims to export products and have a factory for her growing venture. 

The Support for Durable Resettlement (SDR) Project supports the resettlement of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and refugee returnees, providing them with durable resettlement opportunities including access to essential basic services, sustainable livelihoods and income generation opportunities.

The SDR Project is implemented by the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP in Sri Lanka together with the Government of Sri Lanka, with funding from the British High Commission Colombo, across 4 Districts in #Jaffna, #Kilinochchi, #Mullaitivu and #Trincomalee.
