Housing as a Human Right: Stories from the front line 

Housing precariousness has reached an unprecedented scale and worldwide housing is rarely treated as a human right. On the contrary, those people organising and acting to defend and promote this right are often targeted with criminal lawsuits, defamation campaigns and physical attacks.

At this event, we talk to activists at the forefront of housing movements around the world, hear about the obstacles they are facing and the strategies they are using to advance housing rights. 

Panelists include human rights defenders from Cote Dâ€™Ivoire, Cape Town, South Africa and Brazil. Yvonne Toba, Cote Dâ€™Ivoire is a human rights defender who is well known for her work denouncing corruption, bad governance, impunity and social injustice and is the National Coordinator of Novox Cote dâ€™Ivoire, an organization raising the voice of the voiceless in Cote dâ€™Ivoire by promoting an equal access to justice. Buhle Booi, South Africa,  is the head of political organising at Ndifuna Ukwazi,  an activist organisation and law centre that advocates for access to well-located land and affordable housing for poor and working class families, communities and social movements.  Camila Santos, Brazil, is a woman human rights defender born in a place known as Grota, in the group of favelas that make up the Complexo do AlemÃ£o. She is one of the leaders of the fight for housing in the AlemÃ£o complex and started to give voice to 1,300 families. In 2015, based on the actions she was already carrying out and the demands of women who arrived, Camila established the collective Women in Action in AlemÃ£o (MEAA). Camila was 2021 Front Line Defenderâ€™s Award Winner for the Americas.

The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program officially launched a new partnership with Geo Hospitals, a network of 15 inpatient and 10 outpatient facilities in five regions of Georgia employing over 1,350 doctors and 1,000 nurses. The partnership aims to establish a sustainable postgraduate nursing education system in the Kvemo Kartli and Kakheti regions. This will be achieved by replicating successful specialized training programs that will serve as a basis for upscaling continuous nursing education programs in two of Geo Hospitals' new regional training centers. The focus will be on specialties in high demand from the healthcare industry. The Program was thrilled to host Erin McKee, the Assistant Administrator in USAIDâ€™s Bureau for Europe and Eurasia, at the grant signing event with Geo Hospitals.

text:
ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡· #Iran

Joint Statement: we demand an end to the deliberate violence, arrest, threats, and charges against Iranian human rights defenders, journalists, student activists and civil rights actors, especially amongst minority ethnic groups.

Since 18 September 2022, over fifty human rights defenders, in addition to journalists and student activists, have been arrested and arbitrarily detained, some already charged with "acting against national security". The death toll around the country is estimated to have gone beyond one hundred according to some human rights organisations and media outlets. According to the Baloch Activists Campaign on 1 October 2022, at least sixty seven protesters have been killed only in Zahedan, Balouchestan province. The arrests and attacks appear to be aimed at punishing and silencing those protesting for human rights, especially womenâ€™s rights, and accountability for the death in Morality Police custody of a 22-year-old young woman, Mahsa (Jina) Amini, while enforcing the countryâ€™s discriminatory forced veiling laws. In response to this, several human rights groups have called for the Iranian police and authorities to be held accountable. 

#IranRevolution

Read more:

https://frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/joint-statement-iran-alarm-over-mass-arrests-human-rights-defenders-amidst-protests

Traceability in the supply chain is becoming essential to ensuring compliance with both international trade requirements and the standards of many buyers in global supply chains. This facet of doing business is rapidly becoming just as important as scale, quality, and quantity with these buyers. Through these events, USAID LinkSME is helping to make SMEs more competitive.

The rapidly changing environment in Sri Lanka requires that farmers adopt new practices and techniques to manage risks and increase production, becoming more resilient in the face of climate change. IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project partnered with the Department of Animal Production and Health (DAPH) and the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) to develop a Climate-Smart Dairy model for medium-scale dairy farms in Sri Lanka. The model, which focuses on low-carbon milk production, emission management, and capacity building, was well received during a two-day workshop. In partnership with MOD and IESC, DAPH will take the lead in piloting the proposed model on 20 to 50 farms to ensure its sustainability beyond the life of the project. #climatesmartag #climateresilience

With the support of IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Trade Safe (TraSa) project in the Dominican Republic, a delegation of Dominican border agents participated in an observation tour of customs facilities in Miami, FL and Laredo, TX. Led by partner the World Food Logistics Organization (WFLO), the objective of the tour was to observe the inspection systems and cold chain processing of two major points of entry for perishable goods in the U.S.: Miami International Airport and the border crossing in Laredo, Texas. IESCâ€™s TraSa project sponsored inspectors and supervisors from the Ministry of Industry, Commerce, and MSMEs; Special Port Security Unit (CESEP); Customs; Department of Plant Health; Department of Animal Health; the National Institute of Traffic and Land Transport (INTRANT); Special Airport and Aviation Security Unit (CESAC); Special Land Border Security Unit (CESFRONT); and General Directorate of Medicines, Food, and Health Products (DIGEMAPS) on this tour. With IESC's support, Dominican inspection units are implementing cold chain solutions to improve food quality and safety for consumers during customs processing. #ProyectoTraSa #ProyectoTradeSafe #TraSa #TradeSafe Proyecto Trade Safe

text: On October 14th, 2022, USAIDâ€™s youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, in partnership with Gamma Pizzakraft Lanka (the owner of the Pizza Hut franchise in Sri Lanka) and the Sevalanka Foundation, celebrated the official launch of the first vocational training kitchen, opened at the Technical College in Kuliyapitiya. This training kitchen is the first under the â€˜An Equal Slice for Everyoneâ€™ initiative, which is funded by a $1.3 million grant from the Yum! Brands Foundation. Through this public private partnership, the initiative will build 28 vocational training kitchens at training centers across Sri Lanka, with two centers dedicated to training youth with disabilities. The program will train more than 2,100 youth annually for a career in the quick service restaurant industry. Upon successful completion of a six-month course, which includes on-the-job training, students will receive a National Vocational Qualification Level 3 certification. IESC will assist in the development of new curricula aligned to global industry best practices, provide training for vocational instructors, and certify learning outcomes. This initiative will not only employ youth and help fund vocational training, but also ensure the training is sustainable and aligned with employer needs.

In Sri Lanka, one of the most challenging inputs for dairy farmers to find is quality and affordable feed for their cows, a crucial ingredient in boosting milk production. The recent removal of government subsidies made chemical fertilizers one of the most expensive inputs for fodder production in Sri Lanka, impacting the entire agriculture sector. To help ease the effect of this added expense on fodder cultivators, IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project is launching an applied research collaboration with nine local public and private sector partners. This collaboration will help find effective microorganisms and vermitea technology to reduce chemical fertilizer use in fodder cultivation while maintaining quality crop yields and soil health.

#Palestinian HRD Salah Hammouri is being detained in solitary confinement in inhumane conditions - he is in poor health due to enduring a hunger strike, while enduring conditions which worsen his condition. Reports have indicated that conditions in cell are as follows:

â€¢ The cell is dirty
â€¢ No air ventilation. Vent-hole is blocked
â€¢ Cell is 2x3 square meters
â€¢ Metal bed with a 2 cm mattress 
â€¢ A primitive toilet in the room
â€¢ No shower in room
â€¢ No windows (no sunlight)
â€¢ Small yellow bulb. 

Punitive measures infringed by Israeli prison administration due to hunger strike:

â€¢ Deprivation of salt intake
â€¢ Handcuffs on during shower
â€¢ Deprivation of personal belongings, including family and children photos, books and note books.
â€¢ Total deprivation of outdoor time since 28 September
â€¢ No clean underwear
â€¢ Deprivation of monthly family visit
â€¢ Subjection to punitive fees 

We call for his immediate release and to end his solitary confinement immediately:

Application update!! 

Issues updating your application:
1. Follow the step by step guide given in this link - https://www.unfpa.org/sites/default/files/resource-pdf/Quantum%20-%20External%20Application%20Guide%20August%202022%20.pdf 
2. Use an Incognito Browser to prepare the application - https://www.computerworld.com/article/3356840/how-to-go-incognito-in-chrome-firefox-safari-and-edge.html 
3. Clear browser cookies. 
a. Chrome - https://support.google.com/accounts/answer/32050?hl=en&co=GENIE.Platform%3DDesktop
b. Microsoft Edge - https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/delete-cookies-in-microsoft-edge-63947406-40ac-c3b8-57b9-2a946a29ae09
c. Apple Mac - https://support.apple.com/en-lk/guide/safari/sfri11471/mac
4. When preparing the application, save it from time to time. 
5. Make sure to attach a Cover Letter and an updated CV customized to the position. Ensure that you add the dates of employment and qualifications, names and details of employers and academic institutions etc. Please provide details of 4 referees, together with the application. 
6. If the technical issue is not resolved, please call 074-1176752, or email lk-hr@unfpa.org.

âœ… Defining territories and understanding environmental struggles.

âœ… Understanding the judicial systems in Sri Lanka. 
âœ… Developing a rapid response system for defense. 
âœ… Role of men and women in campaigning. 
âœ… Networking and campaigning for environmental issues.

Women's Participation in Politics, Business, Education, Administration, etc must be encouraged. But this needs to be done systematically and strategically by empowering women. Creation of spaces for women if done haphazardly will result in women "breaking the glass ceiling" yet failing to "navigate the glass cliff". This ultimately results in more labels against women further curtailing their space and opportunity. We need to have "right women at right places". 

With the pressure from governments, International Organisations, SDGs, availability of recognition and funding for women's movement many organisations and institutions pay lip service to the rightful empowerment and promotion of women. This rather helping them, does a larger damage. 

#Gender #glasscliff #glassceiling #empowe #women

Susil Sirivardana (1938-2021)

We are saddened by the loss of Mr Susil Sirivardana. His passion,  commitment and contribution to poverty alleviation and housing programmes as well as his pursuit of participatory, pro poor development approaches have left a mark in Sri Lanka. We at CEPA are grateful for the opportunities we had to interact with Mr Sirivardana. We had the opportunity to learn from his vast experience, and at times he would push us and encourage us to take action. His support  for our work especially on issues related to urban poverty and housing is much valued. 

We offer our condolences to his family and colleagues.

Global Legal Action Network and Front Line Defenders are deeply concerned over the repeated targeting of human rights defenders resisting destructive private luxury tourism developments in Barbuda. A group of human right defenders inspecting one of the contested construction sites on the island have been charged with unlawful trespass. Their hearing, where they could potentially face criminal charges, is set to happen on 29 September 2022.

One of the most effective tools IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project in Sri Lanka employs is Farmer Group Discussions. These discussions allow a lead farmer to share their experience in applying a particular best practice with other farmers to relay the benefits they have experienced from implementation. After attending a Farmer Group Discussion on total mixed ration (TMR) feeding, Ms. Seetharanjini was convinced to apply the practice on her farm. With IESCâ€™s support, she has doubled her milk production from 6 to 12 liters per day since doing so.

Despite evidence on the impacts of waste-to-energy incinerators on health, climate, and the environment, governments and International Financial Institutions (IFIs) continue to finance and support waste-to-energy projects. 

It's time for governments and IFIs to STOP investing in this false solution to plastic pollution and the climate crisis. 

Investments should go to real and effective solutions such as REUSE and ZERO WASTE systems.

ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡¾ #Belarus

On 22 September 2022, Frunze District Court in Misnk sentenced woman human rights defender Nasta Loika to another 15 days administrative arrest on â€œpetty hooliganismâ€ charges, a violation under Article 19.1 of the Code of Administrative Offences. On 21 September 2022, her colleagues reported that she was not released from detention. On 7 September 2022, Nasta Loika was already sentenced to 15 days of administrative arrest on the same charges.

Nasta Loika is a prominent Belarusian WHRD working in the field of human rights education. She also addresess repressive â€œanti-extremistâ€ laws, and advocates for the protection of the migrants and stateless people rights in Belarus. In the summer of 2021, Belarusian authorities shut down the organisation where Nasta Loika previously worked for - Human Constanta - which promoted public interests and joint actions in response to modern challenges in the field of human rights, as a part of an orchestrated attack against the civil society in the country.

On 22 September 2022, Frunze District Court in Misnk sentenced Nasta Loika to another 15-days administrative arrest on â€œpetty hooliganismâ€ charges. She was not present in court, and did not have access to her lawyer, as the court denied the motion to invite  attorney. The only person who was invited to be present during the hearing was a law enforcement officer. According to his testimony, the law enforcement officers were informed about Nasta Loikaâ€™s participation in public protests and they needed to question her about her involvement.

Front Line Defenders is gravely concerned about the lack of information on the whereabouts of woman human rights defender Nasta Loika and calls upon the Belarusian authorities to immediately release her from detention. Front Line Defenders believes that the woman human rights defender is being repeatedly targeted for her peaceful human rights work. Her earlier arrest is part of the increasing attacks against Belarus's human rights defenders and civil society by Belarusian authorities.  

https://frontlinedefenders.org/en/case/woman-human-rights-defender-nasta-loika-sentenced-another-15-days-administrative-arrest

Curious to know what IESCâ€™s Farmer-to-Farmer (F2F) program has accomplished in the past 2+ years? F2F has been providing support to agricultural organizations abroad through a paired remote volunteer model, matching up a U.S.-based volunteer expert and one national volunteer expert to take on a short-term assignment. IESCâ€™s F2F focus on increasing access to finance in Kenya, Tanzania, and Sri Lanka has allowed many women and youth farmers to obtain financing to strengthen their livelihoods. Watch the video to learn more about one assignment completed by U.S. volunteer expert Katherine Cassidy and Tanzania volunteer expert Ernest Jerome, who worked with a microfinance institution in Zanzibar that provides loans, particularly to women and smallholder farmers. http://ow.ly/H90o50KXg6B #F2F

International Human Rights Day 2022
Dignity, Freedom, and Justice for All

Dr. Sakuntala Kadirgamar
Executive Director
Law and Society Trust

Today, the 10th of December is Human Rights Day and today, as in the past the United Nations, governments, and civil society the world over will commemorate it.

the theme is the danger that we make ritual commemorations and as the day passes, everyone forgets about making this a living reality.

This year, the theme focuses on Dignity, Freedom, and Justice for all and we must ask ourselves what these words mean to us in Sri Lanka today.

Our economy and society have been ravaged by covid and an economic crisis that has thrown many people into poverty and the prospects of recovery are uncertain if not bleak. Our government is focusing on balancing the books and on economic indicators but less attention is paid to human development indicators. There is a rise in malnutrition, food insecurity, and the prospects of children ruined through disruptions in education.

Covid has provided the cover for governments the world over to clamp down on civil rights, freedoms of movement, association, and even free speech where people criticized government responses to covid.

In Sri Lanka, we continue to struggle against the Prevention of Terrorism Act â€“ a draconian law enabling arbitrary arrests and detention for alleged terrorist activities that are vaguely defined. It has been arbitrarily used against minorities and is now expanded for use against political opponents of governments.

Justice for all remains elusive in Sri Lanka where the Rule of Law does not operate. Those with political power and patronage enjoy impunity and are not held accountable for corruption, abuse of power, and even murder. Post-war claims for accountability for war crimes, information on missing persons, and restitution of lands and livelihoods remain unaddressed.

We must ask ourselves: Are we committed to ensuring Dignity, Freedom, and Justice for All in the coming year or will this be another ritual commemoration?

This event connected 100 SMEs in the supporting industries sector to 20 foreign investors and international lead firms and facilitated 200 meetings both online and on-site. The promise of potential international linkages will spur participating SMEs to improve their production processes to meet the quantity, quality, and consistency demands of lead firms, thereby increasing both their competitiveness and the likelihood of increasing Vietnamese SMEsâ€™ participation in the global economy.

More than 11 years on from his brutal arrest and 9 years after the WGAD opinion, Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja remains behind bars in Jau prison in Bahrain. 

In a January 2021 phone call, the human rights defender listed four concerns including that prison authorities had placed restrictions on his phone calls with family (that have replaced their in-person visits) and had confiscated hundreds of his books and other materials. The defender continues to suffer from chronic pain as a result of the mistreatment he endured in the early days of his detention, and requires additional medical intervention as his facial bone structure remains permanently damaged. Prison authorities continue to arbitrarily deny him adequate healthcare and refuse to refer him to specialists for the surgeries he requires. Denying a prisoner needed medical care violates the United Nations Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners, known as the Nelson Mandela Rules. 

We urgently call on the #Bahrain government to #FreeAlKhawaja and support the call of the Danish government to free him immediately.

On September 15, 2022, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperationâ€™s (SDC) Skilled and Resilient Migrant Workers project (SRMW), implemented by IESC, held a public-private dialogue on building a more skilled migrant workforce in Sri Lanka. The dialogue included a group of 32 stakeholders, including relevant government and ministry representatives, donor agencies, training institutions, employment agencies, and non-governmental and multilateral development partners. the dialogue challenged them to come together to support prospective migrant workers with better information and skills. As priority next steps, the dialogue identified the need to strengthen skills certification through the recognition of prior learning (RPL) process, to implement key policy recommendations related to increasing skilled labor migration, and to improve soft skills training opportunities. IESC will hold focused workshops on these areas to develop rapid interventions with stakeholders for implementation. The goals for this collaboration are to improve the quality of and access to information, occupational guidance, and opportunities for skills development for prospective migrant workers in a timely manner, in order to minimize negative impacts and maximize the positive impacts of overseas work. Achieving these goals will ensure that when overseas migrant workers return to Sri Lanka, they do so with skills and knowledge that will contribute to the countryâ€™s continued growth. 

Pictured here, Mr. R. P. A. Wimalaweera, Secretary to the Ministry of Labor and Foreign Employment, is making opening remarks at the dialogue.

Former Middle East and North Africa (MENA) Protection Coordinator for Front Line Defenders, former President of the Bahrain Centre for Human Rights (BCHR) and co-founder of Gulf Centre for Human Rights (GCHR), Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja has a long history of working to promote human rights in the MENA region and championing the protection of human rights defenders at risk. 

In February 2011 protests and demonstrations broke out across Bahrain calling for greater political freedoms. As part of the governmentâ€™s crackdown on these protests, opposition leaders and leading human rights defenders, including Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja were arrested. 

On 9 April 2011, up to twenty armed and masked policemen broke into the Al-Khawaja family home in the middle of the night, dragged Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja down the stairs even though he agreed to go peacefully, and extensively beat him, including repeatedly kicking his head. Following his arrest he required a 4 hour surgery on his face and jaw, injuries that continue to cause him pain 10 years on.

On 22 June 2011, Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja was sentenced to life imprisonment on charges of â€œorganising and managing a terrorist organisationâ€, â€œattempts to overthrow the government by force and in liaison with a terrorist organisation working for a foreign countryâ€ and the â€œcollection of money for a terrorist groupâ€ .

To this day he remains in prison.

Abdul-Hadi Al-Khawaja is a dual Danish-Bahraini citizen, and one of the most prominent democracy and human rights defenders in the Gulf region. Over three decades, he has fought peacefully for social justice, human rights, and pro-democratic changes in Bahrain. He is the co-founder and former director of several human rights organizations, and he has received numerous awards for his activism and work.  
 
In 2011, Al-Khawaja was sentenced to life in prison for his involvement in peaceful protests in Bahrain. During his arrest and time in prison, Al-Khawaja has been brutally tortured and subjected to solitary confinement. As a result of his treatment, Al-Khawaja is in dire need of medical attention and rehabilitation. As of this moment, Al-Khawaja is being denied all access to medical treatment and weâ€™re very worried about his health.

IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Trade Safe (TraSa) project (Proyecto Trade Safe) held the first graduation ceremony for our food safety training program in San Juan de la Maguana, Dominican Republic. Together with local partner CEDAF and family-owned P&T Valley Farms, IESC celebrated 22 producers for completing their first farmer field school (FFS) in Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA) readiness training. This training program ensures the fresh produce exported from DR follows health and food safety regulations required for entrance into US markets through the Produce Safety Alliance (PSA) Grower Training Course. 

Grower Juan Sanchez expressed the following as a result of his participation in the FFS: â€œAt the Farmer Field School, we learned about the importance of knowing and respecting the pesticide application/harvest intervals for the safety of the consumers of our vegetables. We used to apply pesticides even up to the day before harvest! Now we understand that the type, amount, and when we apply pesticides is critical from a food safety and environmental protection standpoint.â€ 

Following the FFS, P&T Valley Farms saw a 68% increase in the FSMA Produce Safety Rule knowledge of their producers.

#storiesofresettlement: Jeevanandhan, after resettling in 2016 in Sri Lanka, began selling fish on a bicycle to support his family. Through the SDR Project, he and a few others from the village were selected as beneficiaries to undergo training on developing their businesses. Idhaya Rasa was another #fisherman who benefited from the project. He and 23 other families were provided with fishing boats and nets to further their #livelihoods. 

The Support for Durable Resettlement (SDR) Project supports the resettlement of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and refugee returnees, providing them with durable resettlement opportunities including access to essential basic services, #sustainable livelihoods and income generation opportunities. 

The SDR Project is implemented by the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP in Sri Lanka together with the Government of Sri Lanka, with funding from the High Commission of Canada to Sri Lanka and Maldives, across 4 Districts in #Jaffna, #Kilinochchi, #Mullaitivu and #Trincomalee.

The Organization of American States/Inter-American Committee against Terrorism (CICTE) asked IESCâ€™s USDA-funded T-FAST project (Proyecto T-FAST) to present their joint results, achieved with Paraguayâ€™s public and private sectors, in advancing the Authorized Economic Operator (AEO) program, which recently became the AEO Country program (OEA PaÃ­s in Spanish).

At the training, international experts shared experiences and encouraged the coordination and cooperation of strategic, safe, resilient, and reliable trade through the implementation of the World Customs Organization's and AEO program's Standards to Secure and Facilitate Trade (SAFE) Framework. Additional information regarding Paraguayâ€™s AEO Country Program was shared, which includes buy-in from the five main agricultural trade regulators to adopt the program: the Ministry of Industry and Commerce (MIC) in December 2020; the National Anti-Narcotics Secretariat (SENAD) in December 2021; National Plant and Seed Quality and Health Service (SENAVE) in March 2022; National Institute of Food and Nutrition (INAN) in July 2022; and National Directorate of Health Surveillance (DINAVISA) in July 2022. Each of these institutions formally committed to giving detailed preferences to AEO-certified businesses, including guaranteeing that 95 percent of their goods pass through the faster green channel for inspections compared to the overall average of only 34 percent of goods passing through green channel. 

Since the creation of the OEA PaÃ­s program with IESC's support in 2020, several cooperation agencies, such as the European Union (EU), United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), Global Alliance for Trade Facilitation (GATF), and Organization of American States (OAS), have expressed great interest in replicating Paraguayâ€™s successes in other regional countries.

With support from IESCâ€™s USDA-funded T-FAST project (Proyecto T-FAST) in Paraguay, the Digitalization of the Foreign Trade Single Window (DIGIVUCE) officially became the fourth National Trade Facilitation Committee (NTFC) working group, with the mission of digitizing, integrating, and simplifying import and export processes and procedures to develop internal and external communication and information mechanisms that will allow it to act quickly and transparently, establishing adequate internal coordination and permanent dialogue with key foreign trade actors. In addition, the DIGIVUCE working group facilitates inter-institutional coordination by establishing mechanisms for analysis, evaluation, and monitoring of all processes that affect foreign trade, strengthening the efforts of the Single Window for Exports (VUE), and progressively integrating import and export processes with the Single Window for Imports (VUI).

The new working group is made up of the main agricultural product regulators in Paraguay including National Animal Quality and Health Service (SENACSA), National Plant and Seed Quality and Health Service (SENAVE), National Institute of Food and Nutrition (INAN), National Directorate of Health Surveillance (DINAVISA), National Institute of Technology, Standardization, and Metrology (INTN), and National Directorate of Customs (DNA) from the public sector and the multidisciplinary Trade Facilitation Working Group from the private sector. The DIGIVUCE group meets on a biweekly basis and the agreed-upon action plan contains almost 100 activities divided into 17 action areas that address bottlenecks identified in the USDA-funded trade mapping study. IESCâ€™s efforts in Paraguay are helping to expand regional and international trade of agricultural goods through systematic and continual improvements in trade facilitation.

Tribute to Mr. Trini Rayan (Attorney-at-law) ğŸ’

Within his career, he was a great environmental activist who stood along with the Centre for Environmental Justice in many of our environmental struggles, as an advocate, lawyer, as well as a companion. Often, his moral support encouraged us to pursue our environmental advocacy. The most recent engagement was saving the farmlands of Rideemaliyadda from the proposed 65,000-acre sugarcane factory project. At the very last moment, he guided CEJ on measures to be taken, and that very decision saved farmers from losing their lands. His good deeds will be his blessing and wealth, which he will carry with him.

May his soul rest in peace!

This year, IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project in Sri Lanka introduced a voucher initiative to help progressive dairy farmers invest in their farms to improve efficiency and productivity. One of the first voucher recipients was Mr. Punyasiri Bandara, who used his voucher to purchase and install a solar-powered water pump. This allowed him to reduce his electricity consumption by 63% while expanding his fodder cultivation from one-fourth of an acre to one full acre. After observing the cost-effectiveness of this renewable energy system, Mr. Punyasiri plans to expand his fodder cultivation to another acre. These upgrades and expansions will help him reach a target of 100 liters of milk per day year round.

Last month, IESCâ€™s USAID-funded Farmer-to-Farmer (F2F) program in Tanzania mobilized two volunteer experts, Doris Lyimo of Tanzania and Greg Sullivan of the U.S., to complete a volunteer assignment alongside USAIDâ€™s Alliance for Inclusive and Nutritious Food Products (AINFP) program, implemented by TechnoServe. IESC volunteer experts conducted dairy market research for Shambani Milk, a Tanzanian dairy company. With the informative market research data collected on consumer preferences for types of dairy products, packaging, and price, Shambani Milk will now be able to introduce new dairy products in Tanzania. Absalom Mwajpaja, an AINFP Senior Business and Marketing Linkage specialist, said, â€œThis was a very great and successful collaboration among the two USAID-funded programsâ€¦ for the benefit of our food processors and the whole value chain. This assignment will guide the way to introduce affordable nutritious products... that will help in combating malnutrition in the community.â€ This is just one example of how IESC supports agribusinesses through fruitful collaborations with other USAID implementing partners. Doris Lyimo is pictured here discussing dairy products with a shopkeeper. #farmertofarmer #volunteer

The recent upsurge in Sri Lankans migrating abroad for work highlighted a need for improved career guidance and counseling for migrant workers. The Skilled and Resilient Migrant Workers (SRMW) project, funded by the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) and implemented by IESC, conducted the first of a series of training programs for district-level partner staff from the Voice Area Federation in Puttalam and Federation of Institution for Rural Management (FIRM) in Vavuniya. Career guidance trainings will be rolled out for all district partner organizations and officials from the Sri Lanka Bureau of Foreign Employment (SLBFE) in the coming months, and will be followed by additional training on the delivery of Occupational Guidance Counselling (OGC) and Post Return Career counselling (PRC) for migrant workers. These efforts will help to make overseas employment safer and more rewarding for Sri Lankan migrants.

Prior to working with IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) project, Mr. Sugath Kumara Bandaranayakeâ€™s dairy management style was rudimentary, and his farm produced just 25-30 liters of milk per day at best. Mr. Sugath started working with IESC in 2019 and has since gradually adopted recommended best practices such as cultivating and ensiling his own fodder, providing clean drinking water to his cows 24 hours a day, and improving cow comfort. Mr. Sugath is now producing over 100 liters of milk per day and is planning additional improvements to maintain that milk yield consistently throughout the year. During a dairy farmer field day event held by Sri Lankaâ€™s Department of Animal Production and Health, Mr. Sugath shared his experiences with close to 300 dairy farmers to showcase the improvements he has made by implementing best practices shared by IESC through the MOD project.

Are you a digital marketing professional looking for an opportunity to give back? IESC's Farmer-to-Farmer program is in search of a volunteer with digital marketing expertise to virtually support a Sri Lankan agri-enterprise that focuses on the production and export of organic produce. Over the course of two weeks, the volunteer will support development of a digital marketing plan for the agri-enterprise. The selected volunteer will have the opportunity to work alongside the agri-enterprise's management team and have a direct impact on its ability to expand operations in the midst of the ongoing economic crisis in Sri Lanka. The first two awareness sessions for the members of "Kandiyapita Sobadam surakeeme sanwidanaya" (Kandiyapita Nature conservation society), under the GGF grant was held on 8th and 9th June 2023 at Weli Oya. As part of the training program we delievered lectures on preparing organic fertilizers for different crops and different stages of the plants, preparation of organic pest control mixtures, proper and effective harvesting to prevent losses, and discussed how the group can strengthen the environmental momentum by addressing the plastic pollution along the banks of the Balaharuwa lake and reducing the use of plastic and polythene. The CEJ team also joined the event of the group getting two huts to expand their market opportunities. The members acknowledged the involvement of CEJ in developing the proposal and getting the GGF grant including such a long-term investment.

HRDs Said Boudour, Kaddour Chouicha + Jamila Loukil face risk of imprisonment - summoned to court today with 2 days notice. 

Human rights defender Said Boudour remains under judicial surveillance as the judicial authorities upheld the decision to reject his appeal to withdraw the surveillance on 21 August 2022, while Kaddour Chouicha continues to be under a travel ban.

The human rights defenders are under the risk of being detained after appearing for questioning before the investigative judge today.

Front Line Defenders is deeply concerned by the recent series of reprisals, the use of anti-terrorism laws and judicial harassment faced by Algerian human rights defenders Said Boudour, Kaddour Chouicha and Jamila Loukil, which are directly related to their peaceful and legitimate work in the defence of human rights. We urge courts + authorities to drop the false criminal charges against them for their peaceful human rights work!

Today on World Oceans Day 2021 we reflect on the MV X-Press Pearl disaster that is unfolding before us. 

The short-term and long-term impacts of the disaster on marine flora and fauna, overall ecosystem health, people's livelihoods, food and health security, tourism, our nation's economy etc., are too extensive to realistically quantify. The intricate relationships we as humans have with the Ocean and its resources are beyond measure.  For fisher communities who depend on the oceans directly they are facing multiple simultaneous shocks, with few reassurances to restart their livelihoods. They have little or no access to social protection and are in a dire state. 

So today we focus on the fact that any form or scale of destruction to the Ocean is going to have impacts that extend beyond what we can see.

#WorldOceanDay #WorldOceansDay2021 #lk #SriLanka #MVXPressPearl

On August 12, IESCâ€™s USAID LinkSME project in Vietnam, in collaboration with the Agro Processing and Market Development Authority (Agrotrade), organized a workshop on trademarks and branding for 150 representatives of SMEs in the agro-processing sector. The event included 64 business matchmaking sessions between six lead firms and 25 SMEs. It also featured 11 SMEs displaying their products next to the venue. Agrotrade and USAID LinkSME will follow up on this workshop by providing support to participant SMEs where needed to help them meet lead firm requirements.

IPEN: for a toxics-free future has shared some important facts highlighted during Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee 2 on Plastic Pollution which was held in Paris, France from 29th of May to 02nd of June 2023.

During the contact group on control measured there was broad support to regulate chemicals in plastics and no major opposition in principle. Also, there was a very strong support to have transparency measures to trace chemicals in plastics.

The reports from the two contact groups, one on control measures, the other on means of implementation and means of implementation are available online at the following links:

Contact group 1: https://wedocs.unep.org/bitstream/handle/20.500.11822/42621/CG1.pdf
Contact group 2: https://wedocs.unep.org/bitstream/handle/20.500.11822/42622/CG2.pdf

All in session documents are available here: https://www.unep.org/events/conference/second-session-intergovernmental-negotiating-committee-develop-international/documents/in-session

Last month, IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) Project in Sri Lanka facilitated the completion of a week-long hands-on training session in partnership with the University of Florida (UF) and the Department of Animal Production and Health (DAPH). This session was attended by 40 veterinary surgeons and livestock development instructors who had previously completed nine virtual technical training modules offered by UF. The training combined classroom learning with farm visits and focused on best practices in milking, farm resource analysis, farm assessment, silage management, and heat stress management, among other topics. MOD, DAPH, and UF will review progress made by the participants in three months to address challenges implementing the best practices that were shared.

Through the sale of #PegasusSpyware, Israeli companies and govt have been profiting off escalating threats against human rights defenders around the world.  

 Visualizing Palestine  shows us the impact of this through a new visual project, The Pegasus Effect:

''The structures of Israeli settler colonialism, military occupation, and apartheid have enabled Israel to build one of the largest cyber industries in the world. By exporting technologies such as Pegasus spyware, the Israeli government and private Israeli companies are profiting off of escalating threats against human rights defenders, journalists, and political opponents around the world and exporting the Palestinian experience of mass surveillance and state violence under apartheid.

We partnered with Al Haq, Bisan Center, and Mind The Gap Consortium to create â€œThe Pegasus Effect,â€ a visual that uses the idea of the â€œbutterfly effectâ€ to depict how technologies that uphold Israeli apartheid ripple outward to impact communities thousands of miles away.  ''

https://visualizingpalestine.org/visuals/the-pegasus-effect

International Day of the Disappeared:

''No matter how powerful a country is, no matter what security challenges (real or perceived) they may face, the experts rightfully emphasize: â€˜There can never be an excuse to disappear people.â€™ Enforced disappearances are strictly prohibited under international law under any circumstances, and may constitute a crime against humanity when committed as part of a widespread or systematic attack against any civilian population.

The Chinese government continues to ignore calls for it to ratify the International Convention for the Protection of All Persons from Enforced Disappearance. It has disregarded requests for over nine years by the UNâ€™s Working Group on Enforced and Involuntary Disappearances to visit the country, including its most recent on 7 January 2022. In the meantime, the number of cases of individuals disappeared presented before the Working Group soared, reaching 214 by 2021, out of which 98 remain outstanding.

UN experts and civil society actors have documented many practices used by the Chinese authorities amounting to enforced disappearance. Some are written into Chinese law, or Chinese Communist Party guidance; others happen outside the scope of Chinaâ€™s own laws. Some target individuals for their actions or speech; others are wielded with the intent to terrorize a particular ethnic or religious community.

It is urgent that the UN, governments, and civil society worldwide press China to end, unequivocally, all forms of enforced disappearance.

Today, we remember these human rights defenders who have been forcibly disappeared and call for action to end disappearances.''

Enforced disappearances of HRDs is an increasingly worrying trend in #China. On the International Day of the Disappeared, we urge the international community to take meaningful action to put an end enforced disappearance in China.

Just over five years ago, on 13 August 2017, human rights lawyer Gao Zhisheng vanished for the third time. Gao, praised as the â€˜Conscience of Chinaâ€™, had long fought for the rights of those who dared to speak out, who belonged to religious minorities, who were evicted from their homes when their land was seized, or who protested against exploitation. For that, he was in and out of prison and separated from his family for nearly a decade. For more than five years, his wife and children have had no idea of his whereabouts, nor even if he is alive.

Gao Zhishengâ€™s case is severe, and yet represents only the tip of the iceberg: many other activists and lawyers face a similar fate, such as Tang Jitian, disappeared in 2021, tortured, and detained in a secret location. UN experts, including the Working Group on enforced disappearance, have sounded the alarm from as early as 2011 about the use of enforced disappearances against those taking part in Chinaâ€™s human rights movement. 

The Chinese government continues to ignore calls for it to ratify the International Convention for the Protection of All Persons from Enforced Disappearance. It has disregarded requests for over nine years by the UNâ€™s Working Group on Enforced and Involuntary Disappearances to visit the country, including its most recent on 7 January 2022. In the meantime, the number of cases of individuals disappeared presented before the Working Group soared, reaching 214 by 2021, out of which 98 remain outstanding.

It is urgent that the UN, governments, and civil society worldwide press China to end, unequivocally, all forms of enforced disappearance. 

Read more:

https://frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/civil-society-call-end-enforced-disappearances-china

Happy International Youth Day! The population in Kenya is dominated by youth, yet unemployment rates among the youth population in the country are high. Over 90% of unemployed youth in Kenya lack formal vocational or professional skills training, as evidenced by their low engagement in the agriculture sector where the average age of workers is 55. To strengthen opportunities for youth to get involved in the agriculture sector, IESCâ€™s Farmer-to-Farmer (F2F) program in Kenya has partnered with CAP Youth Empowerment Institute (CAP YEI) (CAP-Youth Empowerment Institute Capacity Building). IESCâ€™s specialized volunteer experts have provided training to youth who are interested in working in agriculture on obtaining access to finance to strengthen and grow their agribusiness endeavors. In honor of International Youth Day, the F2F Kenya program is excited to celebrate the growth of CAP YEIâ€™s work and the growth of the next generation of youth in agriculture.

In June 2022, F2F implementers from countries throughout Africa visited CAP YEIâ€™s demonstration farm and met with aspiring youth farmers to learn more about their work. Two F2F staff members and CAP YEI youth members are pictured here. #InternationalYouthDay #agriculture #youthempowerment #volunteer

Every 5 years, World Bank Sri Lanka analyses the country's understanding of the most important challenges and opportunities faced in its development journey. Now is the time for #SriLankans to make their voice count in our assessment of #SriLanka. Take this survey: http://wrld.bg/qDxR50EIM55  #SCDSL2021

The Centre for Poverty Analysis (CEPA) is conducting a series of stakeholder consultations on behalf of the World Bank Group (WBG) who are carrying their Systematic Country Diagnostic (SCD) update for Sri Lanka, 2021.

This survey will enable the World Bank to engage with the Sri Lankan public and seek their opinions on important development opportunities and challenges faced by the country in achieving the twin goals of eradicating extreme poverty and boosting shared prosperity. 

Lend your voice by participating in this online survey!

This International Youth Day, IESC highlights efforts by the USAID-funded youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, to ramp up skills in the solar technician trade. The Sri Lanka Sustainable Energy Authority (SLSEA) estimates that at least 10,000 new solar technicians will be needed to meet the governmentâ€™s targets and growing demand for solar energy solutions. In response to nationwide energy shortages and sharp increases in the cost of energy, the Government of Sri Lanka announced a strategy to generate 70% of the countryâ€™s power needs from renewable sources by 2030. YouLead is working with SLSEA and the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) on a pilot program to train and find on-the-job placements for 1,200 prospective solar techniciansâ€”with up to 70% of participants comprised of youth. IESC trained the first group of 420 prospective solar technicians through a two-day immersion, preparing school leavers for on-the-job training. Each training culminated in a job fair with approximately 100 solar installation companies actively recruiting. Following six months of on-the-job experience, the trainees will be eligible for formal certification. 

International Youth Day showcases the importance of youth engagement to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The launch of the Solar Technicians Training pilot program ties directly to achievement of SDG Goal 7 â€“ improving access to affordable and clean energy. Through this pilot, IESC will ultimately support new employment opportunities for thousands of youth while simultaneously helping to decrease Sri Lankaâ€™s dependence on non-renewable energy sources. #internationalyouthday

On July 11, 2022, Paraguay's DINAVISA launched its digital institutional management system called "DINAVISAPY." This system reduces times in product import processes and facilitates international trade in the chemical-pharmaceutical sector, including key ingredients for fertilizers and other agrochemicals.

The presentation was made in the presence of government authorities, including the Minister of Health, Dr. Julio Borba; DINAVISA National Director, Dr. MarÃ­a Antonieta Gamarra; and Ministry of Foreign Affairs, First Secretary Carrillo. Also in attendance were representatives from 11 trade associations that purchased the base software on which "DINAVISAPY" was built, as well as USDA Food for Progress Program Manager Kevin Alonzo, IESC Associate Vice President Chad Ford, and other prominent businesspeople and media. 

As "DINAVISAPY" is implemented, IESCâ€™s USDA-funded T-FAST project (Proyecto T-FAST) will continue to expand the system until March 2023 when all trade-related processes have been digitalized and then integrated into both single windows of import and export. A short video of the event can be seen at: http://ow.ly/6HUN50KgLL3

On 18 August 2022, Sri Lankan police used disproportionate force against peaceful protesters in Colombo including tear gas, water cannons and batons. 20 protesters, including human rights defender Chinthaka Rajapaksa and student leader and education rights defender Wasantha Mudalige were arrested from the protest. 16 of those arrested, were released on bail by the Magistrates Court the following day (19 August). Chinthaka Rajapakse was denied bail and remanded until 26 August. Wasantha Mudalige and two other student activists were held in police custody for well over 72 hours without access to lawyers and in violation of their due process rights. They are currently detained under Detention Orders in terms of the draconian Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA). Sri Lankan authorities invoked the PTA, depriving the detainees of basic safeguards, and without recourse to bail, despite appeals against the use of this law against protesters.  

We call for their immediate release and for authorities to respect the right to peaceful protest:

https://bit.ly/3woAGtC

With the support of IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Trade Safe (Proyecto Trade Safe) project in the Dominican Republic, a delegation of local business owners visited the World Food Logistics Organization (WFLO) Latin American Institute in MÃ©xico. Participants received training in cold chain practices to apply to their companies to improve operational efficiency. During the visit, they developed tools to design internal and external communications, as well as build leadership and management skills. Additionally, the group networked and learned about new strategies and technologies from industry leaders at WFLO Institute Latin America. With IESC's support, Dominican companies are implementing cold chain solutions to improve food quality and safety for consumers. #ProyectoTraSa #ProyectoTradeSafe #TraSa #TradeSafe

On the morning of 18 August 2022, Israeli security forces raided the offices and confiscated the property of the six Palestinian civil society organisations designated as â€œterrorist groupsâ€ under its Counter Terrorism Law, 2016. Documents, printers and computers were seized and closure orders were issued against the organizations. 

The organisations are Al-Haq Organization Ù…Ø¤Ø³Ø³Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø­Ù‚  Al-Haq, Addameer Prisoner Support & Human Rights Association  Addameer Prisoners Support and Human Rights Association, Bisan Center for Research & Development  Ù…Ø±ÙƒØ² Ø¨ÙŠØ³Ø§Ù† Ù„Ù„Ø¨Ø­ÙˆØ« ÙˆØ§Ù„Ø§Ù†Ù…Ø§Ø¡  Bisan Center for Research and Development, Defense for Children International- Palestine, Ø§ØªØ­Ø§Ø¯ Ù„Ø¬Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ù…Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ø²Ø±Ø§Ø¹ÙŠ (UAWC)  the Union of Agricultural Work Committees (UAWC) and the Union of Palestinian Womenâ€™s Committees (UPWC). The offices of the Health Work Committees (HWC) @hwcpal were also raided and closed.

This follows the Israeli governmentâ€™s move last year to outlaw the six groups designating them as â€œterroristâ€ organizations under Israeli law, and as â€œunlawful associationsâ€ under military law, which is applicable in the occupied West Bank. 

Front Line Defenders strongly condemns the raids, closures and the designations of terrorism brought against these Palestinian human rights organisations in response to their peaceful human rights work. Human rights defenders are not terrorists. This development marks a grave expansion of Israel's systematic policies and practices intended to silence Palestinian human rights defenders who seek justice and accountability for violations of Palestinians human rights. 

Front Line Defenders calls on all stakeholders â€“ states, international bodies, corporations and law enforcement authorities to clearly and unequivocally reject the terrorism charges brought against Palestinian human rights organisations and human rights defenders.

Family planning and reproductive health are central for women's empowerment and sustainable development. 

During crises, sexual and reproductive health needs of women and girls are overlooked and neglected, resulting in severe consequences. 

UNFPA is working with government and civil society stakeholders to uphold the health and protection rights of the most vulnerable women and girls.

STATEMENT:

Front Line Defenders condemns the disbarment of human rights lawyers in #Crimea by #Russian authorities for voicing concerns over the on-going human rights violations in Crimea.

Since Russiaâ€™s occupation of Crimea in 2014, authorities have relentlessly persecuted Crimean Tatars and others who have been critical of Russiaâ€™s human rights violations on the peninsula. In response to the growing abundance of politically motivated cases against Euromaidan activists, representatives of the Mejlis of the Crimean Tatar People (banned in Russia in 2016), activists from the Ukrainian cultural center and representatives of the Islamic political party Hizb ut-Tahrir, the human rights initiative â€œCrimean Solidarityâ€ was launched. This initiative supports victims of political persecution by documenting human right violations, providing legal aid, observing trials and supporting victimsâ€™ families. Lawyers working on politically motivated cases in Crimea soon became major targets for the authorities, regularly being subjected to harassment, threats, judicial prosecution, office raids, disciplinary penalties and threats of disbarment. On 15 July 2022, the Bar Association of the Chechen Republic of the Russian Federation disbarred human rights lawyers Lilia Hemedzhy, Rustem Kyamilev and Nazim Sheikhmambetov. Front Line Defenders condemns the disbarment of the lawyers and the increased targeting against human rights lawyers in Crimea by Russian authorities. 

Front Line Defenders condemns the disbarment of human rights lawyers Lilia Hemedzhy, Rustem Kyamilev and Nazim Sheikhmambetov. It believes that their disbarment is a clear reprisal for their legitimate and peaceful work as human rights lawyers and for voicing concerns over the on-going human rights violations in Crimea. The targeting and systemic persecution of human rights lawyers by the Russian authorities forms part of a worrying trend in Crimea since its annexation in 2014. 

See full statement: https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/crimea-ukraine-human-rights-lawyers-disbarred

The National Forum Against #GenderBasedViolence co-chaired by UNFPA and IDEA hosted a diverse panel discussion to mark the start of #16Days of Activism 2022, under the theme Unite! Activism to End Violence Against Women and Girls.

Former Minister of Justice Thalatha Atukorale stated that the issue continues to be a timely conversation and she strongly believes that we all have to work together to see violence against women and girls end.

Chief of Party of IDEA/MS Mr. Gowthaman Balachandran highlighted that technology is an enabler of violence as it gives a sense of entitlement for men and even boys to violate the dignity and rights of women and girls.

UNFPA Sri Lanka Country Representative Mr. Kunle Adeniyi emphasized the need to change hearts and minds and engage the new generation to improve how men and boys treat women and girls.

The panel discussion reflected on how women, especially those in the garment and estate sectors are particularly affected by the economic crises, policing and migration policies.

European Union in Sri Lanka and the Maldives funded #JURE, is jointly implemented by United Nations Development Programme - UNDP and UNICEF Sri Lanka, and is facilitated by the Ministry of Justice - Sri Lanka.

Today marks 12 years in arbitrary detention of indigenous Zapoteco leader, and forest & water rights defender, Pablo LÃ³pez Alavez in Oaxaca, #Mexico.  We come together at the Front Line Defenders office in Dublin, Ireland to plant a tree as a symbol of hope and we call for Pablo's immediate release. 

Prior to his detention, Pablo spent more than two decades working to ensure that the San Isidro AloÃ¡pam communityâ€™s rights to a safe environment and access to water were guarded and guaranteed.

As a direct consequence of this work, he made powerful enemies and faced many criminal accusations. On 15 August 2010, he was arbitrarily and violently detained. Following 7 years in detention without trial, and despite testimony and the presentation of evidence that Pablo was elsewhere on the day and time of a shooting he was accused of, and despite there being many inconsistencies and contradictions in the witness' testimony, a judge at the trial found him guilty on trumped up murder charges and sentenced him to 30 years in prison.

 #LibertadParaPablo #SeguimosSembrandoEsperanza

Princy Mangalika found out she had HIV at the age of 41 in 2001.

After she lost her husband and her home, she escaped the village with her two daughters, only having LKR 840.

â€œThey threw stones at our house, dumped garbage and hooted.â€

And even that didnâ€™t stop the stigma. This eventually made her think about attempting suicide. But she decided to live for her daughters. 

After that, she created the Positive Women's Network to assist other HIV victims. She has since raised awareness about HIV/AIDS, driving away the myths and misconceptions.

She was one of the first people to fight to bring down medicine for HIV/AIDS patients in Sri Lanka. 

World AIDS Day is a reminder that the disease and the severe stigma around it still exists. And the more we educate, the more we understand that alienating its victims is not the solution.

Joint Statement: ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡« #Afghanistan

 One year after Taliban takeover, human rights defenders at greater risk than ever.

One year since the Taliban captured power in Afghanistan, conditions for human rights defenders, especially women, have further deteriorated. A year ago, when the Taliban seized power in Afghanistan, they promised to respect human rights - including the rights of women and girls and media freedom. However, over the past year, they have carried out serious human rights violations and abuses, and sought to suppress civil society, media freedom, and any form of dissent with complete impunity. 

...Despite this grave human rights crisis, the international community has failed to live up to their responsibility for the Afghan human rights defenders they funded and encouraged for two decades . It is time for the international community to take concrete steps to provide practical support to human rights defenders and ensure the Taliban are held accountable.

The Support for Durable Resettlement (#SDR) Project supports the resettlement of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and refugee returnees, providing them with durable resettlement opportunities including access to essential basic services, sustainable livelihoods and income generation opportunities. 

Stories of Resettlement: Having resettled in 2015, Sundaralingam began cultivating on a portion of his land that was returned. Puwanachandran's interest in cultivation started at an early age, and he began growing vegetables on a small scale. Gopalakrishnan was faced with issues in transporting his produce, and a lack of water. 

The SDR Project is implemented by the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP together with the Government of Sri Lanka, with funding from the British High Commission Colombo, across 4 districts in #Jaffna, #Kilinochchi, #Mullaitivu and #Trincomalee.

At least thirteen Bahaâ€™i activists and defenders of the rights to freedom of religion, including human rights defenders Mahvash Sabet, Fariba Kamalabadi and Afif Naemi have remained arbitrarily detained in Tehran, Karaj, Sari, Qazvin and Shiraz since 31 July 2022. During this period, the homes and businesses of 100 Bahaâ€™is across Iran have been raided and the thirteen advocates for the rights of the Bahaâ€™i community to freedom of religion have been arrested or imprisoned.

In an attack on 2 August 2022, targeting the Bahaâ€™i community in Iran, up to 200 Iranian government agents sealed off the village of Roushankouh in Mazandaran province in north Iran where a number of Bahaâ€™is live and demolished their houses with heavy machinery. According to BIC, at least six houses were destroyed and over 20 hectares of land were confiscated. Prior to the raid, roads leading to the village were blocked, mobile devices of almost all people present in the village were confiscated and filming was prohibited. Anyone who tried to challenge the agents was arrested.  

Front Line Defenders urges the Iranian authorities to immediately and unconditionally release all arrested Bahaâ€™i human rights defenders including Mahvash Sabet, Fariba Kamalabadi and Afif Naemi. Additionally, Front Line Defenders urges the authorities to carry out an immediate, thorough and impartial investigation into the house raids, demolition of homes and confiscation of properties, including land grab of the members of the Bahaâ€™i community, with a view to publishing the results and bringing those responsible to justice in accordance with national and international standards. 

Read more:
https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/confiscation-properties-and-demolition-houses-bahai-community-following-arrests

Volunteers have been a critical part of IESCâ€™s mission since 1964. The Frank Pace Award, named for one of IESCâ€™s founders, is awarded each year to the volunteer expert who performed the most outstanding project in the previous year. Itâ€™s time to turn commitments into action. In #Mongolia, human rights defender Sukhgerel is at risk of arrest bc of her NB work protecting the #environment. We stand with her and urge authorities in #Mongolia to support her work! 

Sukhgerel Dugersuren is a Mongolian woman human rights defender who works closely with communities impacted by large scale development projects. She has a long history of exposing human rights abuses and environmental degradation linked to large scale mining, energy and infrastructure projects. She is the Executive Director of Oyu Tolgoi Watch (OT Watch) â€“ a Mongolian NGO monitoring the environmental and human rights impacts of Rio Tintoâ€™s gold and copper mine Oyu Tolgoi â€“ and Director of the Rivers without Boundaries Coalition in Mongolia which helps local communities to protect river ecosystems they depend on. 

On 3 August 2022, during a government briefing, the Minister of Justice and Internal Affairs of Mongolia, H. Nyambaatar, stated that the construction of the power plant had been suspended for two years. On 3 June 2022, an article written by Sukhgerel Dugersuren criticising the Erdeneburen hydroelectric power plant which is planned to be built on the Khovd River in Western Mongolia was published by The Third Pole.1 The article raised concerns about the project, including about the safety of the construction, potential environmental impact given its location in an ecologically sensitive area of Tsambagarav Uul National Park, and the potential displacement of 112 pastoralist households.

 Front Line Defenders condemns the attempt to criminalise Sukhgerel Dugersuren and other human rights defenders in Mongolia. Opposing the negative human rights and environmental impacts of infrastructure, energy and mining projects is not a crime and should not be punished.

We at the Centre for Poverty Analysis are saddened by the demise of Mr V. Sivagnanasothy, Secretary of the Commission of Inquiry and Member of the Public Service Commission.
 
Mr Sivagnanasothy served as a Board Member of the Centre for Poverty Analysis from 2016-2018. He supported our work, especially with his in-depth knowledge and expertise in reconciliation work.

Moreover, we wish to acknowledge with gratitude and appreciate the support rendered by Mr Sivagnanasothy who paved the way to highlight our efforts to influence policy when he served as the Secretary to the Ministry of Prison Reforms, Rehabilitation, Resettlement & Hindu Religious Affairs. His dedication and efforts to revive the plantation sector are humbly appreciated. 

May his soul Rest in Peace.

As Vietnamese SMEs face significant difficulties in their post-COVID-19 business recovery, digital transformation and access to finance are crucial to help them adapt to and recover from emerging challenges and enhance their competitiveness to participate in national and international supply chains. 

On July 26, IESCâ€™s USAID LinkSME Project in Vietnam, in collaboration with Vietnamâ€™s Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI), hosted a workshop on Empowering Small and Medium Enterprises through Digital Transformation and Access to Finance. The event was attended by representatives from MPI and USAID/Vietnam, as well as more than 100 representatives from ministries, government agencies, representatives of provinces, business associations, businesses, and the media, and was streamed online to hundreds of businesses across the country. 

Apart from learning about powerful tools and materials, workshop participants were introduced to upcoming support programs and discussed digital transformation and access to finance needs and solutions through face-to-face matching and consultations with solution providers, banks, and credit funds. MPI and USAID LinkSME will continue empowering Vietnamese SMEs through digital transformation and access to finance to help SMEs adapt to the new business environment, overcome challenges, and seize market opportunities.

IESCâ€™s USDA-funded T-FAST project in Paraguay (Proyecto T-FAST) recently supported the training and certification of 33 professionals from the agricultural and food sector representing Paraguayâ€™s National Institute of Technology, Standardization and Metrology (INTN), the Secretary of Agriculture and Livestock (SENACSA), the National Plant and Seed Quality and Health Services (SENAVE), the National Institute of Food and Nutrition (INAN), the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock (MAG), and the National Accreditation Body of the National Council for Science and Technology (ONA-CONACYT). Professors specialized in food safety from T-FAST implementing partner Kansas State University (KSU) delivered the "Food Safety and the Hazard Analysis of Critical Control Points (HACCP) systemâ€ training over the course of a three-day workshop, providing the opportunity for participants to obtain official HACCP international certification granted by the Food Safety Net Services (FSNS). This training and international certification was organized by the Working Group for the Facilitation of Trade in Agricultural Goods of the National Committee for Trade Facilitation (NTFC) and coordinated by MAG and the Paraguayan Chamber of Exporters and Marketers of Cereals and Oil Seeds (CAPECO), with the support of the T-FAST project and KSU.

Intergenerational Dialogue Series 

â€˜Voices of Peaceâ€™ on the 6th April 2021 at 4:00pm on Zoom

This is the third dialogue planned for this series is an online discussion with author and activist Sarah Kabir. Sarah will give insights from her book â€œVoices of Peaceâ€. The format of the event is set to be a book reading followed by a question-and-answer session. Voices of Peace (herein referred to as VOP), is an anthology of stories from a sample of twenty combatants from both sides of the conflict. The book published in 2018 contains narratives that highlight the experience and struggles of combatants during and after the war. Sarahâ€™s work of recording narratives with the view of preserving the multifaceted history of the state emulates the principles of memorialisation. 

Further, the socio-political context of the state provides a backdrop in which revisiting the human aspect of ethnic and civil conflict is pertinent if not imperative. The growing tension between communities as well as the developments vis-a-vis international response to human rights in Sri Lanka revitalises the importance of familiarising with the human cost of conflict in order to move towards a more cohesive society.

Congratulations to the six graduates of the AccelerateHER program, Sri Lankaâ€™s first customized accelerator program for female entrepreneurs implemented in partnership with the US Department of State and Hatch Works and supported by IESC's USAID-funded youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead. The curated three-month program empowered early-stage start-ups and drove gender parity in entrepreneurship, providing support to upskill six women entrepreneurs and their businesses. IESC supported the program with subject matter expertise, technical assistance, and mentoring for the Personal Development module of the program.
 
The graduating class conducted a Demo Day for an audience of potential investors and noteworthy stakeholders. The entrepreneurs had the opportunity to pitch their validated business concept, financial feasibility, go-to-market strategy, and team expansion plan.
 
Since the completion of the AccelerateHER program and Demo Day, participants have achieved significant business milestones, including over 17 strategic and retail partnerships worth over Rs. 20 million ($55,000). In addition, five out of six women entrepreneurs doubled their product lines and increased product quantities by 100%; 70% doubled their sales and revenue; and 90% expanded their teams making them first-time employers and creating much-needed jobs.
 
As its next step, AccelerateHER launched regional bootcamps to support, nurture, and accelerate female-led ventures across Sri Lanka.

IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) Project in Sri Lanka recently hosted a World Milk Day commemoration to create broader awareness of the potential for increasing milk yields even under trying economic conditions. The event was attended by over 200 dairy farmers, processing company representatives, and key officials from the Ministry of Livestock Development and the Department of Animal Production and Health. The event included a walkthrough tour of one of MODâ€™s progressive dairy farmers, showcasing the low-cost farm model producing 100 liters per day. Through the event, IESC helped to increase awareness of the possibilities of the dairy sector and the support that public officials can provide.

Its been one year since The Pegasus Project exposed cyber surveillance of HRDs - demonstrating chilling effects on human rights and the well-being of HRDs. 

In December, we made a strong call for action to be taken in addressing targeted surveillance of human rights defenders, after Front Line Defenders uncovered surveillance spyware on the devices of six Palestinian human rights defenders 2 month before:   

https://t.co/RE2otuPczX 

We subsequently uncovered a number of targeted surveillance attacks in different contexts:

Palestine: https://frontlinedefenders.org/en/press-release-front-line-defenders-investigation-finds-pegasus-spyware-6-palestinian-hrd-phones

Jordan (w CitizenLab ): https://frontlinedefenders.org/sites/default/files/jordanpegasusreport.pdf

WHRD report (w Access Now ): https://frontlinedefenders.org/sites/default/files/unsafe-anywhere_-women-human-rights-defenders-speak-out-about-pegasus-attacks_en.pdf

El Salvador: https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/exposed-civil-society-condemns-use-pegasus-el-salvador-spy-journalists-and 

We continue to call for a global moratorium on the sale, use and transfer of surveillance technologies:

https://www.amnesty.org/en/petition/targeted-surveillance-human-rights-defenders/

Revitalising the Disaster Risk Management (DRM) process in the New Normal

Duryog Nivaran, Janathakshan and the Centre for Poverty Analysis conduct the official kick-off meetings for the project â€˜Revitalising the Disaster Risk Management (DRM) process in the New Normalâ€™

Duryog Nivaran â€“ the South Asia Network for Disaster Mitigation recently received a grant from the South Asia Small Grants Program (SAGSP) which is managed by The Asia Foundation (TAF) to implement a project with its partner organisations Janathakshan and the Centre for Poverty Analysis that aims to revitalize the DRM process in the New Normal.

The project was conceived through the recognition of the need for stronger DRM processes, especially at community level, in the New Normal created as a result of COVID19. In the New Normal, the state and communities will have to build resilience and effective response mechanisms for concurrent disaster situations (floods, droughts, cyclones etc. amidst COVID19 limitations), in order to mitigate both their short-term and long-term impacts. The project looks to empower communities and civil society organizations (CSOs) to take a more active role in DRM processes while also strengthening coordination between such structures and local institutions.

Read More - https://www.cepa.lk/blog/revitalising-the-disaster-risk-management-drm-process-in-the-new-normal/

On 5 July 2021, 84-year-old Jesuit priest and human rights defender Father Stan Swamy died in judicial custody at the Holy Family Hospital, in Mumbai, India. 

On the first anniversary of his death, we, the 13 undersigned international and national human rights organisations, remember Stan Swamyâ€™s decades-long commitment to realising the rights of Dalit and indigenous peoples in India, especially in Jharkhand State. 

We reiterate our call demanding an independent and effective investigation into his death in custody and for the immediate and unconditional release of the 15 other prominent human rights defenders charged in the same case.

On June 23-24, IESCâ€™s USAID LinkSME Project in Vietnam, in collaboration with the Agency for Enterprise Development, organized a two-day training in Ho Chi Minh City for business support organizations (BSOs) on matchmaking events and membership retention and expansion. Nearly 40 BSO representatives attended the training and many expressed interest in future collaboration with the project on these topics. BSOs represent a path to sustainable support for businesses independent of the project. BSOs that are skilled at matchmaking and attracting and retaining members are an invaluable resource for SMEs.

On 5th July, it will be one year since Father Stan Swamy died in custody. Fr. Stan Swamy was an indigenous peopleâ€™s rights defender. He was the founder of Vistapan Virodhi Janvikash Andolan (VVJA), an all India platform for different movements that are resisting displacement of adivasi people, dalits, and farmers from their lands. The defender spent 9 months in jail under the anti-terror law, the Unlawful Activities Prevention Act (UAPA), denied bail and medical care in jail, and only transferred to a hospital when his condition became critical on 29 May. 

Join us for a discussion on the persecution of religious minorities in India, and to commemorate Fr. Stans death with a number of key speakers:

IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) Project in Sri Lanka recently hosted leaders from the Department of Animal Production and Health (DAPH) in visits to MOD trained dairy farmers in the North Western Province. IESC and DAPH visited dairy farmers who have doubled, tripled, and even quadrupled their milk production using improved management practices recommended by IESC. IESC also showcased the achievements of entrepreneurs engaged in the commercial fodder and silage sector who are helping to enable dairy farmers to bridge gaps in feed requirements. Following the visits, the DAPH team held a debriefing and brainstorming session where they suggested further improvements to reach maximum productivity at minimum cost.

Iran: Meta Must Protect the Iranian #MeToo Movement

A wide network of Iranian womenâ€™s rights defenders, feminist activists and public figures, â€”who are part of Iranâ€™s #MeToo movement and in the diasporaâ€” have come under coordinated attacks from bots and trolls on Instagram in an effort to stifle their freedom of expression and damage their online presence and influence. The huge numbers of fake followers flooding their accounts are part of a sustained, paid campaign.

ARTICLE 19, Access Now, United for Iran and Front Line Defenders urge Meta, Instagramâ€™s parent company, to immediately investigate and eliminate these fake followers and do more to protect the free expression of these human rights defenders, activists and individuals. 
....

Our organisations urge Meta to prioritise its investigations and hold these paid-for troll farms accountable. We are deeply worried by their potential for being hired by actors associated with states such as the Islamic Republic of Iran who would benefit from stifling the voices of these womenâ€™s rights defenders.

These fake followers must be investigated and removed. Meta must act swiftly to stop the harms inflicted on Iranian womenâ€™s rights defenders, and urgently ensure the protection of their freedom of expression on the platform.
