Life at Home During COVID-19

CEPAâ€™s 63rd Open Forum was held on the 16th of February 2021 via Zoom and Facebook Live. The virtual discussion was centred on two studies, by CEPA and Asha Abeyasekera, both looking at â€˜life at homeâ€™ during COVID-19.

The presenters at the Open Forum were Gayathri Lokuge, Nadhiya Najab and Asha L Abeyasekera, with Madhavie Gunawardena being the discussant and Chandima Arambepola as the moderator.

The forum brought about fruitful discussions and unique perspectives, ending with an array of questions that each presenter got the chance to answer with their expertise and opinions, drawing ideas from the studies they conducted.

The exploratory research study from CEPA looked at how families with young children were faced with the challenges of care responsibilities brought about by the movement restrictions imposed due to COVID-19. Data for the study were collected in two waves, the study was conceptualised and conducted during wave 1, from March to May 2020, and wave 2 was conducted between November and December. Information was gathered through a quantitative survey, shared on social media, to capture the experiences and perspectives of those with access to web-based platforms. The 1st wave saw a response of 466, while the second wave had 81 respondents. At the forum, the focus was the on the quantitative component but there was also a qualitative component to the study during both waves.

CEPAâ€™s Gayathri Lokuge spoke of the gendered nature of COVID-19 related impacts, the tasks divided, and how individuals coped with the shift to remote working and distance learning. With case studies, examples and statistics, Gayathri explained the mental impact, such as the increase in feelings of tension and anxiety, due to the loss of â€˜me-timeâ€™, for both men and women.

Nadhiya Najab dived a little deeper highlighted the gendered nature of the division of household and childcare responsibilities and distance learning. The â€˜COVID pushâ€™, Nadhiya explained, is the term used to illustrate the change in participation in household responsibilities, which saw an increase in male participation during the first lockdown in Sri Lanka, in 2020. Nevertheless, with the arrival of the second wave, Nadhiya showed the audience how the division of labour became bigger and the responsibility of childcare fell back greatly on women.

https://www.cepa.lk/blog/life-at-home-during-covid-19/

Increasing access to finance for youth in the agriculture sector is a main objective of IESCâ€™s USAID-funded Farmer-to-Farmer (F2F) Program in Tanzania. Youth have what it takes to drive the future of the agricultural sector in Tanzania and increasing their access to finance is an important way to improve food security and agricultural productivity and provide livelihoods to youth. That is why IESC has supported the Mshikamano Youth Group located in the Geita region of Tanzania - to increase their knowledge of lending and to access finance for agriculture activities. Through F2F volunteer expert support and training, Mshikamano Youth Group members were able to pool their shared financial resources to undertake profitable activities as a group and provide individual loans to group members, which is extremely impactful for group members who previously were not able to obtain financing and were excluded from the Tanzanian financial sector. #WYSD2022

We condemn the arbitrary arrest of #Indian WHRD Teesta Setalvad - happening shortly after the dismissal of a petition filed by Teesta and Zakia Jafri, seeking accountability for the 2002 Gujarat riots. 

On 25 June 2022, prominent whrd Teesta Setalvad was arbitrarily detained by the Anti-Terrorism Squad (ATS) of Gujarat Police on trumped up charges including forgery, fabricating evidence and criminal conspiracy.

ATS officers forcibly entered her home in Mumbai, and detained her without a warrant - this happened a day after the Supreme Court of India dismissed a petition seeking justice and accountability for the 2002 Gujarat riots filed by Teesta Setalvad and Zakia Jafri, the widow of a person killed in the riots.

This World Youth Skills Day, IESC highlights efforts by the USAID-funded youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, to build the skills of young entrepreneurs to start and run their own business. Through entrepreneurship development training with the Samurdhi Authority, IESC is supporting young mothers such as 21-year-old Maduwanthi to turn their informal livelihoods into micro or small enterprises. â€œI realized that we need to be more financially prudent and learn how to keep track of our income and costs. I was still breastfeeding my baby but also didnâ€™t want to miss the opportunity to learn. So, I just brough my baby along,â€ says Maduwanthi. Through the training, which was accommodating to the needs of this new mother, Maduwanthi and her husband learned skills for managing their cash flow and expanding their business through product diversification. By the end of June 2022, YouLead completed 127 training programs in eight districts, teaching entrepreneurship development skills to more than 5,000 participants. #WYSD2022

Happy World Youth Skills Day! Building the capacity of youth is a key activity of IESCâ€™s USAID Farmer-to-Farmer program in Tanzania. Last year, IESCâ€™s F2F volunteer experts Frank Wertheim and Ernest Jerome delivered a training to the Missenyi Green House Youth Group, which is made up of 100 youth members. In March 2019, they received a greenhouse facility from the Tanzanian Prime Ministerâ€™s Office and Ministry of Labor, Employment, and Youth Development to unlock the potential of Tanzanian youth in the agriculture sector and address youth unemployment. The Missenyi Youth Group works on optimizing horticultural production and improving the quality of produce in order to increase the income of its members. The F2F volunteer experts trained Missenyi members on compost making, tomato production and agronomy, and soil health management to enhance their skills in sustainable tomato production. The training provided the youth members with techniques to monitor and regulate the soil pH and improve soil organic matter content and fertility, resulting in greater tomato harvests and higher incomes. #WYSD2022

IESCâ€™s USDA-funded T-FAST project (Proyecto T-FAST) in Paraguay recently sent a 12-person delegation of key public and private sector decision-makers in the international trade arena, including Paraguayâ€™s National Customs Director, to SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil. The Paraguayan Customs Director, along with customs authorities from ten other countries in the Americas and the Caribbean, signed a Regional Mutual Recognition Agreement (MRA) to recognize the Authorized Economic Operators (AEO) of every other country, increasing the number of AEO certified companies recognized by Paraguayâ€™s Customs and the Customs authorities of Argentina, Brazil, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Peru, the Dominican Republic, and Uruguay, to 2,009 AEO companies. AEO programs help low-risk trade move through inspections faster, helping businesses and agencies to expedite trade of agricultural goods.

IESC is celebrating the success of the USAID-funded Workforce and Higher Access to Markets Activity (WHAM Activity) in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which officially closed last month. The WHAM Activity was a five-year project (2017-2022) implemented by IESC that stimulated job creation by advancing BiHâ€™s trade integration with and expansion into the EU and regional markets. WHAM focused on accelerating employment for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the metal processing, wood processing, textile/apparel, and information and communications technology (ICT) sectors.

Through 83 grants and in close cooperation with 335 companies and 67 municipalities, IESC helped SMEs achieve 293 transactions with foreign customers, supported 54 companies to attain 94 new certifications, and supported 60 SMEs to obtain new or upgraded technologies. WHAM-supported SMEs reported an 18.2% increase in sales and an 13.6% increase in exports. IESC also supported the training of 2,657 workers and jobseekers, and the creation of 2,333 new full-time jobs, 33% of which were for women and 60% of which were for young people. 

You can watch a summary of the USAID WHAM Activity and its many accomplishments here: http://ow.ly/Qytf50JQMrh 

#USAIDBiH #USAinBiH USAID Bosnia and Herzegovina

IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Market-Oriented Dairy (MOD) Project in Sri Lanka facilitated the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between USDA and the Sri Lankan Department of Agriculture. This MoU will strengthen the existing partnerships between MOD and the Government of Sri Lankaâ€™s Department of Animal Production and Health (DAPH) allowing for MOD to broaden its reach and lay the groundwork for the sustainability of project activities after the project ends. In the short time since the MoU was signed, IESC and DAPH have already moved to deepen their partnership, beginning to implement delayed activities focused on building DAPHâ€™s dairy extension capabilities to reach more farmers. Read more here: https://lk.usembassy.gov/the-united-states-contributes-27-million-to-strengthen-sri-lankas-dairy-industry/

The odds are in favour of what might just be the best prequel ever!ğŸ¹

This is a visual masterpiece, to say the least. Francis Lawrence returned as the director for the fifth installment of The Hunger Games franchise, honouring Suzanne Collinsâ€™ already perfect world-building.  The creators tow the thin line between both retro and futuristic settings.
 
Rachel Zegler nailed the free-spirited, rebellious musician archetype as Lucy Gray Baird. Tom Blyth played Coriolanus Snow, staying true to Donald Sutherland's version but adding his own flair. Blyth skillfully captured Snow's transition into a power-hungry tyrant. Hunter Schafer, Viola Davis and Peter Dinklage were excellent in their roles as you might already expect.

While the plot holds its own story, we loved picking up on the subtle Easter eggs and callbacks to the original series â€“ if you know, youâ€™ll know. 

Overall, despite the length of the film, it packs action, emotion and moving soundtracks into, in our opinion, one of the best prequel movies ever made - a rather tricky feat for most blockbuster franchises to pull off.

The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is now screening at Scope Cinemas. Be sure to check it out on the big screen!

By: Kameshi Kohomange

Today on #WorldYouthSkillsDay, we are reminded of the pressing need to empower young people and equip them with the skills to effectively navigate the future of work. As we continue to grapple with a socio-economic crisis, compounded by a steady increase in population, we emphasise the role of Education and training systems in responding to these challenges. 

A team of experienced educators at UNDP #SriLankaâ€™s HackaDev Academy has been working closely with the National Youth Corps (NYC) to revamp the present curriculum through syllabus and module development as part of a wider engagement with the institution, a collaboration which directly aligns with the 2023 YSD theme: 'Skilling teachers, trainers and youth for a transformative future'. 3 of 9 modules have been developed by the HackaDev team, the approval of which took place at the first module validation meeting held at Citra Lab recently.

The correlation between poverty and inequality

A common assumption is that when levels of poverty decrease, inequality levels go down as well. This is, however, far from reality as inequality and poverty are two different concepts. The effects of inequality on societies are potentially harmful and is a cause for concern in the long run.

Sri Lankaâ€™s poverty levels have seen a significant reduction. The poverty headcount ratio was at 4.1% in 2016, compared to 15.2% in 2006/7 (Department of Census and Statistics). Despite the decline in income poverty, income inequality continues to remain unchanged. More than half the total household income of the country is enjoyed by the richest 20% in Sri Lanka while the bottom decile (poorest 20%) gets only 5%, with the share of household income being just 1.6% for the poorest 10%.

https://www.cepa.lk/blog/the-correlation-between-poverty-and-inequality/

In recognition of Micro-, Small, and Medium-sized Enterprises (MSME) Day today, we are highlighting the USAID-funded Workforce and Higher Access to Markets Activity (WHAM Activity) in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which closed earlier this month. Supporting small and medium enterprises was central to IESCâ€™s work under WHAM, which helped more than 320 SMEs to attain new certifications, upgrade technologies, increase sales and exports, and find qualified workers to meet labor needs. 

Through a grant provided to the Association of Employers of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, IESC helped young men and women gain the skills needed to obtain meaningful jobs in the textile and footwear industries through practical training with local SMEs. Not only does this support young unemployed people to build their skillsets and find work, but it also supports Bosnian SME employers to find qualified tailors, seamstresses, and assemblers to fill open positions, enabling them to expand production capacities and exports and ultimately hire even more people. 

Watch the video to learn more about the impact of this support: https://youtu.be/9pj0CvaSLh8

For Micro-, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprises (MSME) Day, IESC celebrates the USAID LinkSME projectâ€™s work to strengthen and connect Vietnamese SMEs to global markets. Vietnam continues to attract substantial amounts of foreign investment despite the economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. USAID LinkSME is dedicated to ensuring that as much of this foreign investment as possible remains in the domestic economy by strengthening the capabilities of SMEs to meet the demands of foreign investors and domestic lead firms. This allows foreign investors and domestic lead firms to partner with these domestic SMEs for parts, supplies, or other intermediate goods, rather than importing them from abroad. When this investment remains in the country, Vietnamese SMEs are able to innovate, generate jobs, and improve their communities. #MSMEDay #MSMEDay2022

STATEMENT:

Front Line Defenders is profoundly concerned for the health of prominent human right defender and dual Danish-Bahraini citizen, Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja, who is currently serving a life sentence in Bahrain for exercising his rights to freedom of expression, association and peaceful assembly.

As a direct result of the well-documented torture and mistreatment the human rights defender endured at the hands of the Bahraini authorities1, Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja suffers from a series of chronic and degenerative health problems and requires timely, expert medical treatment. According to recent reports however, between January 2022 and April 2022, necessary medical treatment was actively withheld from the human rights defender by the Bahraini authorities, and access to medical appointments was denied.

Read more:

https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/en/statement-report/call-immediate-release-ireland-medical-grounds-prominent-human-rights-defender-and

The USAID Industry-led Skills Development Program in Georgia signed a grant agreement with Caucasus University, a leading educational institution in Georgia. Together with the Spanish Basque Culinary Center and the Gastronomic Tourism Business Association of Georgia, Caucasus University will develop an innovative skills development certificate training program, which will be the first gastronomy training created in collaboration with international partners. The knowledge and experience transfer from one of the leading educational centers in gastronomy in Europe will benefit Georgiaâ€™s gastronomical vocational education programs and the hospitality industry overall. The key to sustainability is the programâ€™s integration within the curriculum of the Caucasus Academy of Gastronomy in Gurjaani, Kakheti.

The Support for Durable Resettlement (SDR) Project supports the resettlement of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) and refugee returnees, providing them with durable resettlement opportunities including access to essential basic services, sustainable livelihoods and income generation opportunities. 

Stories of Resettlement: Niroshan's initial interest in agriculture was piqued by his Muthalali. From that point, the SDR Project provided him with a sprinkler set which allowed him to expand the area in which he cultivated. Since her return from India, Shanthi has been running her own Indian food shop. She has developed her business to include the marketing of her speciality 'sambar powder' which has also been a fast-selling item. Brindhapan, an air condition mechanic also versed in repairing refrigerators and electronic devices learnt his skills from his father. Prarthana's wish for a photocopy machine was granted through the project, and she has been able to continue her father's business successfully. Through the SDR project, each of them was taught how to develop their businesses and save money while continuing to grow. 

The SDR Project is implemented by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in Sri Lanka together with the Government of Sri Lanka, with funding from the British High Commission in #Colombo, across 4 Districts in #Jaffna, #Kilinochchi, #Mullaitivu and #Trincomalee and the Pacific #fundingwindows.

Last month, IESCâ€™s USDA-funded T-FAST project in Paraguay (Proyecto T-FAST) and PROCOMEX presented the results of the exports mapping study for air cargo, which consisted of six workshops with a representative group of decision makers from the private sector and two workshops with a representative group from the private and public sectors, at the Paraguayan Industrial Union (UIP). In total, 56 bottlenecks were identified and discussed, and solutions were agreed upon. Considering just the procedural bottlenecks, which include lack of coordination, norm adaptation, and unnecessary bureaucracy, a potential time reduction of 22% was identified. This unprecedented and comprehensive trade mapping study marks the beginning of a new phase for Paraguayâ€™s National Trade Facilitation Committee (NTFC) as these bottlenecks are being incorporated into the NTFCâ€™s working groups to commit all parties involved to provide long-lasting solutions.

WE'RE HIRING:

Come and work with us - Front Line Defenders is currently seeking an experienced and resourceful manager to lead the Communications and Events strategy for the organisation and develop the work of the team, with the objective of supporting human rights defenders (HRDs) at risk through the use of the media and other communications channels. 

This role has overall responsibility for all communications and events of Front Line Defenders, including publications, media engagement, social media, website and events (namely Front Line Defenders Award, Dublin Platform, Annual Lecture, Dublin Human Rights & Arts Festival and others).

The tasks of the Head of Communications and Events include developing and implementing the Communications & Media strategy for Front Line Defenders, with a focus on promoting the protection of human rights defenders; managing the Communications & Events team; coordinating media and promotional efforts; ensuring standards for communications, representations and events are maintained to the highest standard. 

See more details on how to apply here: https://frontlinedefenders.org/en/recruitment-volunteering

See role profile here: https://bit.ly/3whtPCt

Much like the larger global economy, Vietnam is increasingly going digital, with producers and consumers becoming increasingly reliant on digital technologies. It is important for SMEs to not be left behind in this digital transition. On June 2nd and 3rd, the USAID LinkSME project organized a two-day training on e-commerce for SMEs in Dalat City with the Technical Assistance Center and the Lam Dong Business Association. Representatives from nearly 70 SMEs attended the training in person and another 60 joined remotely. E-commerce offers SMEs the opportunity to lower inventory costs, reach new customers, and improve convenience and consumer satisfaction. The project identified participants most likely to benefit from intensive follow-on assistance and will be providing them with further technical assistance to expand their e-commerce activities.

The UNFPA Representative in Sri Lanka Kunle Adeniyi chaired a discussion on intimate partner violence during pregnancy at the Congress of South Asian Federation of Obstetrics and Gynaecology in Colombo. The objective of the session was to capacitate the participants of the congress - obstetricians and post graduates from Sri Lanka and SAFOG countries - on addressing intimate partner violence in the obstetric practice.

A UNFPA team visited the district of Monaragala in Sri Lanka to sensitise the beneficiaries of the UNFPA's cash voucher assistance programme in partnership with WFP. UNFPA provides an additional cash top up to 51,700 pregnant and lactating women, people living with disabilities and women headed households so they are able to fulfill their health and nutritional needs. UNFPA also distributed 150 UNFPA's dignity kits to women and girls.

IESCâ€™s USDA-funded T-FAST project (Proyecto T-FAST) in Paraguay conducted training sessions at Paraguayâ€™s National Vegetable and Seed Health Service (SENAVE) for lab technicians from SENAVE, Paraguayâ€™s National Institute of Technology and Standardization (INTN), and Paraguayâ€™s National Institute of Food and Nutrition (INAN). Led by laboratory specialists from IESCâ€™s partner, Kansas State University, the training sessions covered topics such as the use of polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and vegetable bacteriology. Through these training activities, IESC is increasing the technical and scientific capacities of Paraguayâ€™s laboratories. Lab technicians from SENAVE, INTN, and INAN are now better equipped to support the trade of agricultural goods through comprehensive laboratory techniques and methodologies for food analysis.

IESC held a closing ceremony for the USAID-funded Workforce and Higher Access to Markets Activity (WHAM Activity) in Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH), which officially closed on June 8. The ceremony was attended by WHAMâ€™s private and public sector partners, business associations, employment agencies, workforce training and education centers, and other grant recipients. Also in attendance were the USAID/BiH Mission Director Courtney Chubb, IESC President and CEO David Hartingh, and IESC Program Director Gabriela Kliewer. 

Between June 2017 and June 2022, IESC delivered 83 grants and technical assistance to export-oriented small and medium enterprises (SMEs) working in the wood processing, metal processing, textile/apparel, and ICT sectors through the USAID WHAM Activity.

Front Line Defenders and partners presents its live Annual Lecture 2022 with Professor Anat Biletzki: Politicizing Human Rights in Palestine/Israel. 

In Palestine/Israel, the recent criminalization and tagging of Palestinian human rights groups as â€œterrorist organizationsâ€ by Israel is a cynical political maneuver. A narcissistic view sees â€œHuman Rightsâ€ as apolitical; that is, it should be universally conceived, internationally regulated, objectively adjudicated, legally administered, and never instrumentally exploited for particular interests. 

However, it is only in explicit political contexts such as Palestine/Israel, that we can make sense of the goal of â€œHuman Rightsâ€ and their defenders â€“ to relieve victims of tyranny, oppression, and persecution.

We are hiring a full-time Research Writer!

Curious to uncover intriguing stories that are just waiting to be heard? Weâ€™re on the lookout for a go-getter who does their research and produces impactful stories! 

If this sounds like your calling, join our versatile team of creatives and see how far you can excel!

Send us your CV and portfolio to shout@pulse.lk!

Job Description

- Ideating and conceptualising content
- Producing insightful and impactful audiovisual content i.e. documentaries
- Producing comprehensive and engaging infographic content
- Producing in-depth research articles
- Engaging in fieldwork
- Coordinating with multiple in-house teams and external parties
- Fact checking
- Proofreading 

Requirements

- Academic qualifications in writing/ literature/ journalism/audiovisual media
- 2 years of experience in a similar capacity
- Outstanding portfolio of work
- Excellent command of English 
- Fluency in Sinhala and/or Tamil will be an added advantage
- Attention to detail 
- Ability to work in a fast-paced environment and be a team player

We are an equal opportunity employer.
All eligible applicants will receive equal consideration for employment. 
Females are encouraged to apply.

Commemorating #WorldHumanitarianDay, DMC Srilanka together with UNFPA and the financial support of the Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade launched #SriLanka's first Handbook on Gender, Sexual and Gender-Based Violence in Disasters. The UNFPA Representative for Sri Lanka, Kunle Adeniyi speaking at the event impressed upon the fact that "The current socio-economic crisis in Sri Lanka has negatively impacted social and gender equality. Even before the crisis, Sri Lanka had a high rate of gender-based violence, and past studies indicate that there is an increasing risk of GBV during crisis situations. So now more than ever, we must work together to strengthen our knowledge and skills on GBV coordination as gender equality and protection from further vulnerability and harm is a central responsibility of humanitarian action.â€ 

Australian High Commission, Sri Lanka and Maldives

On Day 3 of the Farmer-to-Farmer Africa Regional Meeting, participants split into groups to visit four host organizations in Kenya that have benefitted from #F2F volunteer experts. One group visited CAP-Youth Empowerment Institute Capacity Building (CAP YEI), an NGO that provides vocational training and teaches financial skills to youth members to help them work towards earning their own incomes. IESC's F2F volunteer experts have worked with CAP YEI on creating #financialliteracy training for youth, and mapping out potential financing sources for youth to expand their #agribusiness activities.

One of CAP YEIâ€™s major projects is its agricultural development demonstration center in Nyahururu, where youth interested in agriculture are taught how to cultivate high-value crops like strawberries (shown in the first photo) and French beans. #volunteer #accesstofinance #agribusiness #youthempowerment #F2FAfricaMeets

USAIDâ€™s youth employment and entrepreneurship project, YouLead, in coordination with Sri Lankan TV Derana and Jordan-based Partners for Good, aired its first season of the reality TV show Startup 21. Startup 21 promoted and encouraged youth entrepreneurship by featuring the ideas of 30 young entrepreneurs competing for the winning title. In April 2022, Startup 21 awarded the three winners of its first season: Venura Wijesekera, Gavesha, and Menaka Keerthi. The Support for Durable Resettlement (SDR) Project supports the resettlement of Internally Displaced Persons (#IDPs) and refugee returnees, providing them with durable #resettlement opportunities including access to essential basic services, #sustainable livelihoods and income generation #opportunities. 

Stories of Resettlement: In Trincomalee, the 'Anna Fisherman's Cooperative Society' has been around for generations. After the conclusion of the war, returnees such as Gauthaman, Sivakumar, and Sridharan struggled to find means to support their families without fishing equipment. The SDR Project stepped in to provide boats, GPS systems, eco sounders and ice boxes to help improve the livelihoods of the fishermen. 

The SDR Project is implemented by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in Sri Lanka together with the Government of Sri Lanka, with funding from the British High Commission in #Colombo, across 4 Districts in #Jaffna, #Kilinochchi, #Mullaitivu and #Trincomalee and the Pacific #fundingwindows.

On the second day of the #FarmertoFarmer #Africa Regional Meeting in Nairobi, hosted by IESC F2F staff, over 60 attendees discussed important issues related to F2F program implementation, including communication strategies like publishing success stories and articles, M&E data collection, and volunteer strategies. A panel of F2F #volunteers presented their experience to the group, discussing their work using the paired remote model which was introduced in 2020 due to the impacts of COVID-19. Over the past three months, IESC's USDA-funded Trade Safe (TraSa) Project in the Dominican Republic has been working on a communications campaign focused on educating consumers about maintaining food safety using four key actions: clean, separate, cook, and chill. IESC developed an effective influencer marketing strategy, working with some of the most popular figures in the DR, along with targeted online advertising, thoughtful public relations, and dynamic media tours. As a result of these efforts, the campaign has reached nearly 4 million consumers who are now more aware of how they can take care of their families by maintaining food safety in their homes.

IESCâ€™s USDA-funded Market Oriented Dairy (MOD) project in Sri Lanka knows the importance of safe, hygienic milk in growing the dairy industry. Through MOD, IESC promotes best practices for hygienic milking, transportation, and proper maintenance of chilling facilities for processors like Chello Dairies, while incentivizing them to pay producers higher prices for meeting quality standards. By adopting the best practices promoted by MOD, Chello Dairies has been able to reduce the amount of milk they reject due to safety issues by 50%, delivering better and safer milk to consumers. By promoting safe milk to both producers and consumers and encouraging higher prices for meeting quality standards, IESC aims to raise safety standards throughout the dairy industry in Sri Lanka. #worldfoodsafetyday

As the #Olympics2022 games continue in #Beijing, we highlight the atrocities and injustices which #China has committed against human rights defenders. 

Human rights abuse and violations by the hosts of one of the biggest sporting events in the world cannot go unacknowledged.

If long pre-trial arbitrary detention of human rights defenders is an Olympic sport, China would easily hold the world record in gold medal wins. Woman human rights lawyer Li Yuhan was detained for 1472 days before her trial in October 2021. Land and housing rights defender Chen Jianfang was detained for 730 days before her trial in March 2021. The verdicts in both cases have yet to be published.

The BRS COPs are starting from today, 1st to 12th May 2023 at Geneva, Switzerland. The gathering hosts sixteenth meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Basel Convention (BC COP-16), the eleventh meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Rotterdam Convention (RC COP-11) and the eleventh meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Stockholm Convention (SC COP-11). The theme for this Conferences of the Parties to the three conventions is,  â€œAccelerating action: Targets for the sound management of chemicals and wasteâ€. As an organization engaged in research and advocacy on chemical contamination, Centre for Environmental Justice is all ears on the outcomes of this COPs.

Web page: http://www.brsmeas.org/2023COPs/Overview/tabid/9316/language/en-US/Default.aspx
